Journal of Machine Learning Research Submitted th July Published Kernel Matrix Determinant Estimates from stopped hole sky Decomposition Simon Bartels bartels di ku dk University of Copenhagen Universit ets park en Kbe nh avn Denmark Wouter Booms ma wb di ku dk University of Copenhagen Universit ets park en Kbe nh avn Denmark Jes Fr ells en jef tu dk Technical University of Denmark Richard Petersen lads Kgs Lyngby Denmark Damien Garr eau damien garr eau nice fr Universit Cote Azur In ria CNRS LJ AD Parc Val rose Nice Cede France Editor Abstract Algorithms involving Gaussian processes or determinant al point processes typically require computing the determinant of kernel matrix Frequently the latter is computed from the hole sky decomposition an algorithm of cubic complexity in the size of the matrix We show that under mild assumptions it is possible to estimate the determinant from only sub matrix with probabilistic guarantee on the relative error We present an augmentation of the hole sky decomposition that stops under certain conditions before processing the whole matrix Experiments demonstrate that this can save considerable amount of time while having an overhead of less than when not stopping early More generally we present probabilistic stopping strategy for the approximation of sum of known length where addends are revealed sequentially We do not assume independence between addends only that they are bounded from below and decrease in conditional expectation Keywords Gaussian Processes Optimal Stopping Kernel Methods rig ing Eq

Tag Rec Automated Tagging of Questions with Hierarchical Learning Taxonomy cid Ven tesh Mukesh Mohan and Vikram Goya Indraprastha Institute of Information Technology Delhi ven tesh mukesh vikram iii td ac in Abstract Online educational platforms organize academic questions based on hierarchical learning taxonomy subject chapter topic Auto mati call tagging new questions with existing taxonomy will help organize these questions into die rent classes of hierarchical taxonomy so that they can be searched based on the facets like chapter topic This task can be formulated as at multi class classic ation problem Usually at classic ation based methods ignore the semantic relatedness between the terms in the hierarchical taxonomy and the questions Some traditional methods also sue from the class imbalance issues as they consider only the leaf nodes ignoring the hierarchy Hence we formulate the problem as similarity based retrieval task where we optimize the semantic rel at ed ness between the taxonomy and the questions We demonstrate that our method helps to handle the unseen labels and hence can be used for taxonomy tagging in the wild like the question answer forums In this method we augment the question with its corresponding answer to capture more semantic information and then align the question answer pairs contextual zed embedding with the corresponding label taxonomy vector representations The representations are aligned by ne tuning transformer based model with loss function that is combination of the cosine similarity and hinge rank loss The loss function maximizes the similarity between the question answer pair and the correct label rep resent at ions and minimizes the similarity to unrelated labels Finally we perform extensive experiments on two real world datasets We empirically show that the proposed learning method outperforms representations learned using the multi class classic ation method and other state of the art methods by as measured by Recall We also demonstrate the performance of the proposed method on unseen but related learning content like the learning objectives without re training the network Keywords Hinge rank loss multi class classic ation Information retrieval cid This work is supported by Extra marks Education an education technology company and TiH nub hut III TD

Proceedings of Machine Learning Research Machine Learning for Healthcare Read Attend and Code Pushing the Limits of Medical Codes Prediction from Clinical Notes by Machines Byung Hak Kim hak kim aka com Va run Gana pathi va run aka com AKA South San Francisco CA USA Editor Editors name Abstract Prediction of medical codes from clinical notes is both practical and essential need for every healthcare delivery organization within current medical systems Automating anno ation will save sign cant time and excessive ort spent by human coders today However the biggest challenge is directly identifying appropriate medical codes out of several thou sands of high dimensional codes from unstructured free text clinical notes In the past three years with Convolutional Neural Networks CNN and Long Short Term Memory LTS networks there have been vast improvements in tackling the most challenging benchmark of the MIMIC III full label inpatient clinical notes data set This progress raises the fundamental question of how far automated machine learning ML systems are from human coders working performance We assessed the baseline of human coders per for man ce on the same sub sampled testing set We also present our Read Attend and Code RAC model for learning the medical code assignment mappings By connecting con vol ved embedding with self attention and code title guided attention modules combined with sentence permutation based data augmentations and stochastic weight averaging training RAC establishes new state of the art SOTA considerably outperforming the current best Macro by and reaches past the human level coding baseline This new milestone marks meaningful step toward fully autonomous medical coding AMC in machines reaching parity with human coders performance in medical code prediction

The Real Meaning of Quantum Mechanics Francois Igor Pris Abstract suggest contextual realist interpretation of Carlo Rove ll is relational quantum mechanics The principal point is correct understanding of the concept of reality and taking into account the categorical distinction between the ideal and the real Within my interpretation consciousness of the observer does not play any metaphysical role The proposed approach can also be understood as return to the Copenhagen interpretation of quantum mechanics corrected within the framework of contextual realism The contextual realism allows one to get rid of the metaphysical problems encountered by various interpretations of quantum mechanics including the relational one wave function neither literally reflects an exterior reality nor is it merely predictive mathematical tool In particular an entangled wave function can be viewed as the formal cause of quantum correlations whose reality is contextual The reduction of wave function is not real physical process And there are no autonomous quantum events which would be different from the facts of their representation The quantum measurement problem results from confusion between the categories of the ideal and the real It is dissolved logically The quantum theory plays the role of Wittgenstein ian rule norm measuring physical reality within language game of its application Keywords relational quantum mechanics contextual realism Wittgenstein ian rule quantum correlation quantum measurement problem

Mean el interactions in evolutionary spatial games Dmitriy Antonov Evgeni Bur ovsk and Lev Sh chur HSE University Moscow Russia and Landau Institute for Theoretical Physics Cher no go lov ka Russia We introduce mean el term to an evolutionary spatial game model Namely we consider the game of Nowak and May based on the Prisoners dilemma and augment the game rules by self consistent mean el term This way an agent operates based on local information from its neighbors and non local information via the mean el coupling We simulate the model and construct the steady state phase diagram which shows sign cant new features due to the mean el term The main eec ts are observed for stationary steady states which are parametric ally close to chaotic states the mean el coupling drives such stationary states into spatial chaos Mean el games demonstrate continuous change between steady states contrary to the original Nowak and May game discontinuous changes

in Process System bases on the Knowledge Rocks framework Visual cues for abnormal values and instances from the knowledge base are added to the spiral plot of the analyzed data using stream graph The time slider is augmented to show related instances from the knowledge base Abstract We present Knowledge Rocks an implementation strategy and guideline for augmenting visualization systems to knowledge assisted visualization systems as de ned by the KAVA model Visualization systems become more and more sophisticated Hence it is increasingly important to support users with an integrated knowledge base in making constructive choices and drawing the right conclusions We support the effective reactivation of visualization software resources by augmenting them with knowledge assistance To provide general and yet supportive implementation strategy we propose an implementation process that bases on an application agnostic architecture This architecture is derived from existing knowledge assisted visualization systems and the KAVA model Its centerpiece is an ontology that is able to automatically analyze and classify input data linked to database to store class ed instances We discuss design decisions and advantages of the KR framework and illustrate its broad area of application in diverse integration possibilities of this architecture into an existing visualization system In addition we provide detailed case study by augmenting an it security system with knowledge assistance facilities Index Terms Knowledge Assisted Visualization Ontology IT Security

Dynamic Portal Occlusion for Pre computed Interactive Sound Propagation Nik un Raghu van shi Abstract Anim mer sive audio visual experience in games and virtual reality requires fast calculation of diffraction based acoustic effects To maintain plausibility the effects must retain spatial smoothness on source and listener motion within geometrically complex scenes Pre computed wave based techniques can render such results at low runtime CPU cost but remain limited to static scenes Modeling the occlusion effect of dynamic portals such as doors present an unresolved challenge to maintain audio visual consistency We present fast solution implementable as drop in extension to existing pre computed systems Key is novel portal search method that leverages pre computed propagation delay and direction data to nd portals intervening the diffract ed shortest path connecting dynamic source and listener at runtime The method scales linearly with number of portals in worst case far cheaper than explicit global path search that scales with scene area We discuss culling techniques to accelerate further The search algorithm is combined with geometric acoustic approximations to model the additional direct and indirect energy loss from intervening portals depending on their dynamic closure state We demonstrate plausible audio visual animations within our system integrated with Unreal Engine TM and wise TM Index Terms sound propagation diffraction dynamic portal

Fast Temporal Decomposition Procedure for Long horizon Nonlinear Dynamic Programming Sen Na Department of Statistics University of Chicago senna chicago edu Mihai An it escu Mathematics and Computer Science Division Argonne National Laboratory an it escu mcs anl gov Mladen Kolar Booth School of Business University of Chicago mladen kolar chicago booth edu We propose fast temporal decomposition procedure for solving long horizon nonlinear dynamic programs The core of the procedure is sequential quadratic programming QP with dieren ti able exact augmented Lagrangian being the merit function Within each QP iteration we solve the Newton system approximately using an overlapping temporal decomposition We show that the approximated search direction is still descent direction of the augmented Lagrangian provided the overlap size and penalty parameters are suitably chosen which allows us to establish global convergence Moreover we show that unit step size is accepted locally for the approximated search direction and further establish uniform local linear convergence over stages Our local convergence rate matches the rate of the recent Schwarz scheme However the Schwarz scheme has to solve nonlinear sub problems to optimal it yin each iteration while we only perform one Newton step instead Numerical experiments validate our theories and demonstrate the superiority of our method Key words nonlinear dynamic programming temporal decomposition sequential quadratic programming augmented Lagrangian

Net Attention Augmented Real Time Object Detection Abhi nav Sagar Independent Researcher Mumbai India abhi nav sagar gmail com Abstract In this work we address the problem of object detection from point cloud data in realtime For autonomous vehicles to work it is very important for the perception component to detect the real world objects with both high accuracy and fast inference We propose novel neural network architecture along with the training and optimization details for detecting objects using point cloud data We present anchor design along with custom loss functions used in this work combination of spatial and channel wise attention module is used in this work We use the Kitti Birds Eye View data set for benchmarking and validating our results Our method surpasses previous state of the art in this domain both in terms of average precision and speed running at FPS Finally we present the abl ation study to demonstrate that the performance of our network is general iz able This makes it feasible option to be deployed in realtime applications like self driving cars

ONLINE ICRC ICRC THE ASTRO PARTICLE PHYSICS CONFERENCE Berlin Germany THE ASTRO PARTICLE PHYSICS CONFERENCE CoBs meri cl iRn th yI Ct Geo ren rfa emt rie ann nca eyl July Reconstruction of Neutrino Events in Ice Cube using Graph Neural Networks The Ice Cube Collaboration completelist of authors can be found at the end of the proceedings mail martin ha minh ice cube wis edu The Ice Cube Neutrino Observatory is cubic kilometer scale neutrino detector embedded in the Antarctic ice of the South Pole In the near future the detector will be augmented by extensions such as the Ice Cube Upgrade and the planned Gen detector The sparseness of observed light in the detector for low energy events and the irregular detector geometry have always been challenge to the reconstruction of the detected neutrinos parameters of interest This challenge remains with the Ice Cube Upgrade currently under construction which introduces seven new detector strings with novel detector modules The Upgrade modules will increase the detection rate of low energy events and allow us to further constrain neutrino oscillation physics However the geometry of these modules render existing traditional reconstruction algorithms more di cult to use We introduce new reconstruction algorithm based on Graph Neural Networks which we use to reconstruct neutrino events at much faster processing times than the traditional algorithms while providing comparable resolution We show that our algorithm is applicable not only to reconstructing data of the current Ice Cube detector but also simulated events for next generation extensions such as the Ice Cube Upgrade Corresponding authors Martin Ha Minh Technical University Munich Presenter th International Cosmic Ray Conference ICRC July th rd Online Berlin Germany Copyright owned by the author under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution NonCommercial No Derivatives International License CC BY NC ND https pos is it

AVA Augmentation Augmented Variation al Auto encoders William Falcon An any Harsh ha Teddy Kok er Kyung hyun Cho Grid Labs New York University CI FAR Fellow will an any grid Abstract Recent methods for self supervised learning can be grouped into two paradigms contrastive and non contrastive approaches Their success can largely be attributed to data augmentation pipelines which generate multiple views of single input that preserve the underlying semantics In this work we introduce augmentation augmented variation al auto encoders AVA third approach to self supervised learning based on auto encoding We derive AVA starting from the conventional variation al auto encoder VA by replacing the KL divergence regular iz ation which is agnostic to the input domain with data augmentations that explicitly encourage the internal representations to encode domain spec ic in variances and qui variances We empirically evaluate the proposed AVA Eon image classic tion similar to how recent contrastive and non contrastive learning algorithms have been evaluated Our experiments con rm the effectiveness of data augmentation as replacement for KL divergence regular iz ation The AVA outperforms the VA by on CI FAR and on ST The results for AVA are largely comparable to the state of the art for self supervised learning

Structure Preserving Multi Domain Stain Color Augmentation using Style Transfer with Disentangled Representations Sophia Wagner Nadi eh Khalil agha Sharma Melanie Box berg Carsten Marr Walter de Back Ting ying Peng Technical University Munich Munich Germany Helmholtz Neu her berg Germany Institute for Computational Biology Helmholtz Zentrum Munich Germany Munich School of Data Science MuDS Munich Germany ul Context Vision AB Stockholm Sweden Abstract In digital pathology die rent staining procedures and can ner cause substantial color variations in whole slide images WS Is es pec ally across die rent laboratories These color shifts result in poor generalization of deep learning based methods from the training domain to external pathology data To increase test performance stain normal iz ation techniques are used to reduce the variance between training and test domain Alternatively color augmentation can be applied during training leading to more robust model without the extra step of color normalization attest time We propose novel color augmentation tech ni que Hist AuG AN that can simulate wide variety of realistic histology stain colors thus making neural networks stain invariant when applied during training Based on generative adversarial network GAN for image to image translation our model disentangles the content of the image the morphological tissue structure from the stain color at tributes It can be trained on multiple domains and therefore learns to cover die rent stain colors as well as other domain spec ic variations introduced in the slide preparation and imaging process We demon st rate that Hist AuG AN outperforms conventional color augmentation techniques on classic ation task on the publicly available data set Came lyon and show that it is able to mitigate present batch eec ts Keywords color augmentation style transfer disentangled re pre sen tat ions

Quantum mechanical work Pinto Silva and Angelo Department of Physics Federal University of Parana Box Curitiba Parana Brazil Regarded as one of the most fundamental concepts of classical mechanics and thermodynamics work has received well grounded den it ions within the quantum framework since the having being successfully applied to many contexts Recent developments on the concept have taken place in the emergent el of quan tum thermodynamics where work is frequently characterized as stochastic variable Notwithstanding this remarkable progress it is still debatable whether some sensible notion of work can be posed for strictly quan tum instance involving few particle system prepared in pure state and abandoned to its closed autonomous dynamics By treating work as quantum mechanical observable with well de ned classical limit here we show that this scenario can be satisfactorily materialized We prove by explicit examples that one can indeed ascribe ei gen bases for work operators This opens the room for frameworks involving quantum superposition and non local steering of work We also show that the commonly used two point measurement protocols can be inappropriate to describe work and other two time physical quantities specially in semi classical regime However subtle it maybe our quantum mechanical notion of work is experimentally testable and requires an updating of our intuition towards the concept of two time elements of reality In this context we derive work energy uncertainty relation and illustrate how energy conservation emerges as an element of the physical reality

SUBMITTED TO IEEE CCG Contrastive Cascade Graph Learning Xo vee Xu Fan Zhou Kun peng Zhang and Si yuan Liu Abstract Supervised learning while prevalent for information cascade modeling often requires abundant labeled data in training and the trained model is not easy to generalize across tasks and datasets Semi supervised learning facilitates unlabeled data for cascade understanding in pre training It often learns ne grained feature level representations which can easily result in overt ting for downstream tasks Recently contrastive self supervised learning is designed to alleviate these two fundamental issues in linguistic and visual tasks However its direct applicability for cascade modeling especially graph cascade related tasks remains under explored In this work we present Contrastive Cascade Graph Learning CCG novel framework for cascade graph representation learning in contrastive self supervised and task agnostic way In particular CCG Lr st designs an effective data augmentation strategy to capture variation and uncertainty Second it learns generic model for graph cascade tasks via self supervised contrastive pre training using both unlabeled and labeled data Third CCG learns task spec ic cascade model via ne tuning using labeled data Finally to make the model transferable across datasets and cascade applications CCG further enhances the model via distillation using teacher student architecture We demonstrate that CCG sign cant ly outperforms its supervised and semi supervised counterparts for several downstream tasks Index Terms Information cascade contrastive self supervised learning graph learning information diffusion data augmentation cid

VI Pose Real time Visual Inertial Object Pose Tracking Run dong Ge and Giuseppe Loi anno time Abstract Estimating the pose of objects is bene cia for robotics tasks such as transportation autonomous navigation manipulation as well as in scenarios beyond robotics like virtual and augmented reality With respect to single image pose estimation pose tracking takes into account the temporal in for mati on across multiple frames to overcome possible detection inconsistencies and to improve the pose estimation efc ien cy In this work we introduce novel Deep Neural Network NN called VI Pose that combines inertial and camera data to address the object pose tracking problem in real time The key contribution is the design of novel NN architecture which fuses visual and inertial features to predict the objects relative pose between consecutive image frames The overall pose is then estimated by consecutively combining relative poses Our approach shows remarkable pose estimation results Fig Visual Inertial object pose tracking top Speed for heavily occluded objects that are well known to be very accuracy benchmark on our VI CB data set with respect to challenging to handle by existing state of the art solutions state of the art solutions bottom The effectiveness of the proposed approach is validated on new data set called VI CB with RGB image IMU data and accurate pose annotations created by employing an Recent RGB based object pose tracking methods automated labeling technique The approach presents accuracy achieved good tracking performances However performances comparable to state of the art techniques but these methods are not robust to severe occlusions which with the additional be net of being real time enforce the re initialization of the pose tracking process

Physical Review Materials in press Pressure induced anomalies in the magnetic transitions of the exotic multi ferro ic material Tb BaNi yer Ram Kumar Raya pro Ma it and Sam path kumaran Department of Condensed Matter Physics and Materials Science Tata Institute of Fundamental Research Hom Bha bha Road Cola ba Mumbai India UGC DAE Consortium for Scientific Research Mumbai Centre BAR Campus Trom bay Mumbai India Hom Bha bha Centre for Science Education Tata Institute of Fundamental Research Pura Mar Man khurd Mumbai India We have studied the influence of external pressure up to GPa on the magnetic transitions of the ortho rhombi Haldane spin chain compound Tb BaNi an exotic multi ferro ic material This parent compound is known to undergo Nel ordering at and another magnetic transition at at which ferro electricity sets in however without any change in the magnetic symmetry but with only sharp change in the canting angle of Tb and Ni magnetic moments There is subtle difference in the anti ferromagnetic state above and below which is supported by the fact that there is meta magnetic transition below only for at kO We report here that with the application of external pressure there is an upward shift of while shifts towards lower temperatures It is interesting that the two magnetic transitions in the same compound behave differently under pressure and the opposite behavior at is attributed to local distortion leading to ferro electricity The results are augmented by temperature dependent ray diffraction and positive chemical pressure studies The chemical pressure caused by the iso electronic doping at Ba site by Sr reduces both the transition temperatures Clearly the external pressure favors anti ferromagnetic coupling that is leading to enhancement whereas the chemical pressure reduces suggesting important role of the changes in local hybridization induced by doping on magnetism in this material

Predicting Take over Time for Autonomous Driving with Real World Data Robust Data Augmentation Models and Evaluation Aks hay Ranges Nac hike Deo Ross Greer uji th Gun arat ne and Mohan rive di Laboratory for Intelligent Safe Automobiles UC San Diego Toyota Collaborative Safety Research Center ranges re greer nde mtr iv edi ucsd edu uji th gun arat ne toyota com Abstract Understanding occupant vehicle interactions by modeling control transitions is important to ensure safe ap roaches to passenger vehicle automation Models which contain contextual semantically meaningful representations of driver states can be used to determine the appropriate timing and conditions for transfer of control between driver and vehicle However such models rely on real world control take over data from drivers engaged in distracting activities which is costly to collect Here we introduce scheme for data augmentation for such data set Using the augmented data set we develop and train take overtime TO models that operate sequentially on mid and high level features produced by computer vision algorithms operating on different driver facing camera views showing models trained on the augmented data set to outperform the initial data set The demonstrated model features encode different aspects of the driver state pertaining to the face hands foot and upper body of the driver We perform ablative ex per im ents on feature combinations as well as model architectures showing that TO model supported by augmented data can be used to produce continuous estimates of take over times without delay suitable for complex real world scenarios

Early and accurate diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease AD and its pro droma period mild cognitive impairment MCI is essential for the delayed disease progression and the improved quality of patients life The emerging computer aided diagnostic methods that combine deep learning with structural magnetic resonance imaging MRI have achieved encouraging results but some of them are limit of issues such as data leakage and unexplainable diagnosis In this research we propose novel end to end deep learning approach for automated diagnosis of AD and localization of important brain regions related to the disease from MRI data This approach is based on two dimensional single model strategy and has the following differences from the current approaches Convolutional Neural Network CNN models of different structures and capacities are evaluated systemic ally and the most suitable model is adopted for AD diagnosis data augmentation strategy named Two stage Random Rand Augment TR RA is proposed to Data Development of Topographic Maps in Neural Field Theory with Short Time Scale Dependent Plasticity Nicholas Gale Jennifer Rodger Michael Small Stephen glen Centre for Mathematical Sciences Wilberforce Rd Cambridge CB WA School of Biological Sciences Stirling Hwy Crawley WA Australia School of Physics Mathematics and Computer Science Stirling Hwy Crawley WA Australia Abstract Topographic maps are brain structure connecting pre syn pati and post synaptic brain regions Topographic development is dependent on He bbi an based plasticity mechanisms working in conjunction with spontaneous patterns of neural activity generated in the pre synaptic regions Studies performed in mouse have shown that these spontaneous patterns can exhibit complex spatial temporal structures which existing models cannot incorporate Neural el theories are appropriate modelling paradigms for topographic systems due to the dense nature of the connections between regions and can be augmented with plasticity rule general enough to capture complex time varying structures We propose theoretical framework for studying the development of topography in the context of complex spatial temporal activity fed forward from the pre synaptic to post synaptic regions Analysis of the model leads to an analytic solution corroborating the conclusion that activity can drive the rene ment of topographic projections The analysis also suggests that biological noise is used in the development of topography to stabilise the dynamics MC MC simulations are used to analyse and understand the dieren ces in topographic rene ment between wild type and the knock out mutant in mice The time scale of the synaptic plasticity window is estimated as seconds in this context with model of Key Words Topographic maps neural el theory ST DP plasticity spontaneous activity He bbi an dynamics neural organisation

Jarvis for Aero engine Analytics Speech Enhanced Virtual Reality Demonstrator Based on Mining Knowledge Databases Saw mir Konrad Ta deja cid Krzysztof Kut Yup uL cid Prana yS es had ri Grzegorz Nal epa Per Ola Kristen son cid cid Department of Engineering University of Cambridge Cambridge Institute of Applied Computer Science Jagiellonian University in Krak Krak Poland Data Centric Engineering The Alan Turing Institute London Department of Mathematics Imperial College London Abstract In this paper we present Virtual Reality VR based environment where the engineer interacts with incoming data from eet of aero engines This data takes the form of computer aided design CAD engine models coupled with characteristic plots for the subsystems of each engine Both the plots and models can be interacted with and manipulated using speech org est ural input The characteristic data is ported to knowledge based system underpinned by knowledge graph storing complex domain knowledge This permits the system to respond to queries about the current state and health of each aero engine asset Responses to these questions require some degree of analysis which is handled by semantic knowledge representation layer managing information on aero engine subsystems This paper represents sign cant step forward for aero engine analysis in bespoke VR environment and brings usa step closer to Jarvis like system for aero engine analytics

Foto ni ques The Barcelona Institute of Science and Technology Castell de fels Barcelona Spain School of Engineering and Physical Sciences He riot Watt University Edinburgh EH AS UK german mora ed ac uk Abstract time of ig ht oF imaging is used in variety of applications such as augmented reality AR computer interfaces robotics and autonomous systems Single photon avalanche diodes PADs are one of the enabling technologies providing accurate depth data even over long ranges By developing PADs in array format with integrated processing combined with pulsed ood type illumination high speed capture is possible However array sizes tend to be relatively small limiting the lateral resolution of the resulting depth maps and consequently the information that can be extracted from the image for applications such as object detection In this paper we demonstrate that these limitations can be overcome through the use of convolutional neural networks CNN for high performance object detection We present outdoor results from portableS PAD camera system that outputs bin photon timing histograms with spatial resolution The results obtained with exposure times down to ms equivalent to FPS and in signal to background BR ratios slow as point to the advantages of providing the CNN with full histogram data rather than point clouds alone Alternatively combination of point cloud and active intensity data may be used as input for similar level of performance In either case the GPU accelerated processing time is less than ms per frame leading to an overall latency image acquisition plus processing in the millisecond range making the results relevant for safety critical computer vision applications which would be net from faster than human reaction times

Predicting the Future from First Person Egocentric Vision Survey Ivan Rodina Antonin oF urn aria Dimitrios avro ed is Giovanni Maria Far in ella Department of Mathematics and Informatics University of Catania Andrea Doria Catania Italy Philips Research High Tech Campus Eindhoven Netherlands Abstract Egocentric videos can bring lot of information about how humans perceive the world and interact with the environment which can be bene cia for the analysis of human behaviour The research in egocentric video analysis is developing rapidly thanks to the increasing availability of wearable devices and the opportunities oe red by new large scale egocentric datasets As computer vision techniques continue to develop at an increasing pace the tasks related to the prediction of future are starting to evolve from the need of understanding the present Predicting future human activities trajectories and interactions with objects is crucial in applications such as human robot interaction assist ive wearable technologies for both industrial and daily living scenarios entertainment and virtual or augmented reality This survey summarise the evolution of studies in the context of future prediction from egocentric vision making an overview of applications devices existing problems commonly used datasets models and input modalities Our analysis highlights that methods for future prediction from egocentric vision can have sign cant impact in range of applications and that further research or ts should be devoted to the standardisation of tasks and the proposal of datasets considering real world scenarios such as the ones with an industrial vocation

Maximize the Foot Clearance for Hopping Robotic Leg Considering Motor Saturation Jun tong Sua Bing chen in Shu sheng Yea Le cheng Ru anc aiming Sun Ning Ding il iF ud and Jian wen Luo Shenzhen Institute of Art ici al Intelligence and Robotics for Society AIRS Shenzhen China Institute of Robotics and Intelligent Manufacturing RIM The Chinese University of HongKong CU HK Shenzhen China Beijing Institute of General Art ici al Intelligence BIG Beijing China State Key Laboratory of Robotics and System Harbin Institute of Technology Harbin China ARTICLE INFO ABSTRACT Keywords hopping leg no matter in legged animals or humans usually behaves like spring during the peri legged locomotion odi chopping Hopping like spring is ec ent and without the requirement of complicated control two mass model algorithms Position and force control are two main methods to realize such spring like behaviour motor saturation The position control usually consumes the torque resources to ensure the position accuracy and com hopping leg pens ate the tracking errors In comparison the force control strategy is able to maintain high el as ti city Currently the position and force control both leads to the discount of motor saturation ratio as well as the bandwidth of the control system and thus attenuates the performance of the actuator To augment the performance this letter proposes motor saturation strategy based on the force control to maximize the output torque of the actuator and realize the continuous hopping motion with natural dynamics The proposed strategy is able to maximize the saturation ratio of motor and thus maximize the foot clearance of the single leg The dynamics of the two mass model is utilized to increase the force bandwidth and the performance of the actuator single leg with two degrees of freedom is designed as the experiment platform The actuator consists of powerful electric motor harmonic gear and encoder The eec ti ve ness of this method is ve ried through simulations and experiments using robotic leg actuated by powerful high reduction ratio actuators

fr these authors contributed equally to this work ABSTRACT Materials micro structures are signatures of their alloying composition and processing history Therefore micro structures exist in wide variety As materials become increasingly complex to comply with engineering demands advanced computer vision approaches such as deep learning DL inevitably gain relevance for quantifying micro tru cut ure constituents from micrographs While DL can outperform classical computer vision techniques by large margins for many tasks shortcomings are poor data efc ien cy and domain general iz ability across datasets This is inherently in conic with the expense associated with annotating materials data through experts and extensive materials diversity To tackle poor domain general iz ability and the lack of labeled data simultaneously we propose to apply sub class of transfer learning methods called unsupervised domain adaptation UDA This class of learning algorithms addresses the task of ding domain invariant features when supplied with annotated source data and un annotated target data such that performance on the latter distribution is optimized despite the absence of annotations Exemplar ly this study is conducted on lath shaped bai nite segmentation task in complex phase steel micrographs Here the domains to bridge are selected to be different metal lo graphic specimen preparations surface etchings typical for experimental scatter and distinct imaging modalities We show that state of the art UDA approach surpasses the nave application of source domain trained models on the target domain generalization baseline to large extent This holds true independent of the domain shift despite using low quantity data and even when the baseline models were pre trained or employed data augmentation Through UDA mean intersection over union mIo was improved over generalization baselines from to on three target datasets respectively This underlines this techniques potential to cope with materials variance

PROTO TRANSFORMER META LEARNING APPROACH TO PROVIDING STUDENT FEEDBACK Mike Wu Noah Goodman Chris Pie ch Chelsea Finn Department of Computer Science and Psychology Stanford University Stanford CA wu mike goodman pie ch cb finn stanford edu July ABSTRACT High quality computer science education is limited by the if cult of providing instructor feedback to students at scale While this feedback could in principle be automated supervised approaches to predicting the correct feedback are bottle necked by the intractability of annotating large quantities of student code In this paper we instead frame the problem of providing feedback as few shot classic ation where meta learner adapts to give feedback to student code on new programming question from just few examples annotated by instructors Because data for meta training is limited we propose number of amendments to the typical few shot learning framework including task augmentation to create synthetic tasks and additional side information to build stronger priors about each task These additions are combined with transformer architecture to embed discrete sequences code to prototypical representation of feedback class label On suite of few shot natural language processing tasks we match or outperform state of the art performance Then on collection of student solutions to exam questions from an introductory university course we show that our approach reaches an average precision of on unseen questions surpassing the precision of teaching assistants Our approach was successfully deployed to deliver feedback to student exam solutions in programming course offered by tier university This is to the best of our knowledge the rst successful deployment of machine learning based feedback to open ended student code

try and Remote Sensing ETH Zurich Switzerland TH AO TON THAT WHELAN and BRENDA YO International Committee of the Red Cross ICRC Switzerland ERDA OF LI and MUHAMMAD IMRAN Qatar Computing Research Institute HBK Qatar Humanitarian actions require accurate information to efficiently delegate support operations Such information can be maps of building footprints building functions and population densities While the access to this information is comparably easy in industrialized countries thanks to reliable census data and national geo data infrastructures this is not the case for developing countries where that data is often incomplete or outdated Building maps derived from remote sensing images may partially remedy this challenge in such countries but are not always accurate due to different landscape configurations and lack of validation data Even when they exist building footprint layers usually do not reveal more fine grained building properties such as the number of stories or the buildings function office residential school etc In this project we aim to automate building footprint and function mapping using heterogeneous data sources In first step we intend to delineate buildings from satellite data using deep learning models for semantic image segmentation Building functions shall be retrieved by parsing social media data like for instance tweets as well as ground based imagery to automatically identify different buildings functions and retrieve further information such as the number of building stories Building maps augmented with those additional attributes make it possible to derive more accurate population density maps needed to support the targeted provision of humanitarian aid CCS Concepts Human centered computing Computing methodologies Machine learning ACM Reference Format Benjamin Kellenberger John Vargas Mu oz Dev is Tui Rodrigo Daud Konrad Schindler Th oT on That Whelan Brenda yo erda Of li and Muhammad Imran Mapping Vulnerable Populations with In ACM SIG DD Conference on Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining August Singapore ACM New York NY USA pages

Winning the Ransom ware Lottery Game Theoretic Model for Mitigating Ransom ware Attacks Erick Ga linkin Rapid Boston MA USA erick ga linkin rapid com Abstract Ransom ware is growing threat to individuals and enter rises like constituting major factor in cyber insurance and in the security planning of every organization Although the game theoretic lens often frames the game as competition between equals prot maximizing attacker and loss minimizing defender the reality of many situations is that ransom ware organizations are not playing an on cooperative game they are playing lottery The want on behavior of attackers creates situation where many victims are hit more than once by ransom ware operators sometimes even by the same group If defend ers wish to combat malware they must then seek to remove the incentives of it In this work we construct an expected value model based on data from actual ransom ware attacks and identify three variables the value of pay ment the cost of an attack and the probability of payment Using this model we consider the potential to manipulate these variables to re duce the prot motive associated with ransom ware attack Based on the model we present mitigation to encourage an environment that is hos tile to ransom ware operators In particular wend that site backups and government incentives for their adoption are the most fruitful avenue for combating ransom ware Keywords Security Malware Economics Ransom ware Incentives Backups

Synthetic ow based crypto mining attack generation through Generative Adversarial Networks Alberto Moz ngel Gonz lez Prieto Antonio Pastor Sandra mez Ca naval and Edgar Talavera Universidad Polit nica de Madrid Madrid Spain Universidad Complutense de Madrid Madrid Spain Instituto de Ciencia Mate tic as SIC AM CM UC Madrid Spain Telef nica Madrid Spain moz up es Abstract Due to the growing rise of cyber attacks in the Internet ow based data sets are crucial to increase the performance of the Machine Learning ML components that run in network based intrusion detection systems IDS To overcome the existing network tra data shortage in attack analysis recent works propose Generative Adversarial Networks GANs for synthetic ow based network tra generation Data privacy is appearing more and more as strong requirement when processing such network data which suggests to nd solutions where synthetic data can fully replace real data Because of the ill convergence of the GAN training none of the existing solutions can generate high quality fully synthetic data that can totally substitute real data in the training of IDS ML components Therefore they mix real with synthetic data which acts only as data augmentation components leading to privacy breaches as real data is used In sharp contrast in this work we propose novel deterministic way to measure the quality of the syn the tic data produced by GAN both with respect to the real data and to its performance when used for ML tasks As byproduct we present heuristic that uses these metrics for selecting the best performing generator during GAN training leading to stopping criterion An additional heuristic is proposed to select the best performing GANs when die rent types of synthetic data are to be used in the same ML task We demonstrate the adequacy of our proposal by generating synthetic crypto mining attack tra and normal tra ow based data using an enhanced version of Wasser stein GAN We show that the generated syn the tic network tra can completely replace real data when training ML based crypto mining detector obtaining similar performance and avoiding privacy violations since real data is not used in the training of the ML based detector Keywords Network tra generation Generative Adversarial Networks crypto mining Jac card index Cyber range

Object aware Contrastive Learning for De biased Scene Representation Sang woo Mo Hyun woo Kang Kih yukS oh Chun Liang Li in woo Shin KAIST Google Cloud wmo hyun woo kang in woos kaist ac kr kih yuks chun liang google com Abstract Contrastive self supervised learning has shown impressive results in learning visual representations from unlabeled images by enforcing in variance against different data augmentations However the learned representations are often con textually biased to the spurious scene correlations of different objects or object and back ground which may harm their generalization on the downstream tasks To tackle the issue we develop novel object aware contrastive learning framework that rst localizes objects in self supervised manner and then de bias scene correlations via appropriate data augmentations considering the inferred object locations For we propose the contrastive class activation map Contra CAM which nds the most disc rim native regions objects in the image compared to the other images using the contrastive ly trained models We further improve the Contra CAM to detect multiple objects and entire shapes via an iterative rene ment procedure For we introduce two data augmentations based on Contra CAM object aware random crop and background mix up which reduce contextual and background biases during contrastive self supervised learning respectively Our experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of our representation learning frame work particularly when trained under multi object images or evaluated under the background and distribution shifted images

the available to users in many application scenarios While assessment of PC quality notably for decoded PCs is critical several PC objective quality metrics are already available and asks for the Deep Predictive Learning of Carotid Stenosis Severity Yi qu Diao Oliver Zhao Pri ya Kot hap all Peter Monte leone Chandra it Baja Abstract Carotid artery stenosis is the narrowing of carotid arteries which supplies blood to the neck and head In this work we train model to predict the severity of the stenosis blockage based on RUC criteria variables and other patient information We implement classic machine learning methods decision trees and random forests used in previous experiment In addition we improve the accuracy through the use of the state of art Augmented Neural ODE deep learning method Through systematic and theory rooted analysis we examine die rent parameters to achieve an accuracy of about These results show the strong potential in applying recently developing deep learning methods while simultaneously suggesting that the current data pro vi ded by the RUC criteria may be in uci ent to predict stenosis severity at high performance level

Cognitive Brain Dynamics Lab National Brain Research Centre Mane sar India Synaptic plasticity and neuron cross talk are some of the important key mechanisms underlying formation of dynamic clusters of active neurons The essence of this study is to model and decipher the mechanism of emergence of task spec ic functional connectivity among population of neurons We have used our proposed neuron activity pattern NAP model to de ne an assorted range of interactions and simulated across lattice with two state ring non ring neurons We observed the emergence of scale free hierarchically organized ordered patterns of active neurons that we call as functional cortical patterns FC Ps only at the near critical phase transition We have done extensive topological characterization of FC Ps and tested its con gruen cy with the functional brain networks obtained from the empirical electro physiological data of visual stimulus task Our results of network theory attributes fractal analysis and functional cartography have con med the transitioning eec while generation of FC Ps This gives us strong implication that the functional neuron al system supports far from equilibrium dynamics upon receiving stimulus Our investigation for the long critical and short ranged interactions has lead to an interpretation that near critical transition phase is spectrum of critical temperatures coupling strengths being aec ted by the distance between the neurons The range of interaction among neurons plays an important role in de ning the functional severity of the neuron al circuitry We propose that interaction range as function of coupling strength drives connectivity in an augmenting fashion as we observed an increase in coupling strength from short to long range interactions among the population of neurons This gives us insight towards the intensity of cognitive behaviour which is attained by multiple stimulus attempts Keywords Long range Ising model Neuron activity patterns task spec ic cognition Brain fun ional networking Near critical dynamics

First Principles estimation of the Superconducting Transition Temperature of Metallic Hydrogen Liquid Ha or an Chen Xiao Wei Zhang in Zheng Li and Jun ren Shi International Center for Quantum Materials Peking University Beijing China State Key Laboratory for Art ici al Micro structure and Mes osco pic Physics and School of Physics Peking University Beijing China Collaborative Innovation Center of Quantum Matter Beijing China Dated August We present rst principles implementation of the stochastic path integral approach proposed by Liu et al for estimating the superconducting transition temperature Tc of liquid The imp le ment ation is based on the all electron projector augmented wave PAW method We generalize Liu et al formalism to accommodate the pseudo description of electron states in the PAW method formula for constructing the overlap operator of the PAW method is proposed to eliminate errors due to the incompleteness of pseudo basis set We apply the implementation to estimate Tc of metallic hydrogen liquids It con rms Liu et al prediction that metallic hydrogen can form superconducting liquid

An augmented Lagrangian algorithm for recovery of ice thickness in unidirectional ow using the Shallow Ice Approximation Elizabeth Mc George Miguel Moyer Gonzalez Phillip Wilson Mathieu ellie rc aTe Kura Panga rau School of Mathematics and Statistics Level Jack Erskine Building University of Canterbury Private Bag Christchurch New Zealand ul Te Puna ha Mat at in Centre of Research Excellence University of Auckland Auckland New Zealand Department of Mechanical Engineering University of Canterbury Christchurch New Zealand Abstract key parameter in ice ow modelling is basal slipping at the ice bed interface as it can have large eec on the resultant ice thickness Unfortunately its contribution to surface observations can be hard to distinguish from that of bed undulations Therefore inferring the ice thickness from surface measurements is an interesting and non trivial inverse problem This paper presents method for recovering du ally the ice thickness and the basal slip using only surface elevation and speed measurements The unidirectional shallow ice approximation is rst implemented to model steady state ice ow for given bedrock and basal slip roles This surface is then taken as synthetic observed data An augmented Lagrangian algorithm is then used to nd the diu sion coe cie nt which gives the best to observations Combining this recovered diu sion with observed surface velocity simple Newtons method is used to recover both the ice thickness and basal slip The method was successful in each test case and this implies that it should be possible to recover both of these parameters in two dimensional cases also Keywords Inverse problems Augmented Lagrangian Ice ow Shallow ice Corresponding author Email address miguel moyer gonzalez canterbury ac nz Miguel Moyer Gonzalez Pre print submitted to Ar Xiv August

Non parametric posterior learning for emission tomography with multi modal data Fedor Goncharov Eric Bar at and Thomas aut remer Universit Paris clay CEA List Palais eau France August Abstract In this work we continue studies of the uncertainty quant cation problem in em is sion tomo graph ies such as PET or SPEC In particular we consider scenario when additional multi modal data anatomical MRI images are available To solve the aforementioned problem we adapt the recently proposed non parametric posterior learn ing technique to the context of Poisson type data in emission tomography Using this approach we derive sampling algorithms which are trivially parallel iz able scalable and very easy to implement In addition we prove conditional consistency and tightness for the distribution of produced samples in the small noise limit when the acquisition time tends to inn it and derive new geometrical and necessary condition on how MRI images must be used This condition arises naturally in the context of mis specie gen era liz ed Poisson models We also contrast our approach with bayesian MC MC sampling based on one data augmentation scheme which is very popular in the context of EM type algorithms for PET or SPEC We show theoretically and also numerically that such data augmentation sign cant ly increases mixing times for the Markov chain In view of this our algorithms seem to give reasonable trade between design complexity cal ability numerical load and as esse ment for the uncertainty quant cation

Spin polarized phases of super ids in neutron stars Takeshi Mizushima Shi ge hiro Ya sui Daisuke In otani and Mu neto Nitta Department of Materials Engineering Science Osaka University Toyo naka Osaka Japan Department of Physics Research and Education Center for Natural Sciences Keio University Hi yoshi Yokohama Kanagawa Japan Interdisciplinary Theoretical and Mathematical Sciences Program THEM RIKEN Wako Saitama Japan Dated August The interior of neutron star is expected to be occupied by neutron super id which is the condensate of spin triplet wave Cooper pairs of neutrons with total angular momentum Here we investigate the thermodynamic stability of super ids in neutron star interior under strong magnetic el Using the theory incorporating the nite size correction of neutron Fermi surface we show that the spin polarized phases of super ids the magnetized bi axial nematic phase and the ferromagnetic phase appear in high temperatures and high magnetic lds These phases were missed in the previous studies using the quasi classical approximation in which dispersions of neutrons are linear zed around the Fermi surface In particular the ferromagnetic phase which is the condensation of Cooper paired neutrons with fully polarized spins appears between the normal phase and the bi axial nematic phase and enlarge the thermodynamic stability of super ids under strong magnetic lds Furthermore we present the augmented Gi nzburg Landau theory that incorporates the thermodynamic stability of spin polarized super id phases

Study of Multilingual End to End Speech Recognition for Kazakh Russian and English Said Muss kho jay eva Yer bol at hassan ov and Hu sey in At akan arol Institute of Smart Systems and Art ici al Intelligence IS SAI Nazarbayev University Nur Sultan Kazakhstan said muss kho jay eva yer bol at hassan ov hvar ol nu edu kz Abstract We study training single end to end automatic speech recognition AS model for three languages used in Kazakhstan Kazakh Russian and English We rst describe the development of multilingual AS based on Transformer networks and then perform an ex ten sive assessment on the aforementioned languages We also compare two variants of output grapheme set construction combined and in de pen dent Furthermore we evaluate the impact of LMs and data augment tion techniques on the recognition performance of the multilingual AS In addition we present several datasets for training and evaluation purposes Experiment results show that the multilingual models achieve comparable performances to the monolingual baselines with similar number of parameters Our best monolingual and multilingual models achieved and average word error rates on the combined test set respectively To ensure the reproducibility of our experiments and results we share our training recipes datasets and pre trained models Keywords Speech recognition Multilingual End to end Data set Transformer Kazakh Russian English

Deep Rival Penalized Competitive Learning for Low resolution Face Recognition Pei ying Li Shi kui Tu Lei Xu Department of Computer Science and Engineering Shanghai Jiao Tong University Shanghai China Abstract Current face recognition tasks are usually carried out on high quality face im ages but in reality most face images are captured under un constrained or poor conditions by video surveillance Existing methods are featured by learning data uncertainty to avoid overt ting the noise or by adding margins to the angle or cosine space of the normalized soft max loss to penalize the target log it which enforces intra class compactness and inter class discrepancy In this paper we propose deep Rival Penalized Competitive Learning PCL for deep face recognition in low resolution LR images Inspired by the idea of the PCL our method further enforces regulation on the rival log it which is de ned as the largest non target log it for an input image Die rent from existing methods that only consider pen aliz ation on the target log it our method not only strengthens the learning towards the target label but also enforces reverse direction becoming de learning away from the rival label Comprehensive experiments demonstrate that our method improves the existing state of the art methods to be very robust for LR face recognition Keywords Face recognition Low resolution PCL Corresponding author Email addresses li pei ying sj tu edu cn Pei ying Li tush kui sj tu edu cn Shi kui Tu lei xu sj tu edu cn Lei Xu Pre print submitted to Neural Networks August

Comparative study of magnetic properties of Mn magnetic clusters in GaN using classical and quantum mechanical approach Ed at hum andy and Sz ten kiel Institute of Physics Polish Academy of Sciences PL Warszawa Poland Dated August Currently simulations of many body quantum systems are known to be computationally too demanding to be solved on classical computers The main problem is that the computation time and memory necessary for performing the calculations usually grow exponentially with the number of particles nec ent approach to simulate many body quantum systems is the use of classical approximation However it is known that atleast at low temperatures the allowed spin uc tu at ions in this approach are overestimated what results in enhanced thermal uc tu at ions It is therefore timely and important to assess the validity of the classical approximation To this end in this work we compare the results of numerical calculations of small Mn magnetic cluster sinG aN where the Mn spins are treated classically with those where they are treated quantum mechanically crystal el model In the rst case we solve the Landau Li fsh itz Gilbert LL equation that describes the precession al dynamics of spins represented by classical vectors On the other hand in the crystal el model the state of Mn ion cong ration with is characterized by the set of orbital and spin quantum numbers Particular attention is paid to use numerical parameters that ensure the same single ion magnetic an iso tro py in both classical and quantum approximation Finally detailed comparative study of magnetization as function of the magnetic el temperature number of ions in given cluster and the strength of super exchange interaction obtained from both approaches will be presented

Under consideration for publication in Fluid Me ch Liquid lm dynamics with immobile contact line during men is cus oscillation Xiao long Zhang and Vadim Nikolayev Universit Paris clay CEA CNRS SPEC Gif sur Yvette Cede France Received August revised xx accepted xx This paper presents theoretical analysis of the liquid lm dynamics during the oscillation of men is cus between liquid and its vapour in cylindrical capillary By using the theory of Taylor bubbles the dynamic role of the deposited liquid lm is calculated within the lubrication approximation accounting for the nite ness of the lm length for the presence of the contact line The latter is assumed to be pinned on surface defect and thus immobile the contact angle is allowed to vary The id ow eec on the curvature in the central men is cus part is neglected This curvature varies in time because of the lm variation and is si determined as apart of the solution The lm dynamics depends on the initial contact angle which is the maximal contact angle attained during oscillation The average lm thickness is studied as function of system parameters The numerical results are compared to existing experimental data and to the results of the quasi steady approximation Finally the problem of an oscillating men is cus is considered accounting for the super heating of the capillary wall with respect to the saturation temperature which causes evaporation When the super heating exceeds quite low threshold oscillations with pinned contact line are impossible anymore and the contact line receding caused by evaporation needs to be accounted for Keywords Bubble dynamics Contact lines Thin lms Lubrication theory Evaporation

Approximation of potential function in the problem of forced escape Pavel rav etc Oleg Gen del man Faculty of Mechanical Engineering Tech ni on Israel Institute of Technology Haifa Israel Abstract The paper addresses an escape of classical particle from potential well under harmonic forcing Most dangerous ec ent escape dynamics reveals itself in conditions of resonance and can be described in the framework of isolated resonant IR approximation The latter requires reformulation of the problem in terms of action angle variables available only for handful of the model potentials The paper suggests approximation of realistic generic potentials by low order polynomial functions admissible for the transformation with possible truncation To illustrate the idea we rst formulate the transformation and solve the escape problem in the IR approximation for generic quartic potential Then the model problem for dynamic pull in in micro electromechanical system MEM is analyzed The model electrostatic potential is approximated by the quartic polynomials globally and locally and quality of predicting the escape thresholds is assessed numerically Most accurate predictions are delivered by global optimal heuristic approximation Keywords escape from potential well resonance manifold MEM dynamic pull in

Distributed System Ident cation for Linear Stochastic Systems with Binary Sensors Ke wei Fu Han Fu Chen Wen xiao Zhao Key Laboratory of Systems and Control Academy of Mathematics and Systems Science Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing China School of Mathematical Sciences University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing China Abstract The problem of distributed ident cation of linear stochastic system with unknown coe fci ent over time varying networks is considered For estimating each agent in the network can only access the input and the binary valued output of the local system Compared with the existing works on distributed optimization and estimation the binary valued local output observation considered in the paper makes the problem challenging By assuming that the agent in the network can communicate with its adjacent neighbours stochastic approximation based distributed ident cation algorithm is proposed and the consensus and convergence of the estimates are established Finally numerical example is given showing that the simulation results are consistent with the theoretical analysis Index Terms Distributed system ident cation binary valued sensor stochastic approximation consensus convergence strong consistency

Parametric co linear xion photon instability Beyer Ma rocco Danson Bingham and Gregor Department of Physics University of Oxford Parks Road Oxford OX PU UK WE Aldermaston Reading RG PR UK Ox CHED Clarendon Laboratory Department of Physics University of Oxford UK Rutherford Appleton Laboratory Chilton Didcot OX QX UK Department of Physics University of Strathclyde Glasgow NG UK ions and xion like particles generically couple to QED via the xion photon photon inter action This leads to mo dication of Maxwell equations known in the literature as xion electrodynamics The new form of Maxwell equations gives rise to new parametric instability in which strong pump decays into scattered light wave and an xion This xion mode grows exponentially in time and leads to change in the polarisation of the initial laser beam therefore providing signal for detection Currently operating laser systems can put bounds on the xion parameter space however longer pulse lengths are necessary to reach the current best laboratory bounds of light shining through wall experiments

Manuscript Click here to view linked References Effect of the hydrogenation solvent in the HIP SAH hyper polarization of pyruvate Bond ar Cav all ari Carrera Aime Reiner Department of Molecular Biotechnology and Health Sciences Molecular Imaging Centre University of Torino Via Niz za Torino Italy Institute of Bio structures and Bio imaging National Research Council Via Niz za Torino Italy corresponding author email francesca reiner uni to it Abstract Para Hydrogen Induced Polarization Side Arm Hydrogenation HIP SAH is an inexpensive tool to obtain hyper polarized pyruvate and other metabolites that can be applied to in vivo diagnostics for the investigation of metabolic processes This method is based on hydrogenation using hydrogen enriched in the para isomer of unsaturated substrates catalyzed usually by homogeneous rhodium complex In this work the effect of the solvent on the hydrogenation efficiency and on the hyper polarization level were investigated Coordinating solvents such as acetone and methanol can increase significantly either the efficiency or the hyper polarization level but they are not compatible with the intended metabolic applications The phase extraction of the hyper polarized product sodium pyruvate in an aqueous solution was obtained carrying out the hydrogenation reaction in chloroform and toluene The traces of the organic solvents in the water phase were removed by means of filtration through lip phil ic resin thus improving the bio compatibility of the aqueous solution of the hyper polarized product

Bit efc ent Numerical Aggregation and Stronger Privacy for Trust in Federated Analytics Graham Cor mode Igor Markov gc or mode fb com markov fb com August Abstract Private data generated by edge devices from smartphones to automotive electronics are highly informative when aggregated but can be damaging when mishandled variety of solutions are being explored but have not yet won the public trust and full backing of mobile platforms In this work we propose numerical aggregation protocols that empirically improve upon prior art while providing comparable local differential privacy guarantees Sharing single private bit per value supports privacy metering that enable privacy controls and guarantees that are not covered by differential privacy We put emphasis on the ease of implementation compatibility with existing methods and compelling empirical performance

High dimensional change point estimation with heterogeneous missing ness Bertil le Fol la in Teng yao Wang and Richard Sam worth Statistical Laboratory University of Cambridge Department of Statistical Science University College London August Abstract We propose new method for change point estimation in partially observed high dimensional time series that undergo simultaneous change in mean in sparse subset of coordinates Our rst methodological contribution is to introduce Miss CU SUM transformation generalisation of the popular Cumulative Sum statistics that cap ture the interaction between the signal strength and the level of missing ness in each coordinate In order to borrow strength across the coordinates we propose to project these Miss CU SUM statistics along direction found as the solution to penal is ed optimisation problem tailored to the spec ic sparsity structure The change point can then be estimated as the location of the peak of the absolute value of the projected uni variate series In model that allows die rent missing ness probabilities in die rent component series we identify that the key interaction between the missing ness and the signal is weighted sum of squares of the signal change in each coordinate with weights given by the observation probabilities More spec ic ally we prove that the an le between the estimated and oracle projection directions as well as the change point location error are controlled with high probability by the sum of two terms both in vol ving this weighted sum of squares and representing the error incurred due to noise and the error due to missing ness respectively lower bound con rms that our change point estimator which we call Miss Inspect is optimal up to logarithmic factor The striking eec ti ve ness of the Miss Inspect methodology is further demonstrated both on simulated data and on an oceanographic data set covering the Neogene period Key words change point estimation missing data high dimensional data segmentation sparsity

Ultra fast hol ono mic quantum gates Pu Shen Tao Chen and Zheng Yuan Xue Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Quantum Engineering and Quantum Materials and School of Physics and Telecommunication Engineering South China Normal University Guangzhou China Guangdong HongKong Joint Laboratory of Quantum Matter and Frontier Research Institute for Physics South China Normal University Guangzhou China Dated August Quantum computation based on geometric phase is generally believed to be more robust against certain errors or noises than the conventional dynamical strategy However the gate error caused by the de coherence effect is inevitable and thus faster gate operations are highly desired Here we propose an on adiabatic hol ono mic quantum computation NH QC scheme based on detuned interactions on type three level system which combines the time optimal control technique with the time independent de tuning adjustment to further acc ler ate universal gate operations so that the gate time can be greatly shortened within the hardware limitation and thus high del it gates can be obtained Meanwhile our numerical simulations show that the gate robustness is also stronger than previous schemes Finally we present an implementation of our proposal on superconducting quantum circuits with de coherence free subspace encoding with the experimentally demonstrated para me tri call unable coupling technique which also implies previous investigations Therefore our protocol provides more promising alternative for future fault tolerant quantum computation

Virginia Tech USA TAN SHREE MITRA University of Washington USA Struggling to curb misinformation social media platforms are experimenting with design interventions to enhance consumption of credible news on their platforms Some of these interventions such as the use of warning messages are examples of nudges choice preserving technique to steer behavior Despite their application we do not know whether nudges could steer people into making conscious news credibility judgments online and if they do under what constraints To answer we combine nudge techniques with heuristic based information processing to design Nudge red browser extension for Twitter Nudge red directs users attention to two design cues authority of source and other users collective opinion on report by activating three design nudges Reliable Questionable and Unreliable each denoting particular levels of credibility for news tweets In controlled experiment we found that Nudge red significantly helped users distinguish news tweets credibility unrestricted by three behavioral confounds political ideology political cynicism and media skepticism five day field deployment with twelve participants revealed that Nudge red improved their recognition of news items and attention towards all of our nudges particularly towards Questionable Among other considerations participants proposed that designers should incorporate heuristics that users would trust Our work in forms nudge based system design approaches for online media CCS Concepts Human centered computing User centered design Keywords Nudging Geometry of Linear Convolutional Networks Kat hlen Koh Thomas Mer kh Guido Mont far Matthew Tr ager August Abstract We study the family of functions that are represented by linear convolutional neural net work LC These functions form semi algebraic subset of the set of linear maps from input space to output space In contrast the families of functions represented by fully connected linear networks form algebraic sets We observe that the functions represented by CNs can be den tied with polynomials that admit certain factorization and we use this perspective to describe the impact of the networks architecture on the geometry of the resulting function space We further study the optimization of an objective function over an LC analyzing critical points in function space and in parameter space and describing dynamical in variants for gradient descent Overall our theory predicts that the optimized parameters of an LC will often correspond to repeated lter across layers or lter that can be de composed as repeated lter We also conduct numerical and symbolic experiments that illustrate our results and present an in depth analysis of the landscape for small architectures Key words Function space description of neural networks linear network To ep litz matrix irc ulan matrix algebraic statistics Euclidean distance degree semi algebraic set gradient ow discriminant critical point tensor AMS subject classic at ions

The energetics of quantum vacuum friction Field uc tu at ions in Guo ID Kimball Milton ID Gerard Kennedy ID William McNulty ID Nim Pour to la mi ID and Yang Li ID Dodge Department of Physics and Astronomy University of Oklahoma Norman OK USA School of Mathematical Sciences University of Southampton Southampton SO BJ United Kingdom National Bank of Canada Montreal QC Canada Department of Physics Nanchang University Nanchang China Dated August Quantum uc tu at ions can induce friction on neutral but polar iz able particle and cause it to radiate energy even if the particle is moving in free space led with black body radiation and is not in contact with or close to any surface or other object We explore the energetics of such particle moving uniformly in vacuum continuing our previous investigations of quantum friction The intrinsic polar iz ability of the particle is considered to be purely real before it is dressed by radiation The particle is then guaranteed to be in the non equilibrium steady state NESS where it absorbs and emits energy at the same rate We rst calculate the quantum frictional power and force on the particle in the rest frame of the black body radiation from rst principles namely the Maxwell Heaviside equations and the Lorentz force law Then we provide simpler method of obtaining the same quantities in the rest frame of the particle by using the principle of virtual work The equivalence of the two approaches is illustrated The formulas we derive for quantum vacuum frictional power and force are fully relativistic and applicable to nite temperature In NESS the quantum vacuum frictional force on the particle is shown to be true drag independent of the model for polar iz ability and the polarization state of the particle Finally we give an estimate of the quantum vacuum friction on gold atom and comment on the feasibility of detecting such quantum vacuum frictional eec ts
