Domain Adaptor Networks for Hyper spectral Image Recognition Gustavo Perez and Sub hr ansu Maj Linear projection Linear Pre trained adaptor CNN Abstract We consider the problem of adapting network Single view prediction Linear adaptor with trained on three channel color images to hyper spectral domain Hyper spectral image pre trained network Predictions with large number of channels To this end we propose Pre trained woit mh in nae td wa opr to kr trna it we odr kos ntl ha arg tem caplet ceo lion pui mt at go eb de act osme tps as tiu bc he CNN Subset selection as Image Net Adaptors enable learning on small hyper spectral Pre trained datasets where training network from scratch may not be effective We investigate architectures and strategies for training Hyper spectral Pre trained CNN adaptors and evaluate them on benchmark consisting of image Adaptor network Predictions multiple hyper spectral datasets We nd that simple schemes Multi view prediction Random Pre trained such as linear projection or subset selection are often the most Hyper spectral image subset network Predictions effective but can lead to loss in performance in some cases Pre trained We also propose novel multi view adaptor where of the inputs CNN View Multi layer network are combined in an intermediate layer of the network in an pooling order invariant manner that provides further improvements We Pre trained Pre trained Multi layer Pre trained present extensive experiments by varying the number of training CNN CNN CNN CNN examples in the benchmark to characterize the accuracy and computational trade offs offered by these adaptors Learn able multi layer adaptor Index Terms convolutional neural networks domain adapt Hyper spectral image With pre trained network Predictions tion transfer learning hyper spectral images Pre trained Hyper spectral CNN Inflated network

Highly super linear photo galvanic eec ts in Bi Sb Te Se Probing topological insulator surface states at room temperature Danilo Go lub Mayer Beer Binder nch Minar Kr on seder Back Bou gear and Ga niche Terahertz Center University of Regensburg Regensburg Germany Ioe Institute St Petersburg Russia New Technologies Research Center University of West Bohemia Plze Czech Republic Technical University Munich Garching Germany and CENTER Institute of High Pressure Physics PAS Warsaw Poland Were port on the observation of complex nonlinear intensity dependence of the circular and linear photo galvanic currents induced by infrared radiation in compensated Bi Sb Te Se topological insulators The photo currents are induced by direct optical transitions between topo logical surface and bulk states We show that an increase of the radiation intensity results rst in highly super linear raise of the amplitude of both types of photo currents whereas at higher intensities the photo current saturates Our analysis of the observed nonlinear ties shows that the super linear behavior of the photo currents is caused by heating of the electron gas while the saturation is induced by slow relaxation of the photo excited carriers resulting in absorbance bleaching The observed nonlinear ties give access to the Fermi level position with respect to the Dirac point and the energy relaxation times of Dirac fermions providing an experimental room temperature probe for topological surface states

University of Technology Tehran Iran Abstract Multiplication of polynomials is among key operations in computer algebra which plays important roles in developing techniques for other commonly used polynomial operations such as division evaluation interpolation and factorization In this work we present formulas and techniques for polynomial multiplications expressed in variety of well known polynomial bases without any change of basis In particular we take into consideration degree graded polynomial bases including but at not limited to orthogonal polynomial bases and non degree graded polynomial bases including the Bernstein and Lagrange bases All of the described polynomial multiplication formulas and tech ni ques in this work which are mostly presented in matrix vector forms preserve the basis in which the polynomials are given Furthermore using the results of direct multiplication of polynomials we devise techniques for intra basis polynomial division in the polynomial bases generalization of the well known long division algorithm to any degree graded polynomial basis is also given The proposed framework deals with matrix vector computations which often leads to well structured matrices Finally an application of the presented techniques in constructing the Gale rk in re pre sent ation of polynomial multiplication operators is illustrated for disc ret iz ation of linear elliptic problem with stochastic coe ci ents Keywords Polynomial arithmetic Degree graded non degree graded polynomial bases Polynomial multiplication Stochastic Gale rk in matrices Classic ation of quadratic unitary fusion categories Cain Edie Michell Masaki Izumi and David Penney Appendix by Ryan Johnson Siu Hung Ng David Penney Jolie Ro at Matthew Tits worth and Henry Tucker August Abstract unitary fusion category is called quadratic if it has group of invertible objects and one other orbit of simple objects under the action of this group We give complete classic ation of quadratic unitary fusion categories The main tools for this classic ation are skein theory generalization of Ost rik results on formal co degrees to analyze the induction of the group elements to the center and computation similar to Larson rank nite ness bound for near group pseudo unitary fusion categories This last computation is contained in an appendix coauthored with attendees from the AMS MRC on Mathematics of Quantum Phases of Matter and Quantum Information

Hardware aware Design of Multiplier less Second Order II Filters with Minimum Adders Remi Garcia Anastasia Volkova Martin Kum Alexandre Golds zte jn Jonas Kuh le Abstract In this work we optimal ly solve the problem of multiplier less design of second order In nite Impulse Response lter with minimum number of adders Given frequency spec cation we design as table direct form lter with hardware aware ed point coe fci ents that yielding minimal number of adders when replacing all the multiplications by bit shifts and additions The coe fci ent design quantization and imp le ment ation typically conducted independently are now gathered into one global optimization problem modeled through integer linear programming and efc ent ly solved using generic solvers We guarantee the frequency domain spec cations and stability which together with optimal number of adders will sign cant ly simplify design space exploration for lter designers The optimal lter are implemented within the Flo PoCo IP Fig Transposed Direct Form II for second order II lter core generator and synthesized for Field Programmable Gate Arrays With respect to state of the art three step lter design methods our one step design approach achieves on average amount of different lter coe fci ent sets can realize reduction in number of lookup tables and improvement given frequency spec cation in delay Quantization converts the coe fci ents to xP Index Terms Digital lter II optimal design multiplier less format such that they still respect the given frequency hardware ILP response and they still lead to stable lter Implementation consists in generating using quan

Deep learning enables accurate sound redistribution via non local meta surfaces Hua Ding in sheng Fang Bin Jia Neng yin Wang Qian Cheng and Yong Li Institute of Acoustics School of Physics Science and Engineering Tong ji University Shanghai China Dated August Abstract Conventional acoustic meta surfaces are constructed with gradient ly local phase shift roles provided by subunits The local strategy implies the ignorance of the mutual coupling between subunits which limits the efc ien cy of targeted sound manipulation especially in complex environments By taking into account the non local interaction among subunits non local meta surface offers an opportunity for accurate control of sound propagation but the requirement of the consideration of gathering coupling among all subunits not just the nearest neighbor coupling greatly increases the complexity of the system and therefore hinders the explorations of functionalities of non local meta surfaces In this work empowered by deep learning algorithms the complex gathering coupling can be learned efc ent ly from the preset data set so that the functionalities of non local meta surfaces can be sign cant ly uncovered As an example we demonstrate that non local meta surfaces which can redirect an incident wave into multi channel re ect ions with rbi tr ary energy ratios can be accurately predicted by deep learning algorithms Compared to the theory the relative error of the energy ratios is less than Furthermore experiments witness three channel re ect ion with three types of energy ratios of and proving the validity of the deep learning enabled non local meta surfaces Our work might blaze new trail in the design of acoustic functional devices especially for the cases containing complex wave matter interactions

Multi class classic ation of de phasing channels Adriano Palmier Federico Bianchi Matteo Paris and Claudia Benedetti Skol kov Institute of Science and Technology Moscow Russia Boc con University Milan Italy Quantum Technology Lab Di parti men to di Fi sica Aldo Pont re moli Universit degli Studi di Milano Milano Italy Is it to Nazionale di Fi sica Nuclear Se zi one di Milano Milano Italy Dated August We address the use of neural networks NN in classifying the environmental parameters of single qu bit de phasing channels In particular we investigate the performance of linear perce ptr on and of two non linear NN architectures At variance with time series based approaches our goal is to learn disc ret zed probability distribution over the parameters using tomo graphic data at just two random instants of time We consider de phasing channels originating either from classical noise or from the interaction with bath of quantum oscillators The parameters to be class ed are the color of the classical noise or the Ohm city parameters of the quantum environment In both cases we found that NN are able to exactly classify parameters into classes using noiseless data linear NN is enough for the color whereas single layer NN is needed for the Ohm city In the presence of noisy data coming from noisy tomo graphic measurements the network is able to classify the color of the noise into classes with about accuracy whereas classic ation of Ohm city turns out to be challenging We also consider more coarse grained task and train the network to discriminate between two macro classes corresponding to and obtaining up to and accuracy using single layer NN

Non Prehensile Manipulation of Cuboid Objects Using Cate nary Robot Gustavo Cardona Diego Antonio Cristian Ioan Vasil and David Salda na Abstract Transporting objects using quad rotors with cables has been widely studied in the literature However most of those approaches assume that the cables are previously attached to the load by human intervention In tasks where multiple objects need to be moved the efc ien cy of the robotic system is constrained by the requirement of manual labor Our approach uses an on stretch able cable connected to two quad rotors which we call the cate nary robot that fully automates the transport tion task Using the cable we can roll and drag the cuboid object box on planar surfaces Depending on the surface type we choose the proper action dragging for low friction and rolling for high friction Therefore the transportation process does not require any human intervention as we use the cable to interact with the box without requiring fastening We validate our control design in simulation and with actual robots where Fig cate nary robot rolling and dragging box we show them rolling and dragging boxes to track desired Video https you tu be Ou Pl XP trajectories

BIASED MULTI LINEAR MAPS OF ABELIAN GROUPS SEAN EBERHARD Abstract We adapt the theory of partition rank and analytic rank to the category of abelian groups If Ak are nite abelian groups and Ak is multi linear map where the bias of is de ned to be the average value of exp If the bias of is bounded away from zero we show that is the sum of bounded ly many multi linear maps each of which factors through the standard multiplication map of for some bounded prime power Related ly if Ak is multi linear map such that is bounded away from zero we show that is the sum of bounded ly many multi linear functions of particular form These structure theorems generalize work of several authors in the elementary abelian case to the arbitrary abelian case The set of all possible biases is also investigated Contents

ITERATING THE BIG PIECES OPERATOR AND LARGER SETS JARED KR AND ELAND RA AN AN CHUL ABSTRACT We show that if an Ahl for David regular set of dimension has Big Pieces of Big Pieces of Lipschitz Graphs denoted usually by BP BP LG then where is Ahl for David regular of dimension and has Big Pieces of Lipschitz Graphs denoted usually by BP LG Our results are quantitative and in fact are proven for any family of Ahl for David regular sets replacing LG and in the setting of metric space simple corollary is that stability of the operator BP after iterations This was previously only known in the Euclidean setting for the case Lipschitz graphs and with substantially more complicated proofs

Published as workshop paper at ICL SimD Workshop EFFICIENT DATA SELECTION METHODS FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF MACHINE LEARNED POTENTIALS Jan Fink be in er Samuel To vey Christian Holm Institute for Computational Physics University of Stuttgart All and ring Stuttgart DE jn kbe in er stove holm icp uni stuttgart de ABSTRACT We present an investigation into data selection methods for the efc ent sampling of cong ration space as applied to the development of inter atomic potentials for scale bridging in molecular dynamics MD simulations This investigation suggests that the most efc ent sampling techniques are those that incorporate information on an atomic level such as forces or atomic energies Finally we generate an inter atomic potential for the sodium chloride system using each data selection technique and nd that the global selection methods result in non physical simulations

NUMERICAL SOLUTION OF STIFF ORDINARY DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS WITH RANDOM PROJECTION NEURAL NETWORKS PRE PRINT Ev angelos Gal aris Di parti men to di Mate mati cae App lica zion iRena to Cac cio poli daniela di serafin un in it Constantin osSie to Di parti men to di Mate mati cae App lica zion iRena to Cac cio poli Universit degli Studi di Napoli Federico II Napoli Italy constantin os iet to un in it August ABSTRACT We propose numerical scheme based on Random Projection Neural Networks RP NN for the solution of Ordinary Differential Equations ODEs with focus on stiff problems In particular we use an Extreme Learning Machine single hidden layer Feed forward Neural Network with Radial Basis Functions which widths are uniformly distributed random variables while the values of the weights between the input and the hidden layer are set equal to one The numerical solution is obtained by constructing system of nonlinear algebraic equations which is solved with respect to the output weights using the Gauss Newton method For our illustrations we apply the proposed machine learning approach to solve two benchmark stiff problems namely the Robe and the van der Pol ones the latter with large values of the stiffness parameter and we perform comparison with well established methods such as the adaptive Run ge Kut ta method based on the Dorm and Prince pair and variable step variable order multi step solver based on numerical differentiation formulas as implemented in the ode and ode MAT LAB functions respectively We show that our proposed scheme yields good numerical approximation accuracy without being affected by the stiffness thus outperforming in same cases the ode and ode functions Importantly upon Corresponding author

JOURNAL OF LATEX CLASS FILES VOL XX NO MONTH XXXX An Empirical Study on the Usage of Transformer Models for Code Completion Matteo in sell Nathan Cooper Luca Pas carell Antonio astro paolo mad Agha jani Denys Pos hyv any Massimiliano Di Penta and Gabriele Bav ota Abstract Code completion aims at speeding up code writing by predicting the next code token the developer is likely to write Works in this el focused on improving the accuracy of the generated predictions with substantial leaps forward made possible by deep learning DL models However code completion techniques are mostly evaluated in the scenario of predicting the next token to type with few exceptions pushing the boundaries to the prediction of an entire code statement Thus little is known about the performance of state of the art code completion approaches in more challenging scenarios in which for example an entire code block must be generated We present large scale study exploring the capabilities of state of the art Transformer based models in supporting code completion at different granularity levels including single tokens one or multiple entire statements up to entire code blocks the iterated block of for loop We experimented with several variants of two recently proposed Transformer based models namely RoBERTa and the Text To Text Transfer Transformer for the task of code completion The achieved results show that Transformer based models and in particular the represent viable solution for code completion with perfect predictions ranging from obtained when asking the model to guess entire blocks up to reached in the simpler scenario of few tokens masked from the same code statement Index Terms Code Completion Deep Learning Empirical Software Engineering cid

ON TYPE II DE GENERATIONS OF HYPER HLER MANIFOLDS HUY BRECHT MAUR Abstract We give simple argument to proveN aga is conjecture for type II de generations of compact hyper hler manifolds and cohomology classes of middle degree Under an additional assumption the techniques yield the conjecture in arbitrary degree This would complete the proof of Naga is conjecture in general as it was proved already for type de generations by Koll Laz acc and Voisin KL SV and independently by Sold aten kov Sol while it is immediate for type III de generations Our arguments are close in spirit to recent paper by Harder Ha proving similar results for the restrictive class of good de generations

Ex BERT An External Knowledge Enhanced BERT for Natural Language Inference Amit Gaj hi ye our Al Mou bayed and Steven Bradley University of She el She el UK gaj hi ye sheffield ac uk University of Durham Durham UK our al mou bayed bradley durham ac uk Abstract Neural language representation models such as BERT pre trained on large scale unstructured corpora lack explicit grounding to real world commonsense knowledge and are often unable to remember facts required for reasoning and inference Natural Language Inference LI is challenging reasoning task that relies on common human un der standing of language and real world commonsense knowledge We introduce new model for LI called External Knowledge Enhanced BERT Ex BERT to enrich the contextual representation with real world commonsense knowledge from external knowledge sources and en han eBERT language understanding and reasoning capabilities Ex BERT takes full advantage of contextual word representations obtained from BERT and employs them to retrieve relevant external knowledge from knowledge graphs and to encode the retrieved external knowledge Our model adaptively incorporates the external knowledge context required for reasoning over the inputs Extensive experiments on the challenging Sci Tail and SNL benchmarks demonstrate the eec ti ve ness of Ex BERT in comparison to the previous state of the art we obtain an accuracy of on Sci Tail and on SNL Keywords Natural Language Inference Contextual Representations

Temperature Steerable Flows and Bolt mann Generators Manuel Di bak and Leon Klein Freie Universit Berlin Department of Mathematics and Computer Science Arni mallee Berlin Germany Frank No Freie Universit Berlin Department of Mathematics and Computer Science Arni mallee Berlin Germany and Rice University Department of Chemistry Houston TX United States Bolt mann generators approach the sampling problem in many body physics by combining normalizing ow and statistical re weighting method to generate samples of physical systems equilibrium density The equilibrium distribution is usually de ned by an energy function and thermodynamic state Here we propose temperature steerable ow SF which are able to generate family of probability densities para met rize by choo sable temperature parameter TS Fs can be embedded in generalized ensemble sampling frameworks to sample physical system across thermodynamic states

Chapter The Application of Artificial Intelligence in Software Engineering Review Challenging Conventional Wisdom Fer as Bat arse Ra sika Mo hod College of Science College of Engineering George Mason University George Mason University Fairfax VA USA Fairfax VA USA Abhi nav Kumar Just in Bu College of Engineering Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences George Mason University University of California Berkeley Fairfax VA USA Berkeley CA USA The less there is to justify traditional custom the harder it is to get rid of it Mark Twain Abstract the field of Artificial Intelligence is witnessing recent upsurge in research tools development and deployment of applications Multiple software companies are shifting their focus to developing intelligent systems and many others are deploying paradigms to their existing processes In parallel the academic research community is injecting paradigms to provide solutions to traditional engineering problems Similarly has evidently been proved useful to Software Engineering SE When one observes the SE phases Requirements Design Development Testing Release and Maintenance it becomes clear that multiple paradigms such as Neural Networks Machine Learning Knowledge Based Systems Natural Language Processing could be applied to improve the process and eliminate many of the major challenges that the SE field has been facing This survey chapter is review of the most commonplace methods of applied to SE The review covers methods between years for the requirements phase major driven methods are found for design for development for testing for release and maintenance Furthermore the purpose of this chapter is three fold firstly to answer the following questions is there sufficient intelligence in the SE lifecycle What does applying to SE entail Secondly to measure for muli ze and evaluate the overlap of SE phases and disciplines Lastly this chapter aims to provide serious questions to challenging the current conventional wisdom status quo of the state of the art craft call for action and to re define the path forward Keywords Lifecycle Phase Artificial Intelligence Paradigms Requirements Testing Design Page of

Chapter The History and Future Prospects of Open Data and Open Source Software Fer as Bat arse Abhi nav Kumar Sam Eisenberg To the past or to the future to an age where thought is free from the age of big brother from the age of the thought police from dead man Greetings by George Orwell Abstract Open data for all New Yorkers that is the tagline on New York City open data website Open government is being promoted at most countries of the western world Governments transparency levels are being measured by the amount of data they share through their online public repositories Additionally open source software is promoted at governments academia and the industry this is the new digital story of this century and the new testament between the Gods of technology and there users data and software openness will redefine the path forward and aim to rekindle our collective intelligence Data and Software Openness can re define Data Democracy and be the catalyst for its progress This chapter provides historical insight into data and software openness the beginnings the heroes prospects for the future and all things we cannot afford to negotiate or lose Keywords Open Data Open Source Software Copyleft Hacking

Predicting Calibration Parameter Values for Constitutive Models using Genetic Programming Gabriel Kr on berger Evgeni ya Kab liman Johannes Kr on steiner Michael Kommen daa Josef Re ssel Center for Symbolic Regression University of Applied Sciences Upper Austria Software park Hagen berg Austria Technical University of Munich Department of Mechanical Engineering cL KR Light Metals Technologies Austrian Institute of Technology Ran sh of en Austria Abstract In material science models are derived to describe emergent properties elasticity strength conductivity and their relations to the material and pro ces sing conditions Constitutive models describe the behaviour of materials for instance deformation processes through applied forces We describe two meth od for the extension of constitutive models using genetic programming GP and demonstrate their application for model which is used in computational mechanics to describe the material response to thermo mechanical loading con ditions The model operates with internal material variables such as dislocation density and contains number of parameters among them three calibration parameters Currently these must be to measured data since the relations to the processing conditions deformation temperature strain rate are not fully understood Our proposed GP based methods identify these relations and generate accurate and short expressions which can be plugged into the const tut ive model instead of the calibration parameters With the expressions found by GP it is possible to interpolate which can potentially reduce the number of experiments and measurements Additionally it opens the possibility for extrapolation Keywords Symbolic Regression Genetic Programming Material Modelling Flow Stress MSC Email address gabriel kr on berger fh hagen berg at Gabriel Kr on berger Pre print submitted to Journal of Advances in Engineering Software August

Who is Better at Anticipating Tra Crashes Human or Art ici al Intelligence Gaze Data based Exploratory Study Yu Li Ph Student Department of Civil Engineering Stony Brook University Stony Brook NY USA Email yu li stony brook edu Muhammad Mon juru Karim Ph Student Department of Civil Engineering Stony Brook University Stony Brook NY USA Email muhammad mon jur karim stony brook edu OR CID Ru wen Qin Associate Professor Department of Civil Engineering Stony Brook University Stony Brook NY USA Email ru wen qin stony brook edu OR CID August Abstract Enhancing roadway safety is priority of transportation Hence Art ici al Intelligence powered crash anticipation is receiving growing attention which aims to assist drivers and Automated Dr iv ing Systems DSs in avoiding crashes To gain the trust from ADS users it is essential to benchmark the performance of models against humans This paper establishes gaze data based method with the measures and metrics for evaluating human drivers ability to anticipate crashes laboratory experiment is designed and performed where in screen based eye tracker collects the gaze data of six volunteers when they are watching videos that include both normal and risky driving scenes Statistical analyses at the sign can ce level of experimental data show that on average drivers can anticipate crash up to seconds before it occurs The chance whereby drivers have anticipated crashes before they occur termed humans recall is An model achieving the same recall value can anticipate crashes seconds earlier than drivers on average and the anticipation precision is The study nds that crash involved tra agents in driving scenes can vary drivers instant attention level average attention level and spatial attention distribution This ding supports models that learn dynamic spatial temporal attention mechanism for strengthening their ability to anticipate crashes Results from the comparison suggests be nets of keeping human in the loop including further re ning

Plasm onic crystals with highly ordered lattice geometries using continuous metal films on diatom bio silica as both scaffolds and sources of tune ability William Wardle Johannes Goes sling Martin Garcia Lopez International Iberian Nanotechnology Laboratory Braga Portugal mail william wardle in in martin lopez in in Keywords Plasm onic crystal bio silica diatom biotic material Abstract Diatoms are microscopic algae found in all of Earths water courses They produce fru stu les porous silica exoskeletons grown by precipitation of sil ici acid from water rust ule components known as girdles from some diatom species also feature highly periodic pore arrays with properties on the same scale and quality of ordering as manufactured photon ic crystals Here the girdles of two diatom species with various lattice constants are used as bio silica scaffolds for plasm onic crystals combined with metals chosen for spectral agreement between permittivity and photon ic crystal properties The use of fru stu les as scaffolds for plasm onic application has been tested earlier as nano porous features can enhance scattering and local hotspots useful for sensing application or ERS However both the use of girdles and of continuous metal films are new approaches offering previously unseen plasm onic effects Angular ly resolved dispersions from reflection Fourier spectroscopy are provided for Cos cino discus gran ii girdles forming well ordered square lattices and Cos cino discus wail es ii forming ordered hexagonal lattices covered with nm film of silver or with nm of gold respectively These were confirmed with optical modelling of the systems including both metal surface layers and internal rust ule structures allowing for calculation of dispersions and electric fields Measurements are further compared with structures produced via Focused Ion Beam microscopy demonstrating the advantages of girdles as photon ic crystal scaffold and as

Full text and URL search Miguel Costa Abstract Web archives are historically valuable source of information In some respects web archives are the only record of the evolution of human society in the last two decades They preserve mix of personal and collective memories the importance of which tends to grow as they age However the value of web archives depends on their users being able to search and access the information they require in ec ent and eec ti ve ways Without the possibility of exploring and exploiting the archived contents web archives are useless Web archive access functionalities range from basic browsing to advanced search and analytical services accessed through user friendly interfaces Full text and URL search have become the predominant and preferred forms of information discovery in web archives full ling user needs and supporting search APIs that feed complex applications Both full text and URL search are based on the technology developed for modern web search engines since the Web is the main resource targeted by both systems However while web search engines enable searching over the most recent web snapshot web archives enable searching over multiple snapshots from the past This means that web archives have to deal with temporal dimension that is the cause of new challenges and opportunities discussed throughout this chapter Miguel Costa Vodafone Research mail miguel costa vodafone com

Hybrid bie xc it on in organic polymer aggregates case of Dr Je ky meeting Mr Hyde Eric Bit ner Department of Chemistry University of Houston Houston Texas United States Carlos Silva cuna School of Chemistry and Biochemistry Georgia Institute of Technology Atlantic Drive Atlanta GA United States Dated August Fr enke ex it on are the primary photo excitation in organic semiconductors and are ultimately responsible for the optical properties of such materials They are also predicted to form bound ex ci ton pairs termed bie xc it on which are consequential intermediates in wide range of photo physical processes Generally we think of bound states as arising from an attractive interaction However here were port on our recent theoretical analysis predicting the formation of stable bie xc it on states in conjugated polymer material arising from both attractive and repulsive interactions We show that in aggregate systems JJ bie xc it on can arise from repulsive dipolar interactions with energies while in aggregates HH bie xc it on states corresponding to attractive JJ HH dipole ex it on ex it on interactions These predictions are corroborated by using ultra fast double quantum coherence spectroscopy on PBT TT material that exhibits both and like ex ci tonic behavior

Pion photo production in chiral perturbation theory with explicit treatment of the resonance Rijn eve en Gasparyan Krebs and Ep el baum Ruhr Universitat Bochum Fa kul tat fur Ph sik und As trono mie Institut fur The or et is che Ph sik II Bochum Germany NRC Kurchatov Institute IT EP Che remus hk in kaya Moscow Russia Dated August We study the reaction of pion photo production on the nucleon in the framework of chiral per tur bati on theory with explicit degrees of freedom In the covariant approach we give results up to order cid in the small scale expansion scheme Furthermore we provide less and full results obtained in the heavy baryon scheme to analyze the dieren ces to the covariant approach Low energy constants are ted to multi pole amplitudes using theoretical truncation errors est mated by Bayesian approach We also compare our dings to data of neutral pion production cross sections and polarization symmetries The description of the reaction is clearly improved by the explicit treatment of the resonance PAC numbers Fe Gp Email nora rijn eve en rub de Email shot gasparyan rub de Email hermann krebs rub de Email evgeny ep el baum rub de

Stochastic gene transcription with non competitive transcription regulatory architecture Amit Kumar Das and Rajesh Karma kar August Kh arial High School Kana pur Hooghly India Department of Physics Ramakrishna Mission Vidya mandir Belur Math How rah India Abstract Gene transcription is stochastic process mostly occurring in bursts Regulation of tr an script ion arises from the interaction of transcription factors Fs with the promoter of the gene The Fs such as activators and repressor can interact with the promoter in competitive or non competitive way Some experimental observations suggest that the mean expression and noise strength can be regulated at the transcription level Few theories are developed based on these experimental observations Here we re establish that experimental results with the help of our exact analytical calculations for stochastic model with non competitive transcriptional regulatory architecture and nd out some properties of Noise strength like sub Poisson ian fano factor and mean expression as we found in two state model earlier Along with those aforesaid properties we also observe some anomalous characteristics in noise strength of mRNA and in variance of protein at lower activator concentrations

The Boundary for Quantum Advantage in Gaussian Boson Sampling Jacob Bulmer Bryn Bell Rachel Chadwick Alex Jones Diana oise Alessandro Rig azzi Jan Thorbecke tz Uwe Haus Thomas Van aere nberg Raj Patel Ian alms ley and Anthony Laing Quantum Engineering Technology Labs University of Bristol Bristol UK Ultra fast Quantum Optics group Department of Physics Imperial College London London UK Quantum Engineering Centre for Doctoral Training University of Bristol Bristol UK Hewlett Packard Enterprise Switzerland Hewlett Packard Enterprise the Netherlands HP HPC ME Research Lab Wallis ellen Schweiz Hewlett Packard Labs HP Belgium Die gem Belgium Department of Physics University of Oxford Oxford UK Dated August Identifying the boundary beyond which quantum machines provide computational advantage over their classical counterparts is crucial step in charting their usefulness Gaussian Boson Sampling GB in which photons are measured from highly entangled Gaussian state is leading approach in pursuing quantum advantage State of the art quantum photo nics experiments that once programmed run in minutes would require million years to simulate using the best pre existing classical algorithms Here we present substantially faster classical GB simulation methods including speed and accuracy improvements to the calculation of loop afn ian the matrix function at the heart of GB We test these on core supercomputer to emulate range of die rent GB experiments with up to modes and up to photons This reduces the run time of classically simulating state of the art GB experiments to several months nine orders of magnitude improvement over previous estimates Finally we introduce distribution that is ec ent to sample from classically and that passes variety of GB validation methods providing an important adversary for future experiments to test against

Multi Frequency GP Microwave Imaging of Sparse Targets Through Multi Task Bayesian Compressive Sensing Approach MarcoS lucci and Nicola Anselm CN IT University of Trento ELE DIA Research Unit Via Somma rive Trento Italy Email marco lucci nicola anselm unit it Abstract An innovative inverse scattering IS method is proposed for the quantitative imaging of pixel sparse scatter ers buried within lossy half space On the one hand such an approach leverages on the wide band nature of ground penetrating radar GP data by jointly processing the multi frequency MF spectral components of the collected radar grams On the other hand it enforces sparsity priors on the problem unknowns to yield regularized solutions of the fully non linear scattering equations Towards this end multi task Bayesian Compressive Sensing MT BCS methodology is adopted and suitably customized to take full advantage of the available frequency diversity and of the priori information on the class of imaged targets Representative results are reported to assess the proposed MF MT BCS strategy also in comparison with competitive state of the art alternatives Keywords Inverse Scattering IS Microwave Imaging MI Ground Penetrating Radar GP Multi Frequency MF Multi Task Bayesian Compressive Sensing MT BCS

Game Theoretic Framework for Controlled Is landing in the Presence of Adversaries Lu yao Niu in uk ahab and Andrew Clark and Radha Poo vend ran Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering Worcester Polytechnic Institute Worcester MA USA Network Security Lab Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering University of Washington Seattle WA USA niu clark wp edu sd in uk rp uw edu cid Abstract Controlled is landing eec iv ely mitigates cascading failures by partitioning the power system into set of disjoint islands In this pa per we study the controlled is landing problem of power system under disturbances introduced by malicious adversary We formulate the in ter action between the grid operator and adversary using game theoretic framework The grid operator rst computes controlled is landing strat gy along with the power generation for the post is landing system to guarantee stability The adversary observes the strategies of the grid operator The adversary then ident ies critical substations of the power system to compromise and trips the transmission lines that are connected with compromised substations For our game formulation we propose double oracle algorithm based approach that solves the best response for each player We show that the best responses for the grid operator and adversary can be formulated as mixed integer linear programs In addition the best response of the adversary is equivalent to sub mod lar maximization problem under cardinality constraint which can be approximated up to optimal it bound in polynomial time We compare the proposed approach with baseline where the grid operator computes an is landing strategy by minimizing the power ow is rup tion without considering the possible response from the adversary We evaluate both approaches using IEEE bus bus bus bus bus and bus power system case study data Our proposed approach achieves better performance than the baseline in about of testcases and on average it incurs about MW less power ow disruption

Progressive Transmission using Recurrent Neural Networks Mohammad Sade gh Safari Va hid Pour ahmadi Patrick Mitra and Hamid Sheikh za deh EE Department Amir kabir University of Technology Tehran Iran ECE Department University of Waterloo Waterloo ON Canada Abstract In this paper we investigate new machine learning based transmission strategy called progressive transmission or Prog Tr In Prog Tr there are variables that should be transmitted using at most channel uses The transmitter aims to send the data to the receiver as fast as possible and with as few channel uses as possible as channel conditions permit while the receiver renes its estimate after each channel use We use recurrent neural networks as the building block of both the transmitter and receiver where the SNR is provided as an input that represents the channel conditions To show how Prog Tr works the proposed scheme was simulated in different scenarios including single multi user settings different channel conditions and for both discrete and continuous input data The results show that Prog Tr can achieve better performance compared to conventional modulation methods In addition to performance metrics such as BER bit wise mutual information is used to provide some interpretation to how the transmitter and receiver operate in Prog Tr

The Devil is in the GAN Defending Deep Generative Models Against Backdoor Attacks Ambr ish Rawat Killian Lev cher Mathieu Sinn IBM Research Europe Dublin August Abstract Deep Generative Models GM allow users to synthesize data from complex high dimensional manifolds Industry applications of GM in clude data augmentation to boost performance of semi supervised ma chin learning or to mitigate fairness or privacy concerns Large scale GM are notoriously hard to train requiring expert skills large amounts of data and extensive computational resources Thus it can be expected that many enterprises will resort to sourcing pre trained GM from po tent ally un ve ried third parties open source model repositories As we show in this paper such deployment scenario poses new attack surface which allows adversaries to potentially undermine the in te grit of entire machine learning development pipelines in victim or ga niz ation Spec ic ally we describe novel training time attacks resulting in corrupted GM that synthesize regular data under normal operations and designated target outputs for inputs sampled from trigger dist rib tion Depending on the control that the adversary has over the random number generation this imposes various degrees of risk that harmful data may enter the machine learning development pipelines potentially causing material or reputation al damage to the victim organization Our attacks are based on adversarial loss functions that combine the dual objectives of attack stealth and del it We show its eec ti ve ness for variety of GM architectures Generative Adversarial Networks GANs Variation al Auto encoders AEs and data domains images audio Our experiments show that even for large scale industry grade GM our attack can be mounted with only modest computational or ts We also investigate the eec ti ve ness of die rent defensive ap roaches based on static dynamic model and output inspections and prescribe practical defense strategy that paves the way for safe usage of GM ambr ish rawat ie ibm com killian lev cher ibm com math sinn ie ibm com

Socioeconomic Clustering and Racial Segregation on Lattices with Heterogeneous Sites hanzha Zhao and Dana Randall School of Computer Science Georgia Institute of Technology Abstract The Schelling model of segregation moves colored agents or particles on the vertices of graph typically lattice with unhappy agents trying to move to new positions if the number of their neighbors with die rent color exceeds some threshold well studied stochastic variant of this model assumes that agents are geometrically happier with each additional neighbor of the same color moving with probability proportional to their unhappiness The stochastic version behaves like ed magnetization Ising model so it is known that we will have segregation at equilibrium if the homo phil or preference for the neighbors of the same color is large enough In this work we consider race and socioeconomic status simultaneously to understand how carefully architect ed placement of urban infrastructure that mostly helps low income individuals might ect segregation In our model agents are both two colored and also labeled as rich or poor We designate certain vertices on the graph as urban sites providing civic infrastructure that most be nets the poorer population in centi viz ing occupation of these vertices by poor agents of either color Infrastructure that is centralized like city center or mall encourages poor agents to cluster centrally in addition to their homo phil preferences while infrastructure that is well distributed like large grid of inner citybus routes tends to disperse the low income agents We ask what eec these two scenarios have on segregation We nd that centralized infrastructure simultaneously causes segregation and the urban iz tion of poverty occupation of urban sites primarily by poor agents when the homo phil and incentives drawing the poor to urban sites are large enough However even when homo phil preferences are very small as long as the incentives drawing the poor to urban sites is large under income inequality where one race has sign cant ly higher proportion of the poor we get racial segregation on urban sites but integration on non urban sites However we nd there is an overall mitigation of segregation when the urban sites are distributed throughout the lattice and the incentive drawing the poor on the urban sites exceeds the homo phil preference We prove that in this case no matter how strong homo phil preferences are it will be exponentially unlikely that cong ration chosen from station ari ty will have large homogeneous clusters of similarly colored agents thus promoting integration in the city with high probability hanzha gate ch edu Supported by Georgia Tech ARC TRIAD Fellowship and ARO MURI award NF randall cc gate ch edu Supported by ARO MURI award NF

Image Augmentation using Task Guided Generative Adversarial Network for Age Estimation on Brain MRI Ruiz he Li Matteo Bastian Do ro the Auer Christian Wagner and in Chen IM LUCID Group School of Computer Science University of Nottingham UK School of Medicine University of Nottingham UK Abstract Brain age estimation based on magnetic resonance imaging MRI is an active research area in early diagnosis of some neuro degenerative diseases Alzheimer Parkinson Huntington etc for elderly people or brain under development for the young group Deep learning methods have achieved the state of the art performance in many medical image analysis tasks including brain age estimation However the performance and general is ability of the deep learning model are highly dependent on the quantity and quality of the training data set Both collecting and annotating brain MRI data are extremely time con sum ing In this paper to overcome the data scarcity problem we propose gen erat ive adversarial network GAN based image synthesis method Different from the existing GAN based methods we integrate task guided branch re gres sion model for age estimation to the end of the generator in GAN By adding task guided loss to the conventional GAN loss the learned low dimensional latent space and the synthesised images are more task specific It helps to boost the performance of the down stream task by combining the synthesised images and real images for model training The proposed method was evaluated on public brain MRI data set for age estimation Our proposed method outperformed statistically significant deep convolutional neural network based regression model and the GAN based image synthesis method without the task guided branch More importantly it enables the identification of age related brain re gions in the image space The code is available on it Hub Keywords Generative Adversarial Network Brain Age Regression Data Aug ment ation

in CMB lensing reconstruction if not properly accounted for Combinations of multi frequency data have been used to minimize the overall map variance internal linear combi nation or IL or spec ic ally null given foreground but these are not tailored to CMB lensing In this paper we derive an optimal multi frequency combination to jointly minimize CMB lensing noise and bias We focus on the standard lensing quadratic estimator as well as the shear only and source hardened estimators whose responses to foregrounds die We show that an optimal multi frequency combination is compromise between the IL and joint de projection which nulls the thermal Suny ev el do vich SZ and Cosmic Infrared Background IB contributions In particular for Simons Observatory like experiment with cid wend that role hard magnitude at noise cost relative to the standard quadratic estimator With small amount of joint de projection the bias to the role hardened estimator can be further reduced to less than half the statistical uncertainty on the respective amplitudes at and noise cost for the auto and cross correlation respectively relative to the role hardened estimator with the standard IL weights Finally we explore possible improvements with more aggressive masking and varying cid max

Ph on on spectrum of Pr and Pr Ir as an evidence of coupling of the lattice with electronic and magnetic degrees of freedom Yuan yuan Xu Hui yuan Man Nan Tang Takumi Oh tsuki Sant Bai dy Hong bin Zhang Satoru Naka tsuji David Vanderbilt and Natalia rich ko Institute for Quantum Matter and Department of Physics and Astronomy Johns Hopkins University Baltimore Maryland USA Institute for Solid State Physics University of Tokyo Kashiwa Chiba Japan Department of Physics and Astronomy Rutgers University CREST Japan Science and Technology Agency Kawaguchi Saitama Japan Institute for Quantum Matter and Department of Physics and Astronomy Johns Hopkins University Baltimore MD USA Department of Physics University of Tokyo Bunk yo ku Tokyo Japan Trans scale Quantum Science Institute University of Tokyo Bunk yo ku Tokyo Japan Magnetic materials with pyr och lore crystal structure form exotic magnetic states due to the high lattice frustration In this work we follow the eec ts of coupling of the lattice and electronic and mag ne tic degrees of freedom in two Pra seo dy miu based pyro chlo res Pr and Pr Ir In both materials the presence of magnetic interactions does not lead to magnetically ordered low tempera ture states however their electronic properties are die rent comparison of Raman ph on on spectra of Pr and Pr Ir allows us to identify magneto elastic coupling in Pr that elucidates its magnetic properties at intermediate temperatures and allows us to characterize ph on on electron coupling in the semi metallic Pr Ir We also show that the eec ts of random disorder on the el Raman ph on on spectra is negligible

Yue Shen in Liu Nadia Zak am ska Qian Yang and Jennifer Li Department of Astronomy University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign Urbana IL USA National Center for Super computing Applications University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign Urbana IL USA Center for AstroPhysical Surveys National Center for Super computing Applications Urbana IL USA Department of Physics and Astronomy Johns Hopkins University ABSTRACT Dual supermassive black holes MBH at pc scales are the progenitor population of MBH mergers and play an important role in understanding the pairing and dynamical evolution of massive black holes in galaxy mergers Because of the stringent resolution requirement and the apparent rareness of these small separation pairs there are scarce observational constraints on this population with few con med dual MBH at pc separations at Here we present results from pilot search for pc scale dual quasars selected with Gaia Data release DR astrometry and followed up with Hubble Space Telescope HST Wide Field Camera dual band Wand snapshot imaging Our targets are quasars primarily selected with the var st rome try technique light centro id it ter caused by asynchronous variability from both members in an unresolved quasar pair supplemented by sub arcsec pairs already resolved by Gaia DR Wend an overall high fraction of HST resolved pairs among the var st rome try selected quasars unresolved in Gaia DR increasing toward high redshift at We discuss the nature of the resolved sub arcsec pairs based on HST and supplementary data substantial fraction of these pairs are likely physical quasar pairs or gravitationally lense quasars We also discover triple quasar candidate and quad ru ply lense quasar which is among the smallest separation quadruple lenses These results provide important guidelines to improve var st rome try selection and follow up con rm ation of pc scale dual MBH at high redshift Keywords black hole physics galaxies active quasars general surveys

MN RAS Pre print August Compiled using MN RAS LATEX style lev Indicator Power Spectra Surgical Excision of Non linear ties and Co variance Matrices for Counts in Cells Andrew Rep Istv an zap udi Christian Liberty Academy Milo St Kea au HI USA Institute for Astronomy University of Hawaii Woodlawn Drive Honolulu HI USA August submitted toM NR AS ABSTRACT We here introduce indicator functions which identify regions of given density in order to characterize the density dependence of clustering After general introduction to this tool we show that indicator function power spectra are biased versions of the linear spectrum on large scales We provide calculation from rst principles for this bias we show that it reproduces simulation results and we provide simple functional form for the trans linear portion of the indicator function spectra We also outline two applications rst these spectra facilitate surgical excision of non linearity and thus sign cant ly increase the reach of linear theory Second indicator function spectra permit calculation of theoretical co variance matrices for counts in cells facilitating parameter estimation with complementary IC methods Key words cosmology theory cosmology miscellaneous methods statistical

Extending Precision Perturb at ive QCD with Track Functions Yi bei Li Ian Moult Solange Sch rijn der van Vel zen Wouter Waal ew jn and Hua Xing Zhu Zhejiang Institute of Modern Physics Department of Physics Zhejiang University Hangzhou China Department of Physics Yale University New Haven CT Nik he Theory Group Science Park XG Amsterdam The Netherlands Institute for Theoretical Physics Amsterdam and Delta Institute for Theoretical Physics University of Amsterdam Science Park XH Amsterdam The Netherlands Collider experiments often exploit information about the quantum numbers of nal state hadrons to maximize their sensitivity with applications ranging from the use of tracking information electric charge for precision jet substructure measurements to vor tagging for nucleon structure studies For such measurements perturb at ive calculations in terms of quarks and gluons are in uci ent and non perturb at ive track functions describing the energy fraction of quark or gluon converted into subset of hadrons charged hadrons must be incorporated Unlike fragmentation functions track functions describe correlations between hadrons and therefore satisfy complicated non linear evolution equations whose structure has so far eluded calculation beyond the leading order In this Letter we develop an understanding of track functions and their interplay with energy ow observable beyond the leading order allowing them to be used in state of the art perturb at ive calculations for the rst time We identify shift symmetry in the evolution of their moments that xe their structure and we explicitly compute the evolution of the rst three moments at next to leading order allowing for the description of up to three point energy correlations We then calculate the two point energy corre lat or on charged particles at illustrating explicitly that infrared singularities in perturbation theory are absorbed by moments of the track functions and also highlighting how these moments seamlessly interplay with modern techniques for perturb at ive calculations Our results extend the boundaries of traditional perturb at ive QCD enabling precision perturb at ive predictions for energy ow observable sensitive to the quantum numbers of hadron ic states

Approximate two body generating Hamiltonian for the PH Pfa fan wavefunction Kir yl Pak rou ski Institute for Theoretical Physics ETH Zurich Zurich Switzerland and Department of Physics Princeton University Princeton NJ Dated August We present several two body Hamiltonians that approximate the exact PH Pfa fan wavefunction with their ground states for all the system sizes where this wavefunction has been numerically constructed to date The approximate wavefunctions have high overlap with the original and reproduce well the low lying entanglement spectrum and structure factor The approximate generating Hamiltonians are obtained by an optimisation pro ce dure where three to four pseudo potentials are varied in the neighbourhood of second Landau level Coulomb interaction or of an on interacting model They belong to nite region in the variation al space of Hamiltonians where each point approximately generates the PH Pfa fan We diagonal ize the den tied Hamiltonians for up to electrons and nd that for them the PH Pfa fan shift appears energetically more favourable Possibility to interpret the data in terms of composite fermions is discussed

Constraints on heavy decaying dark matter with current gamma ray measurements Marco Chi an ese Damiano Fiori ll Ras mi Hajj ar Gennaro Mie le and in etta Savi no Di parti men to di Fi sica Ettore Pan in Universit degli studi di Napoli Federico II Comp less Un iv Monte Angelo Napoli Italy IN FN Se zi one di Napoli Comp less Un iv Monte Angelo Napoli Italy Scuola Superiore Meri dion ale Universit degli studi di Napoli Federico II Largo San Marcel lino Napoli Italy Dated August Among the several strategies for indirect searches of dark matter one very promising one is to look for the gamma rays from decaying dark matter Here we use the most up to date upper bounds on the gamma ray ux from to GeV obtained from CASA MIA AS CADE AS CADE Grande Pierre Auger Observatory and Telescope Array We obtain global limits on dark matter lifetime in the range of masses mD GeV We provide the bounds for set of decay channels chosen as representatives The constraints derived here are new and cover region of the parameter space not yet explored We compare our results with the projected constraints from future neutrino telescopes in order to quantify the improvement that will be obtained by the complementary high energy neutrino searches

Information disclosure in the framework of Kolmogorov complexity Nikolay Vere shc hag in Moscow State University and HSE University Russian Federation Abstract We consider the network consisting of three nodes connected by two open channels and The information present in the node consists of four strings The nodes know and need to know respectively We want to arrange transmission of information over the channels so that both nodes and learn what they need and the disclosure of information is as small as possible By information disclosure we mean the amount of information in the strings transmitted through channels about or about We are also interested in whether it is possible to minimize the disclosure of information and simultaneously minimize the length of words transferred through the channels

Exploration of the solar system and beyond using thermonuclear fusion drive Roman Ya eze rash vili Physics Department New York City College of Technology The City University of New York Brooklyn NY USA The Graduate School and University Center The City University of New York New York NY USA rk eze rash vili city tech cuny edu Dated August It is demonstrated that the development of nuclear fusion rocket engine based on He De te rium Helium technology will allow to travel in the solar system and beyond with an ease never before attained and opens new possibilities to humankind The Direct Fusion Drive DFD is the He fueled neutron ic thermonuclear fusion propulsion system that is underdevelopment at Princeton University Plasma Physics Laboratory It is shown that direct nuclear fusion drive is even more important in human planetary exploration and constitutes solution to the problem of exploring the solar system It is considered and analyzed the Earth Mars mission using the DFD It is shown that one way trips to Mars in slightly more than days become possible and also journeys to the asteroid belt will take about days It is presented an analysis of realistic new trajectories for robotic mission to Saturns largest moon Titan to demonstrate the great advantages related to the thermonuclear Direct Fusion Drive The trajectories calculations and analysis for Saturns largest moon Titan dieren tp role missions are given based on the characteristics of MW class DFD engine This capability results in total trip duration of years for the thrust coast thrust role and less than years for the continuous thrust role Using the same MW class DFD engine one can reach some trans Neptunian object such as the dwarf planets Makemake Eris and Haumea in less than years with payload mass of at least kg so that it would enable all kind of missions from sci en tic observation to in situ operations We consider for each mission Thrust Coast Thrust role For this reason each mission is divided into phases the spiral trajectory to escape Earth gravity in en ce ii the interplanetary travel from the exit of Earth sphere of in en ce to the end of the coasting phase iii maneuvers to rendezvous with Titan or the dwarf planet We present calculations to reach vicinity at AU for the study of the Sun magnetosphere Finally we conclude that spacecraft propelled by DFD will open unprecedented possibilities to explore the border of the solar system in limited amount of time and with very high payload to propellant masses ratio Keywords Direct Fusion Drive Exploration of Mars Exploration of Titan Trans Neptunian Objects Ex plo ration Deep Space Exploration

Production of light nuclei in small collision systems with ALICE Chiara Pinto on behalf of the ALICE Collaboration Di parti men tod iF is ica eAst ron omi Majorana Universit degli Studi di Catania Vi aS So Catania Italy IN NSe zion edi Catania Vi aS So Catania Italy Abstract The energy densities reached in high energy hadron ic collisions at the LHC allow sign cant production of light anti nuclei Their production yields have been measured as function of and charged particle multi pli it in die rent collision systems and at die Trent center of mass energies by ALICE One of the most interesting results obtained from such large var ty of experimental data is that the dominant production mechanism of light anti nuclei seems to depend solely on the event charged particle multi pli it Evidence for this comes from the continuous evolution of the deuteron to proton and He to proton ratios with the event multiplicity across die rent collision systems and energies The characterization of the light nuclei pro duc tion mechanism is complemented by measurements of their production yields in jets and in the underlying event In this paper recent results on light nuclei production in small collision systems are shown and discussed in the context of the statistical hadron iz ation and coalescence models In addition recent results on the deuteron production in jets and new preliminary results on its production in the underlying event measured in pp collisions at TeV are discussed Physics motivation The production mechanism of light anti nuclei is under intense debate in the heavy ion physics community Currently the measured production yields can be described by two classes of models the thermal statistical models and the coalescence ones In the Statistical Hadron iz ation Model HM hadrons are produced by thermally and chemically quil rated source and their abundances are ed at the chemical freeze out This model provides good description of the measured hadron yields in central collisions However the mechanism of hadron production and the propagation of loosely bound states through the hadron gas phase are not addressed by this model On the other hand the production of light anti nuclei can be modelled via the coalescence of protons and neutrons that are close by in phase space at the kinetic freeze out and match the spin thus forming nucleus The key parameter of the coalescence models is the coalescence parameter which is related to the production probability of the nucleus via this process and can be calculated from the overlap of the nucleus wavefunction and the phase space distribution of the constituents via the Wigner formalism mail chiara pinto cern ch

Laboratory of Quark and Lepton Physics MOE and Institute of Particle Physics Central China Normal University Wuhan China Department of Physics Brookhaven National Laboratory Upton NY Mark Baker Physics and Detector Simulations LLC Miller Place NY Center for Frontiers in Nuclear Science Stony Brook NY School of Mathematics and Physics China University of Geosciences Wuhan China Dated August Understanding various fundamental properties of nucleons and nuclei are among the most important sci en tic goals at the upcoming Electron Ion Collider EI With the unprecedented opportunity provided by the next generation machine the EI might provide den it ive answers to many standing puzzles and open questions in modern nuclear physics Here we investigate one of the golden measurements proposed at the EI which is to obtain the spatial gluon density distribution within lead Pb nucleus The proposed experimental process is the exclusive vector meson production the Pb nucleus Pbe cid Pb cid The Fourier transformation of the momentum transfer distribution of the coherent dir action is the transverse gluon spatial distribution In order to measure it the experiment has to overcome an overwhelmingly large background arising from the incoherent dir active production where the nucleus Pb cid mostly breaks up into fragments of particles in the far forward direction close to the hadron going beam rapidity In this paper we systematically study the rejection of incoherent production by vetoing products from these nuclear breakups protons neutrons and photons which is based on the BeAGLE event generator and the most up to date EI Far forward Interaction Region design The achieved vetoing ec ien cy the ratio between the number of vetoed events and total incoherent events ranges from about depending on which can resolve at least the rst minimum of the coherent dir active distribution based on the Sartre model Experimental and accelerator machine challenges as well as potential improvements are discussed Keywords EI BeAGLE coherent dir action incoherent dir action nuclear breakups

Parallel in time pre conditioners for the inc Nys trm method Jun Liu Shu Lin Wu Department of Mathematics and Statistics Southern Illinois University Edwardsville Edwardsville IL USA School of Mathematics and Statistics Northeast Normal University Changchun China Abstract The inc Nys trm method in time is high order spectral method for solving evolutionary differential equations and it has wide applications in sci en tic computation But in this method we have to solve all the time steps implicitly at one shot which may results in large scale non symmetric dense system that is expensive to solve In this paper we propose and analyze parallel in time PinT pre conditioner for solving such inc Nys trm systems where both the parabolic and hyperbolic DEs are investigated Attributed to the special To ep litz like structure of the inc Nys trm systems the proposed PinT pre conditioner is indeed low rank perturbation of the system matrix and we show that the spectrum of the preconditioned system is highly clustered around one especially when the time step size is re ned Such clustered spectrum distribution matches very well with the numerically observed mesh independent GMR ES convergence rates in various examples Several linear and nonlinear ODE and DE examples are presented to illustrate the convergence performance of our proposed PinT pre conditioners where the achieved exponential order of accuracy are especially attractive to those applications in need of high accuracy Keywords inc Nys trm method Parallel in time pre conditioner To ep litz matrix skew symmetric matrix Krone cker product approximation GMR ES diagonal iz ation

Two electrons in harmonic conn ment coupled to light in cavity Chen hang Huang Alexander Ah rens Matthew Be tel and Kal man Varga Department of Physics and Astronomy Vanderbilt University Nashville Tennessee USA The energy and wave function of harmonically conned two electron system coupled to light is calculated by separating the wave functions of the relative and center of mass CM motions The relative motion wave function has known quasi analytical solution The light only couples to the CM variable and the coupled equation can be solved with diagonal iz ation without approximations The approach works for any coupling strength Examples of wave functions of light matter hybrid states are presented

In homogenous Regular iz ation with Limited and Indirect Data Ji hun Han and Yoon sang Lee Department of Mathematics Dartmouth College Abstract For an ill posed inverse problem particularly with incomplete and limited measurement data regular iz ation is an essential tool for stabilizing the inverse problem Among various forms of regular iz ation the cid penalty term provides suite of regular iz ation of various characteristics depending on the value of When there are no explicit features to determine spatially varying in homogeneous can be incorporated to apply die rent regular iz ation characteristics that change over the domain This approach has been investigated and used for de noising problems where the rst or the second derivatives of the true signal provide information to design the spatially varying exponent distribution This study proposes strategy to design the exponent distribution when the rst and second derivatives of the true signal are not available such as in the case of indirect and limited measurement data The proposed method extracts statistical and patch wise information using multiple reconstructions from single measurement which assists in classifying each patch to pre de ned features with corresponding values We validate the robustness and eec ti ve ness of the proposed approach through suite of numerical tests in and including sea ice image recovery from partial Fourier measurement data Numerical tests show that the exponent distribution is insensitive to the choice of multiple reconstructions AMS subject classic at ions

Division Los Alamos National Laboratory Los Alamos NM USA Department of Physics and Astronomy MS Rice University Main St Houston TX USA mail wadia singh gmail com Pulsar winds interacting with sources of external pressure are well established as ec ent and pro li TeV accelerators in our Galaxy Yet enabled by observations from Fermi LAT growing class of non ac cretin pulsars in binaries has emerged and these are likely to become apparent as TeV emitters in the CTA era This class consists of the black widows and red backs binaries in which millisecond pulsar interacts with its low mass companion In such systems an intra binary shock can form as site of particle acceleration and associated non thermal emission We motivate why these sources are particularly interesting for understanding pulsar winds We also describe our new multi zone code which models the ray and gamma ray synchrotron and inverse Compton spectral components for select spider binaries including diu sion convection and radiative energy losses in an axial ly symmetric steady state approach This new multi zone code simultaneously yields energy dependent lightcurves and orbital phase resolved spectra It also better constrains the multiplicity of electron positron pairs that have been accelerated up to TeV energies and are necessary to power orbit ally modulated synchrotron emission components between the rays and MeV GeV bands potentially observed in some systems This or ds more robust prediction of the expected high energy and HE gamma ray ux Nearby MSPs with hoto raring companions maybe promising targets for CTA and it is possible that spider binaries could contribute to the observe dAMS energetic positron excess th International Cosmic Ray Conference ICRC July Berlin Germany Online Presenter Energy spectrum and structure of one dimensional few electron Wigner crystals with and without coupling to light in cavity Chen hang Huang Daniel Pit agora Timothy Zak lama and Kal man Varga Department of Physics and Astronomy Vanderbilt University Nashville Tennessee USA Explicitly Correlated Gaussian basis is used to calculate the energies and wave functions of one dimensional few electron systems in conn ment potentials created by external potentials or coupling to light in cavity The appearance and properties of Wigner crystal like structures are discussed It is shown that one dimensional Wigner crystals can be formed by coupling electrons to light due to the dipole self interaction term in the light matter Hamiltonian provided an additional extremely weak conning potential is present

Spacetime is material Luciano Combi Abstract Space and time are central concepts for understanding our World They are imp or tant ingredients at the core of every sci en tic theory and subject of intense debate in philosophy Albert Einsteins Special and General theories of Relativity showed that space and time blend in single entity called spacetime Even after century of its hi conception many questions about the nature of spacetime remain controversial In this chapter we analyze the ontological status of spacetime from realistic and ma teri ali stic point of view West art by outlining the well known controversy between subst anti valis and relational is and the evolution of the debate with the appearance of General Relativity We analyze how to interpret spacetime as physical system and how to model its properties in background free theory where spacetime itself is dynamical We discuss the concept of change energy and the ontology of spacetime events In the last section were view the mere ology of spacetime and its relevance in cosmology

of rest frame UV emission line sources at intermediate redshift for calibrating and exploring the connection between secondary UV lines and the emitting galaxies physical properties and their Ly emission The sample of emission line sources with was collected from integral el data from theM USE Wide and MUSE Deep surveys taken as part of Guaranteed Time Observations The objects were selected through un targeted source detection no pre selection of sources as in dedicated spectroscopic campaigns in the three dimensional MUSE data cubes We searched optimal ly extracted one dimensional which is in agreement with previous results from the literature The electron density measured from iiii iiii and iii iii line ux ratios is generally cm and the gas phase abundance is below solar at log Lastly we used Photo Ionization Model Probability Density Functions to infer physical parameters of the full sample and individual systems based on photo ionization model parameter grids and observational constraints from our UV emission line searches This reveals that the UV line emitters generally have ionization parameter log and metal mass fractions that scatter around that is Value Avoiding the Great Filter Projected Timeframe for Human Expansion Off World Jonathan Jiang Philip Rosen Kristen Fah Jet Propulsion Laboratory California Institute of Technology Pasadena CA USA Energy Industry Engineer Retired Vancouver WA USA Keywords Great Filter Computing Power Deep Space Missions Human Landings Colonization Humanity Survival Corresponding to Jonathan Jiang jpl nasa gov Abstract foundational model has been developed based on trends built from empirical data of space exploration and computing power through the first six plus decades of the Space Age which projects earliest possible launch dates for human crewed missions from is lunar space to selected Solar System and interstellar destinations The model uses computational power expressed as transistors per microprocessor as key broadly limiting factor for deep space missions reach and complexity The goal of this analysis is to provide projected timeframe for humanity to become multi world species through off world colonization and in so doing all but guarantees the long term survival of the human race from natural and human caused calamities that could befall life on Earth Be ginning with the development and deployment of the first nuclear weapons near the end of World War II humanity entered Window of Peril which will not be safely closed until robust off world colonies become reality Our findings suggest the first human crewed missions to land on Mars selected Asteroid Belt objects and selected moons of Jupiter and Saturn can occur before the end of the st century Launches of human crewed interstellar missions to exoplanet destinations within roughly lightyears of the Solar System are seen as possible during the rd century and launch of intra galactic missions by the end of the th century An aggressive and sustained space exploration program which includes colonization is thus seen as critical to the long term survival of the human race

montpellier fr var dan bagh many an if edu pl giada peron mp hd mpg de Cosmic Ray CR interactions with the dense gas inside Giant Molecular Clouds GMC produce neutral pions which in turn decay into gamma rays Thus the gamma ray emission from GMC is direct tracer of the cosmic ray density and the matter density inside the clouds Detection of enhanced TeV emission from GMC an emission sign cant ly larger than what is expected from the average Galactic cosmic rays illuminating the cloud can imply variation in the local cosmic ray density due to for example the presence of recent accelerator in proximity to the cloud Such gamma ray observations can be crucial in probing the cosmic ray distribution across our Galaxy but are complicated to perform with present generation Imaging Atmospheric Cherenkov Telescopes ACTs These studies require dieren tia ting between the strong cosmic ray induced background the large scaled use emission and the emission from the clouds which is di cult to the small el of view of present generation ACTs In this contribution we use data collected over years to search for TeV emission from GMC in the inner molecular gala to centric ringo four Galaxy We implement DF oV likelihood technique and simultaneously model the hadron ic background the galactic di use emission and the emission expected from known HE sources to probe for excess TeV gamma ray
