Deterministic Distributed Algorithms and Lower Bounds in the Hybrid Model Ioann is An agno tides Department of Computer Engineering National Technical University of Athens Greece Them is Gou leak is Max Planck Institute for Informatics Saarbr cken Germany Abstract The HYBRID model was recently introduced by Augustine et al in order to characterize from an algorithmic standpoint the capabilities of networks which combine multiple communication modes Concretely it is assumed that the standard LOCAL model of distributed computing is enhanced with the feature of all to all communication but with very limited bandwidth captured by the node capac it ted clique NCC In this work we provide several new insights on the power of hybrid networks for fundamental problems in distributed algorithms First we present deterministic algorithm which solves any problem on sparse node graph in Oe rounds of HYBRID where the notation Oe suppresses poly logarithmic factors of We combine this primitive with several spars if cation techniques to obtain efficient distributed algorithms for general graphs Most notably for the all pairs shortest paths problem we give deterministic and log log log approximate algorithms for un weighted and weighted graphs respectively with round complexity Oe in HYBRID closely matching the performance of the state of the art randomized algorithm of Kuhn and Schneider Moreover we make connection with the Gh ff ari Hae up ler framework of low congestion shortcuts leading among others to approximate algorithm for Min Cut after poly log rounds with high probability even if we restrict local edges to transfer log bits per round Finally we prove via reduction from the set disjoint ness problem that rounds are required to determine the radius of an un weighted graph as well as approximation for weighted graphs As byproduct we show an round complexity lower bound for computing approximation of the radius in the broadcast variant of the congested clique even for un weighted graphs ACM Subject Classification Theory of computation Distributed algorithms Keywords and phrases Distributed Computing Hybrid Model Sparse Graphs Deterministic Al gor it hms All Pairs Shortest Paths Minimum Cut Radius Acknowledgements We are indebted to Christoph Lenz en for carefully reviewing an earlier draft of our work and proposing several improvements and interesting directions Specifically he suggested de randomizing Proposition via the Garay Kut ten Peleg algorithm while he also pointed out the connection with low congestion shortcuts leading to the results of Section We are also very grateful to the anonymous reviewers at DISC for carefully reviewing this paper and for indicating many corrections and ways to improve the exposition We are particularly thankful to reviewer for providing very detailed arguments which strengthened our results in Section All errors remain our own

nia Szymon Zelewski Keywords ePS spectroscopy electron microscopy FT van der Waals materials layered semiconductors ABSTRACT Lamella structures of transition metal phosphorus trisulfide possess strong intra layer bonding albeit adjacent layers are held by weak van der Waals interactions Those compounds received enormous interest due to their unique combination of optical and long range magnetic properties Among them iron phosphorus trisulfide ePS gathered special attention for being semiconductor with an absorption edge in the near infrared as well as showing an Ising like anti ferro July Pandemic and disability Challenges faced and role of technology Mon nie Par ida Dr Man jira Sinh mp it kg gmail com man jira sinh cet it kg ac in Indian Institute of Technology Kh arag pur India India Abstract The pandemic has affected every facet of human life Apart from individuals psychological and mental health issues the concern regarding mobility access and communication with high risk infection is challenging situation People with disability are more likely vulnerable to infections The new changes in our social lifestyle social distancing limiting touch can profoundly impact the day today life of people with disability In this paper we will briefly discuss the situation faced by individuals with disabilities some known remedies and yet to be identified and curate technological remedies the impact due to transition of special education toward online mode Tips and tricks for better utilization of work from home concept by people with disabilities Accessibility must be universal accommodating all and encouraging in clu siv it As rightly said by Helen Keller The only thing worse than being blind is having sight but no vision subsequently going by the demand of the time we should contribute toward the universal design approach by supporting people with disabilities and commit to the changes required in disability care to reduce the impact of pandemic Keywords Disabilities pandemic corona virus inclusive

Manchester PL United Kingdom et Abstract We introduce novel thick target concept tailored to the extraction of refractory and transition metal radio nuclides of molybdenum technetium ruthenium and tungsten for radioactive ion beam production Despite the more than year old history of thick target IS OL mass separation facilities like ISOLDE the extraction of the most refractory elements as radioactive ion beam has so far not been successful In ordinary thick IS OL targets their radioisotopes produced in the target are stopped within the condensed target material and have to di use through solid material Here we present concept which overcomes limitations associated with this method We exploit the recoil momentum of nuclear reaction products for their release from the so lil target material They are thermal zed in carbon monoxide containing atmosphere in which volatile carbonyl complexes form readily at ambient temperature and pressure This compound serves as volatile carrier for transport to the ion source Excess carbon monoxide is removed by cryogenic gas separation to enable low pressures in the source region in which the species are ionized and hence made available for radioactive ion beam formation The setup is operated in batch mode with the aim to extract isotopes having half lives of at least several seconds We report parameter studies of the key processes of the method which validate this concept and which de ne the parameters for the setup This would allow for the rst time the extraction of radioactive molybdenum tungsten and several other transition metals at thick target IS OL facilities PAC Radioactive Beams

Bayesian optimal designs for choice experiments with mixtures Mario Bec err and Peter Goo Faculty of Bioscience Engineering KU Leuven Leuven Belgium Faculty of Business and Economics Universit it Antwerpen Antwerpen Belgium August Abstract Discrete choice experiments are frequently used to quantify consumer preferences by having respondents choose between die rent alternatives Choice experiments involving mixtures of ingredients have been largely overlooked in the literature even though many products and services can be described as mixtures of ingredients As consequence little research has been done on the optimal design of choice experiments involving mixtures The only existing research has focused on optimal designs which means that an estimation based approach was adopted However in experiments with mixtures it is crucial to obtain models that yield precise predictions for any combination of ingredient proportions This is because the goal of mixture experiments generally is to nd the mixture that optimizes the respondents utility As result the optimal it criterion is more suitable for designing choice experiments with mixtures than the optimal it criterion because the optimal it criterion focuses on getting precise predictions with the estimated statistical model In this paper we study Bayesian optimal designs compare them with their Bayesian optimal counterparts and show that the former designs perform substantially better than the latter in terms of the variance of the predicted utility Keywords Choice experiment optimal it Mixture coordinate exchange algorithm Mixture experiment Multi no mi al log it model chee models

Observatory Fir Street Black RiverPark Observatory South Africa Department of Physics and Astronomy University of the Western Cape Bell ville CapeTown South Africa Version of August ABSTRACT Context The Fermi Large Area Telescope has detected over gamma ray pulsars About one quarter of these are labeled as radio quiet that is they either have radio ux densities Jy at MHz or they are not detected at all in the radio domain In the population of non recycled gamma ray pulsars the fraction of radio quiet pulsars is higher about one half Aims Most radio observations of gamma ray pulsars have been performed at frequencies between MHz and GHz However pulsar radio ux es increase rapidly with decreasing frequency and their radio beams often broaden at low frequencies As cons que ce some of these pulsars might be detectable at low radio frequencies even when no radio ux is detected above MHz Our aim is to test this hypothesis with low frequency radio observations Methods We have observed Fermi discovered gamma ray pulsars with the international LOw Frequency ARray LO FAR station FR in single station mode We used the LO FAR high band antenna HB band MHz with an average observing time of per target Part of the data had to be discarded due to radio frequency interference On average we kept of observation per target after the removal of aec ted datasets resulting in sensitivity for pulse average dux on the order of Jy Results We do not detect radio pulsations from any of the sources and we establish stringent upper limits on their low frequency radio ux es These non detection are compatible with the upper limits derived from radio observations at other frequencies We also determine the pulsars geometry from the gamma ray roles to see for which pulsars the low frequency radio beam is expected to cross Earth Conclusions This set of observations provides the most constraining upper limits on theux density at MHz for radio quiet gamma ray pulsars In spite of the beam widening expected at low radio frequencies most of our non detection can be explained by an unfavorable viewing geometry for the remaining observations especially those of pulsars detected at higher frequencies the non detection is compatible within uci ent sensitivity Keywords tb

Sub nK thermometry of an interacting dimensional homogeneous Bose gas Muhammad Mis keen Khan Mohammad Me hbo udi Hugo Ter cas Maciej Le wenstein and Miguel Angel Garcia March Instituto Superior Tec nico Universidade de Lisboa Portugal IC FO Institut de Ci enc ies Fot on ques The Barcelona Institute of Science and Technology Av Carl Friedrich Gauss Castell de fels Barcelona Spain Instituto de Plasmas Fu sao Nuclear Instituto Superior Tec nico Universidade de Lisboa Portugal Departement de Physique App liq ee Universit de Gen eve CH Gen eve Switzerland CREA Pg Ll us Company Barcelona Spain Instituto Universitario de Mate ma tica Pura pli cad Universitat Polit ec nica de Val en cia Val en cia Spain We propose experimentally feasible means for non destructive thermometry of homogeneous Bose Einstein condensates in die rent spatial dimensions Our impurity based protocol suggests that the fundamental error bound on thermometry at the sub nano Kelvin domain depends highly on the dimension in that the higher the dimension the better the precision Furthermore sub optimal thermometry of the condensates by using measurements that are experimentally fe as ble is explored We spec ic ally focus on measuring position and momentum of the impurity that belong to the family of Gaussian measurements We show that generally experimentally feasible measurements are far from optimal except in where position measurements are indeed opt mal This makes realistic experiments perform very well at few nano Kelvin temperatures for all dimensions and at sub nano Kelvin temperatures in the one dimensional scenario These results take sign cant step towards experimental realisation of probe based quantum thermometry of Bose Einstein condensates as it deals with them in one two and three dimensions and uses feasible measurements applicable in current experimental setups

LOCAL IS ABLE MONAD CARMEN CONSTANTIN NUI OK DIC AIRE AND CHRIS HE NEN Abstract Monad govern computational side eec ts in programming sem an tics They can be combined in bottom up way to handle several instances of such eec ts Indexed monad and graded monad do this in modular way Here instead we equip monad with ne grained structure in top down way using techniques from tensor topology This provides an intrinsic theory of local computational eec ts without needing to knowhow constituent eec ts interact beforehand Spec ic ally any mono dal category decomposes as sheaf of local cate go ries over base space We identify notion of local is able monad which characterises when monad decomposes as sheaf of monad Equivalently local is able monad are formal monad in an appropriate pre sheaf category whose algebras we characterise Three extended examples demonstrate how local is able monad can interpret the base space as locations in computer memory as sites in network of interacting agents acting concurrently and as time in stochastic processes

Bi photon phase space correlations from Gouy phase measurements using double slits de Brito da Paz Araujo and Sampaio CNH Universidade Federal do ABC Santo Andre SP Brazil Institute for Quantum Optics and Quantum Information QO QI Vienna Austrian Academy of Sciences Bolt mann gas se Vienna Austria Vienna Center for Quantum Science and Technology Atom institut TU Wien Vienna Austria Universidade Federal do Piau Depart men to de sica Teresina PI Brazil and Co librI TD Quantum Computing Group Cours de Val my Put eaux France Quantum correlations encoded in photon ic La guerre Gaussian modes were shown to be related to the Gouy phase shifts Ka was et al Ph ys Rev Let allowing for non destructive manipulation of photon ic quantum states In this work we exploit the relation between phase space correlations of bi photons produced by spontaneously parametric down con version PDC as encoded in the logarithmic negativity LN and the Gouy phase as they are dir acted through an asymmetrical double slit setup Using an analytical approach based on double gaussian approximation for type PDC bi photons we show that measurements of Gouy phase dieren ces provide information on their phase space entanglement variation governed by the physical parameters of the experiment and expressed by the LN via co variance matrix elements

CALIBRATING THE NELSON SIEGEL SVENSSON MODEL BY GENETIC ALGORITHM As if Lakh any Andrej Pinta Amber Zhang Markham Ontario Canada Algorithmic Algorithmic As if Lakh any gmail com Toronto Canada Toronto Canada Andy Pinta ssc inc com Amber Zhang ssc inc com August ABSTRACT Accurately ting the term structure of interest rates is critical to central banks and other market participants The Nelson Siegel and Nelson Siegel Svensson models are probably the best known models for this purpose due to their intuitive appeal and simple representation However this sim pli city comes at price The if cult yin calibrating these models is twofold Firstly the objective function being minimized during the calibration procedure is nonlinear and has multiple local op tima Secondly there is strong co dependence among the model parameters As result their estimated values behave erratically overtime To avoid these problems we apply heuristic opt miz ation method spec ic ally the Genetic Algorithm approach and show that it is able to construct reliable interest rate curves and stable model parameters over time regardless of the shape of the curves Keywords Yield Curve Modelling Nelson Siegel Model Svensson Model

Abstract Hypertext transfer protocol HTTP is one of the most widely used protocols on the Internet As consequence most attacks SQL injection XS use HTTP as the transport mechanism Therefore it is crucial to develop an intelligent solution that would allow to effectively detect and lter out anomalies in HTTP tr afc Currently most of the anomaly detection systems are either rule based or trained using manually selected features We propose utilizing modern unsupervised language representation model for embedding HTTP requests and then using it to classify anomalies in the tr afc The solution is motivated by methods used in Natural Language Processing NLP such as Doc Vec which could potentially capture the true understanding of HTTP messages and therefore improve the efc ien cy of Intrusion Detection System In our work we not only aim at generating suitable embedding space but also at the interpret ability of the proposed model We decided to use the current state of the art RoBERTa which as far as we know has never been used in similar problem To verify how the solution would work in real word conditions we train the model using only legitimate tr afc We also try to explain the results based on clusters that occur in the vector zed requests space and simple logistic regression classier We compared our approach with the similar previously proposed methods We evaluate the feasibility of our method on three different datasets SIC SE IC IDS and one that we prepared Pre print Under review

Non convex Factorization and Manifold Formulations are Almost Equivalent in Low rank Matrix Optimization Yue tian Luo Xu dong Li and An ru Zhang August Abstract In this paper we consider the geometric landscape connection of the widely studied mani fold and factorization formulations in low rank positive semi de nite PS and general matrix optimization We establish an equivalence on the set of rst order stationary points FO SP and second order stationary points SO SP between the manifold and the factorization for mu lat ions We further give sandwich inequality on the spectrum of Riemann ian and Euclidean Hessian at FO SP which can be used to transfer more geometric properties from one for mu la tion to another Similarities and dieren ces on the landscape connection under the PS case and the general case are discussed To the best of our knowledge this is the rst geo met ric landscape connection between the manifold and the factorization formulations for handling rank constraints In the general low rank matrix optimization the landscape connection of two factorization formulations un regularized and regularized ones is also provided By applying these geometric landscape connections we are able to solve unanswered questions in literature and establish stronger results in the applications on geometric analysis of phase retrieval well conditioned low rank matrix optimization and the role of regular iz ation in factorization arising from machine learning and signal processing

Long range transport of ex it on in dynamic acoustic lattice Ru ming Peng dina Rip in Yu sen Ye Jia yi Zhu Changmin Wu Seok hyeon Lee Huan Li Takashi Taniguchi Kenji Watanabe Ting Cao Xiao dong Xu Mo Li Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering University of Washington Seattle WA USA Department of Physics University of Washington Seattle WA USA Department of Material Science and Engineering University of Washington Seattle WA USA Research Center for Functional Materials National Institute for Materials Science Tsukuba Japan ABSTRACT Ex it on are elementary optical excitation in semiconductors The ability to manipulate and transport these quasi particles would enable ex ci tonic circuits and devices for quantum photon ic technologies Recently inter layer ex it on in semiconductors have emerged as promising candidate for engineering ex ci tonic devices due to long lifetime large ex it on binding energy and gate tun ability However the charge neutral nature of the ex it on leads to weak response to the in plane electric field and thus inhibits transport beyond the diffusion length Here we demonstrate the directional transport of inter layer ex it on in bilayer Se driven by the dynamic potential lattice induced by surface acoustic waves SAW We show that at the SAW driven ex ci tonic transport is activated above threshold acoustic power and reaches distance at least ten times longer than the diffusion length only limited by the device size Temperature dependent measurement reveals the transition from the diffusion limited regime at low temperature to an acoustic field driven regime at elevated temperature Our work shows that acoustic waves are an effective contact free means to control ex it on dynamics and transport promising for realizing materials based ex ci tonic devices such as ex it on transistors switches and transducers Present Address Zhejiang University China Email moli uw edu

We present two accurate and efc ent algorithms for solving the in compressible ir rotational Euler equations with free surface in two di men ions with background ow over periodic multiply connected id domain that includes stationary obstacles and variable bottom topography One ap roach is formulated in terms of the surface velocity potential while the other evolves the vortex sheet strength Both invertible In the velocity potential formulation invert bil it is achieved after physically motivated nite rank correction The integral equations for the two methods are closely related one being the ad joint of the other after modifying it to evaluate the layer potentials on the opposite side of each interface In addition to background ow both formulations allow This work was supported in part by for Space and Habitability Arizona State University School of Earth and Space Exploration Bateman Physical Sciences Tempe USA Technical University of Denmark Department of Chemical and Biochemical Denmark University of Bern Center for Space and Habitability Switzerland ABSTRACT We present an update of the open source photochemical kinetics code VULCAN Tsai et al https it hub com exo clime VULCAN to include networks and photo chemistry Additional new features are advection transport condensation various boundary conditions and temperature dependent UV cross sections First we validate our photochemical model for hot Jupiter atmospheres by performing an in ter comparison of HD models between Moses et al Ve not et al and VULCAN to diagnose possible sources of discrepancy Second we set up model of Jupiter extending from the deep tro po sphere to upper stratosphere to verify the kinetics for low temperature Our model reproduces hydrocarbons consistent with observations and the condensation scheme successfully predicts the locations of water and am moni ice clouds We show that vertical advection can regulate the local ammonia distribution in the deep atmosphere Third we validate the model for oxidizing atmospheres by simulating Earth and nd agreement with observations Last VULCAN is applied to four representative cases of extrasolar giant planets WASP HD GJ and Eri dani We look into the effects of the ratio and chemistry of titanium vanadium species for WASP we revisit HD for the effects of sulfur and carbon con dens ation the effects of internal heating and vertical mixing are explored for GJ we test updated zz planetary properties for rida nib with condensates Wend sulfur can couple to carbon or nitrogen and impact other species such as hydrogen methane and ammonia The observable features of the synthetic spectra and trends in the photochemical haze precursors are discussed for each case

Composing Recurrent Spiking Neural Networks using Locally Recurrent Motifs and Risk Mitigating Architectural Optimization Wen ruiZ hang Peng Li University of California Santa Barbara University of California Santa Barbara Santa Barbara CA Santa Barbara CA wen ruiz hang ucsb edu lip ucsb edu Abstract In neural circuits recurrent connectivity plays crucial role in network function and stability However existing recurrent spiking neural networks RS NN are often constructed by random connections without optimization While RS NN can produce rich dynamics that are critical for memory formation and learning systemic architectural optimization of RS NN is still an opening challenge We aim to enable systemic design of largeR NN via new scalable RS NN arch tec ture and automated architectural optimization We composeRS NN based on layer architecture called Sparsely Connected Recurrent Motif Layer SC ML that consists of multiple small recurrent motifs wired together by sparse lateral connections The small size of the motifs and sparse inter motif connectivity leads to an RS NN architecture scalable to large network sizes We further propose method called Hybrid Risk Mitigating Architectural Search HR MAS to system tic ally optimize the topology of the proposed recurrent motifs and SC ML layer architecture HR MAS is an alternating two step optimization process by which we mitigate the risk of network instability and performance degradation caused by architectural change by introducing novel biologically inspired self repairing mechanism through intrinsic plasticity The intrinsic plasticity is introduced to the second step of each HR MAS iteration and acts as unsupervised fast self adaption to structural and synaptic weight modi cations introduced by the rst step during the RS NN architectural evolution To the best of the authors knowledge this is the rst work that performs systematic architectural optimization of RS NN Using one speech and three neuro orphic datasets we demonstrate the sign cant per for man ce improvement brought by the proposed automated architecture optimization over existing manually designed RS NN

Santa Cruz CA USA ABSTRACT Massive stars play critical roles for the re ionization of the Universe Individual massive stars at the re ionization epoch are too faint to observe and quantify their contributions to re ionization Some massive stars however explode as super luminous supernovae or pair instability supernovae that are luminous enough to observe even at and allow for the direct characterization of massive star properties at the re ionization epoch In addition hypothetical long sought after pair instability supernovae are expected to be present preferentially at high redshift and their discovery will have tremendous impact on our understanding of massive star evolution and the formation of stellar mass black holes The near infrared Wide Field Instrument on Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope will excel at discovering such rare high redshift supernovae In this work we investigate the best survey st strategy to discover and identify super luminous supernovae and pair instability supernovae at with Roman We show that the combination of the and lter can clearly separate both super luminous supernovae and pair instability supernovae at from nearby supernovae through their colors and magnitudes The limiting magnitudes are required to be mag and mag in the and lter respectively to identify supernovae at If we conduct deg transient survey with these limiting magnitudes for years with cadence of one year we expect to discover pair instability supernovae and super luminous supernovae at depending on the cosmic star formation history The same survey is estimated to discover pair instability supernovae and super luminous supernovae at Such supernova survey requires the total observational time of approximately hours in years The legacy data acquired with the survey will also be bene cia for many die rent science cases including the study of high redshift galaxies Keywords Supernovae Massive stars Re ionization Early universe Time domain astronomy Near infrared astronomy

Online Training of Spiking Recurrent Neural Networks with Phase Change Memory Synapses Yi it Demi rag Charlotte Fr enke The Institute of Neuro informatics The Institute of Neuro informatics University of Zurich ETH Zurich University of Zurich ETH Zurich rich Switzerland rich Switzerland yi it in et hz ch Me lika Pay vand Giacomo In diver The Institute of Neuro informatics The Institute of Neuro informatics University of Zurich ETH Zurich University of Zurich ETH Zurich rich Switzerland rich Switzerland Abstract Spiking Recurrent Neural Networks RN Ns are promising tool for solving wide variety of complex cognitive and motor tasks due to their rich temporal dynamics and sparse processing However training spiking RN son dedicated neuro orphic hardware is still an open challenge This is due mainly to the lack of local hardware friendly learning mechanisms that can solve the temporal credit assignment problem and ensures table network dynamics even when the weight resolution is limited These challenges are further accentuated if one resorts to using me mri st ive devices for in memory computing to resolve the von Neumann bottleneck problem at the expense of substantial increase in variability in both the computation and the working memory of the spiking RN Ns To address these challenges and enable online learning in me mri st ive neuro orphic RN Ns we present simulation framework of differential architecture crossbar arrays based on an accurate and comprehensive Phase Change Memory CM device model We train spiking RN whose weights are emulated in the presented simulation framework using recently proposed prop learning rule Although prop locally approximates the ideal synaptic updates it is if cult to implement the updates on theme mri st ive substrate due to substantial CM non ideal ties We compare several widely adapted weight update schemes that primarily aim to cope with these device non ideal ties and demonstrate that accumulating gradients can enable online and efc ent training of spiking RN son me mri st ive substrates

Prepared for submission to CAP Searching for Galactic component in the Ice Cube track like neutrino events Gregory Vance Kimberly Emi Cecilia Lunar in and Rogie Wind horst School of Earth and Space Exploration Arizona State University Tempe AZ USA National Radio Astronomy Observatory Edgemont Road Charlottesville VA USA Department of Physics Arizona State University Tempe AZ USA mail Gregory Vance as edu ke mig rao edu Cecilia Lunar in as edu wind hors as edu Abstract Searches for spatial associations between high energy neutrinos observed at the Ice Cube Neutrino Observatory and known astronomical objects may hold the key to stab li shing the neutrinos origins and the origins of hadron ic cosmic rays While extragalactic sources like the lazar TX merit sign cant attention Galactic sources may also represent part of the puzzle Here we explore whether open clusters and supernova rem ants in the Milky Way contribute measurably to the Ice Cube track like neutrino events above TeV By searching for positional coincidences with catalogs of known astro nom ical objects we can identify and investigate neutrino events whose origins are potentially Galactic We use Monte Carlo random iz ation together with models of the Galactic plane in order to determine whether these coincidences are more likely to be causal associations or random chance In all analyses presented the number of coincidences detected was found to be consistent with the null hypothesis of chance coincidence Our results imply that the combined contribution of Galactic open clusters and supernova remnants to the track like neutrino events detected at Ice Cube is well under This upper limit is compatible with the results presented in other Galactic neutrino studies Jansky Fellow of the National Radio Astronomy Observatory

Deep Learning Chromatic and Clique Numbers of Graphs Jason Van Hulse and Friedman August Abstract Deep neural networks have been applied to wide range of problems across die rent application domains with great success Recently research into combinatorial optimization problems in particular has generated much interest in the machine learning community In this work we develop deep learning models to predict the chromatic number and maximum clique size of graphs both of which represent classical NP complete combinatorial optimization problems encountered in graph theory The neural networks are trained using the most basic representation of the graph the adj ace cy matrix as opposed to undergoing complex domain spec ic feature engineering The experimental results show that deep neural networks and in particular convolutional neural networks obtain strong performance on this problem

Quasi symmetric Magnetic Fields in Asymmetric Toroidal Domains Naoki Sato Zhi song Qu David feer le and Robert Dewar Graduate School of Frontier Sciences The University of Tokyo Kashiwa Chiba Japan Email sato naoki edu tokyo ac jp Mathematical Sciences Institute The Australian National University Canberra ACT Australia The University of Western Australia Stirling Highway Crawley WA Australia August Abstract We explore the existence of quasi symmetric magnetic lds in asymmetric toroidal domains These vector lds can bei den tied with class of magneto hydro dynamic qui libri in the presence of pressure an iso tro py First using Cle bsch potentials we derive system of two coupled nonlinear rst order partial dieren ti al equations expressing family of quasi symmetric magnetic lds in bounded domains In regions where ux surfaces and surfaces of constant el strength are not tangential this system can be further reduced to single degenerate nonlinear second order partial dieren ti al equation with externally assigned initial data Then we exhibit regular quasi symmetric vector lds which correspond to local solutions of anisotropic magnetohydrodynamics in asymmetric toroidal domains such that tangential boundary conditions are full led on portion of the bounding surface The problems of boundary shape and locality are also discussed We nd that symmetric magnetic lds can be ted into asymmetric domains and that the mathematical di cult encountered in the derivation of global quasi symmetric magnetic lds lies in the topological obstruction toward global extension aec ting local solutions of the governing nonlinear rst order partial dieren ti al equations

Regret theory under fear of the unknown Fang Liu School of Mathematics and Information Science Guangxi University Nanning Guangxi China ARTICLE HISTORY Compiled August ABSTRACT It is common to encounter the situation with uncertainty for decision makers DMs in dealing with complex decision making problem The existing evidence shows that people usually fear the extreme uncertainty named as the unknown This pa per reports the mo died version of the typical regret theory by considering the fear experienced by DMs for the unknown Based on the responses of undergraduate students to the hypothetical choice problems with an unknown outcome some ex peri mental evidences are observed and analyzed The framework of the mo died regret theory is established by considering the eec ts of an unknown outcome fear function is equipped and some implications are proved The behavioral found tion of the mo died regret theory is further developed by modifying the axiomatic properties of the existing one as those based on the utility function and it is recalled as the utility based behavioral foundation for convenience The application to the medical decision making with an unknown risk is studied and the eec ts of the fear function are investigated The observations reveal that the existence of an unknown outcome could enhance impede or reverse the preference relation of people in choice problem which can be predicted by the developed regret theory KEYWORDS Regret theory Fear of the unknown Experimental evidence Fear function Behavioral foundation

Eec ts of non local dispersal strategies and heterogeneous environment on total population Xue li Bai School of Mathematics and Statistics Northwestern Polytechnic al University You yi Road West Be il in Xian China Fang Li School of Mathematics Sun Yat sen University No in gang Xi Road Guangzhou China Abstract In this paper we consider the following single species model with non local is per sal strategy where denotes the non local diu sion operator and investigate how the dispersal rate of the species and the distribution of resources ect the total population First we show that the upper bound for the ratio between total population and total resource is Cd Moreover examples are constructed to indicate that this upper bound is optimal Secondly for type of implied non local diu sion operator we prove that if sup the total population as function of dispersal rate in fm admits exactly one local maximum point in in fm sup These results reveal essential discrepancies between local and non local dispersal strategies Keywords total population non local dispersal heterogeneity MSC The rst author is supported by Shaanxi NSF No RJ MS and the Fundamental Re search Funds for the Central Universities No cx The second author is supported by NSF of China No NSF of Guangdong Province No and the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities Corresponding author mail li fang mail sy su edu cn

Emergent Discrete Communication in Semantic Spaces My cal Tucker Hua oLi SiddharthA rawal Dana Hughes Katia Sy cara Michael Lewis and Julie Shah Massachusetts Institute of Technology University of Pittsburgh Carnegie Mellon University my cal mit edu hul up it edu siddha ra cs cmu edu Abstract Neural agents trained in reinforcement learning settings can learn to communicate among themselves via discrete tokens accomplishing as team what agents would be unable to do alone However the current standard of using one hot vectors as discrete communication tokens prevents agents from acquiring more desirable aspects of communication such as zero shot understanding Inspired by word embedding techniques from natural language processing we propose neural agent architectures that enables them to communicate via discrete tokens derived from learned continuous space We show in decision theoretic framework that our tech ni que optimizes communication over wide range of scenarios whereas one hot tokens are only optimal under restrictive assumptions In self play experiments we validate that our trained agents learn to cluster tokens in semantically meaningful ways allowing them communicate in noisy environments where other techniques fail Lastly we demonstrate both that agents using our method can effectively respond to novel human communication and that humans can understand unlabeled emergent agent communication outperforming the use of one hot communication

Engineering Center Japan Atomic Energy Agency hira ne Shirak at To kai mura Naka gun Ibaraki Japan In the Gamma Ray Observation of Winter Thunderstorms GROWTH collaboration launched mapping observation campaign for high energy atmospheric phenomena related to thun der storms and lightning discharges This campaign has developed detection network of gamma rays with up to radiation monitors installed in Kanazawa and Komatsu cities Ishikawa Pre fec ture Japan where low charge center winter thunderstorms frequently occur During four winter seasons from October to April in total gamma ray glows minute lasting bursts of gamma rays originating from thunderclouds were detected Their average duration is sec Among the detected events were observed in nighttime The gamma ray glows can be cl as sie into temporally symmetric temporally asymmetric and lightning terminated types based on their count rate histories An averaged energy spectrum of the gamma ray glows is well ted with power law function with an exponential cu to whose photon index cu to energy and ux are MeV and erg cm MeV re spec iv ely The present paper provides the rst catalog of gamma ray glows and their statistical analysis detected during winter thunderstorms in the Kanazawa and Komatsu areas

STABILITY OF ASSOCIATED PRIMES AND DEPTH OF INTEGRAL CLOSURES OF POWERS OF EDGE IDEALS DONG HU MAU AND TR AN NAM TRUNG Abstract In this paper we study associated primes and depth of integral closures of powers of edge ideals We provide sharp bounds on how big of powers for which the set of associated primes and the depth of integral closures of powers of edge ideals are stable

Orbital contributions in the element resolved valence electronic structure of Bi Se Cheng Tai Kuo Shih Chi eh Lin Jean Pascal Rue ff Zhe sheng Chen Irene Aguilera Gustav ihl mayer Lukasz luc in ski Ismael Graf Giuseppina Conti Ivan Vartan ants Claus Schneider Charles Fadl ey Department of Physics University of California Davis Davis California USA Materials Sciences Division Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory Berkeley California USA Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Light source LAC National Accelerator Laboratory Menlo Park California USA Synchrotron SOLEIL Or me des Meri sier Saint Aubin BP Gif sur Yvette France Sorbonne Universit CNRS Labor to ire de Chi mie Physique Ma tire et Rayon ne ment Paris France Peter Gru nberg Institut PG For chung zentrum Juli ch Juli ch Germany Department of Physics Federal University of Paran Curitiba Brazil Advanced Light Source Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory Berkeley California USA Deutsches El ek tron en Synchrotron DES Not ke stra Hamburg Germany National Research Nuclear University ME PhI Moscow Engineering Physics Institute Kashi sko Sho sse Moscow Russia email ct kuo lac stanford edu Deceased August ABSTRACT In this work we studied the bulk band structure of topological insulator TI Bi Se and determined the contributions of the Bi and Se orbital states to the valence bands using standing wave excited hard ray photo emission spectroscopy SW HA XP ES This SW technique can provide the element resolved information and extract individual Bi and Se contributions to the Bi Se valence band Comparisons with density functional theory FT calculations LDA and GW reveal that the Bi Bi and Se states are dominant in the Bi Se HA XP ES valence band These findings represent major step further in describing the Bi Se band structure and improve the accuracy for future FT predictions of emergent properties in this class of TIs

LOCAL FOURIER ANALYSIS OF BALANCING DOMAIN DECOMPOSITION BY CONSTRAINTS ALGORITHMS JED BROWN YUN HUI HE AND SCOTT MACLACHLAN Abstract Local Fourier analysis is commonly used tool for the analysis of multi grid and other multi level algorithms providing both insight into observed convergence rates and predictive analysis of the performance of many algorithms In this paper for the rst time we adapt local Fourier analysis to examine variants of two and three level balancing domain decomposition by constraints BDD algorithms to better understand the eigenvalue distributions and condition number bounds on these preconditioned operators This adaptation is based on mo died choice of basis for the space of Fourier harmonics that greatly implies the application of local Fourier analysis in this setting The local Fourier analysis is validated by considering the two dimensional La plac ian and predicting the condition numbers of the preconditioned operators with die rent sizes of subdomain Several variants are analyzed showing the two and three level performance of the lumped variant can be greatly improved when used in multiplicative combination with weighted diagonal scaling pre conditioner with weight optimized through the use of LF Keywords Balancing domain decomposition by constraints BDD Domain decomposition Local Fourier analysis Multiplicative methods AMS subject classic at ions

The maximum entropy principle of self gravitating id system and el equations Hikaru Yumi saki Gunma University Show Maebashi Japan August Abstract We investigate the maximum entropy principle for general el theory including metric tensor vector el dA and scalar el das the fundamental lds and nd imposing an ordinary constraint relation on the el equations which is constructed of the Euler Lagrange derivative of an arbitrary Lagrangian density the stress tensor of perfect id and the electric current vector in ordinary man ner are compatible with the maximum entropy principle and ii varying also the constraint relation on the maximum entropy principle requires next rascal are ld which is introduced as the difference from the ordinary constraint relation on The el is also interpreted as the difference between two geometries one is the geometry de ned by in which the thermodynamical relations are written in the ordinary and simplest form and the other is the geometry de ned by in which force free id ow along geodesic orbit instead the thermo dyna ical relations the rst law of thermodynamics and the Gibbs Du he relation are mo died We also calculate the variation of the entropy in the Love lock theory in which is expressed as linear combination of the variations of the Kodama energy and the size of the system Finally with the el introduced we propose set of el equations in the thermodynamical and kinematic al geometries which possesses appropriate scaling properties and point out that in vacuum spacetime they resemble those of the dil at on gravity in the string and Einstein frame respectively Contents

Model Based Opponent Modeling Xia open gYu Jie chuan Jiang Hao bin Jiang Zon qing Lu Peking University yu xiao peng jie chuan jiang hao bin jiang zon qing lu pku edu cn Abstract When one agent interacts with multi agent environment it is challenging to deal with various opponents unseen before Modeling the behaviors goals or beliefs of opponents could help the agent adjust its policy to adapt to different opponents In addition it is also important to consider opponents who are learning simultaneously or capable of reasoning However existing work usually tackles only one of the aforementioned types of opponent In this paper we propose model based opponent modeling BOM which employs the environment model to adapt to all kinds of opponent BOM simulates the recursive reasoning process in the environment model and imagines set of improving opponent policies To effectively and accurately represent the opponent policy BOM further mixes the imagined opponent policies according to the similarity with the real behaviors of opponents Empirically we show that BOM achieves more effective adaptation than existing methods in competitive and cooperative environments respectively with different types of opponent ed policy nave learner and reasoning learner

Learning Barrier Cert cates Towards Safe Reinforcement Learning with Zero Training time Violations Yu ping Luo and Ten gyu Ma Computer Science Department Princeton University Department of Computer Science and Statistics Stanford University August Abstract Training time safety violations have been major concern when we deploy reinforcement learning algorithms in the real world This paper explores the possibility of safe RL algorithms with zero training time safety violations in the challenging setting where we are only given safe but trivial reward initial policy without any prior knowledge of the dynamics model and additional in data We propose an algorithm Co trained Barrier Cert cate for Safe RL CRABS which iterative ly learns barrier cert cates dynamics models and policies The barrier cert cates learned via adversarial training ensure the policys safety assuming calibrated learned dynamics model We also add regular iz ation term to encourage larger cer tied regions to enable better exploration Empirical simulations show that zero safety violations are already challenging for suite of simple environments with only dimensional state space especially if high reward policies have to visit regions near the safety boundary Prior methods require hundreds of violations to achieve decent rewards on these tasks whereas our proposed algorithms incur zero violations

EP manuscript No will be inserted by the editor Anisotropic turbulence in relativistic plasmas Abhi sek Saha and Soma any al School of Physics University of Hyderabad Ga chi bowl Hyderabad India the date of receipt and acceptance should be inserted later Abstract Signs of turbulence have been observed at the relativistic heavy ion collision at high collision energies We study the signatures of turbulence in this system and nd that there are sign cant departures from isotropic turbulence in the initial stages of the collision Since the anisotropic uc tu at ions are sub leading to the isotropic uc tu at ions the Kolmogorov spectrum can usually be obtained even for the initial stages However the energy spectrum and the temperature uc tu at ions indicate deviations from isotropic turbulence Since strong momentum an iso tro py exists between the transverse and the longitudinal plane we study the energy density spectrum in these two planes The geometrical an iso tro py is ree ted in the anisotropic turbulence generated in the rotating plasma and wend that the scaling exponent is die rent in the two planes Wend that the scaling exponents in the longitudinal plane are independent of centrality while the scaling exponent in the transverse plane depends on the centrality range We also obtain the temperature spectrum in the initial stages The spectrum deviates from the Gaussian spectra expected for an isotropic turbulence All these seem to indicate that the large scale momentum an iso tro py persists in the smaller length scales for the relativistic heavy ion collisions PAC XX XX XX No PAC code given Key words Kolmogorov length scale turbulence spec energies favoured the value of While the tra energy dissipation hydro dynamic models are required to follow the qui lib rium conditions the initial stage is far from equilibrium in all respects Kinetic theory has been used to describe

Semi supervised Conditional GAN for Simultaneous Generation and Detection of Phishing URLs Game theoretic Perspective Sharif Amit Kam ran Sham ik Sen gupta and Ali rez aT vak koli Dept of Computer Science Engineering University of Nevada Reno NV USA ska mr an nevada unr edu sen gupta unr edu ta vak kol unr edu Abstract Spear Phishing is type of cyber attack where the attackers end shy per links through email on well researched targets The objective is to obtains en it ive information such as name credentials credit card numbers or other crucial data by imitating oneself as trustworthy website According to recent report phishing incidents nearly doubled in frequency in In recent times machine learning techniques have become the standard for defending against such attacks Many augmentations have been made for improving the existing architectures such as Convolutional Networks Recurrent Networks and Generative Ad versa al Networks However these architectures were designed with only defense in mind Moreover the attackers perspective and motivation are absent while re ting such training and deployment pipelines To address this we need game theoretic approach to understand the rational decision making process of the at acker Hacker and the defender Phishing URL detector We propose Con it ional Generative Adversarial Network for real time phishing URL detection Additionally we train our architecture in semi supervised manner to dist in guis between adversarial and real examples along with detecting malicious and benign URLs We also design two games between the attacker and defender in training and deployment settings by utilizing the game theoretic perspective Our experiments con rm that the proposed architecture surpasses recent state of the art architectures for phishing URLs detection Keywords Generative Adversarial Networks Phishing Attacks Phishing URL detection Cyber Security Phishing

New form of kernel in equation for Nakanishi function Karma nov Le be dev Physical Institute Lenin sky Prospekt Moscow Russia Dated August The Be the Sal peter amplitude is expressed by means of the Nakanishi integral re pre sen ation via smooth function This functions at is esa canonical equation Ng However calculations of the kernel in this equation presented previously were restricted to one boson exchange and depending on method dealt with complex multivalued functions Although these di cul ties are surmountable but in practice they complicate ding the unambiguous result In the present work an unambiguous expression for the kernel in terms of real functions is derived For the one boson scalar exchange the explicit formula for is found With this equation and kernel the binding energies calculated previously are reproduced Their ding as well as calculation of the Be the Sal peter amplitude in the Minkowski space become not more di cult than in the Euclidean one The method can be generalized to any kernel given by irreducible Feynman graph This generalization is illustrated by example of the cross ladder kernel PAC numbers Pm Ge St

Draft version August Typeset using LATEX two column style in AS TeX Probing the nu cleo synthetic contribution of low metal li city low mass star companions of EMP stars She eelam mal and run Goswami Indian Institute of Astrophysics Kora mangal Bangalore India Received XXX Revised XXX Accepted XXX Submitted to pJ ABSTRACT The observed abundance diversities among the EMP stars can shed light on the formation and evolution of elements in the early Galaxy In this work we present results obtained from detailed abundance analysis of sample of seven extrinsic carbon stars The analysis is based on high resolution spectra obtained with HC HE SP and SUBARU HDS We present for the rst time the elemental abundance results for the objects BD BD HE HE and BD Abundances of few elements are available in literature for HE and HD we present an update on the abundances of these elements along with new abundance estimates for several other elements Our analysis con rms the object HD to be CH star While BD HE and BD are found to be EMP stars the objects BD HE and HE are found to belong to EMP group The observed abundance patterns of the three EMP stars are well reproduced with the process model predictions While the objects BD and HD are con med binaries the binary status of the remaining objects are not known Analysis based on die rent elemental abundance ratios con rms low mass former GB companions for all the objects Kinematic analysis shows that BD HE HE and BD belong to the Galactic halo whereas BD HE and HD are members of Galactic thin disk Keywords stars Abundances stars chemically peculiar stars carbon stars individual

The Rope length of Complex Knots Alexander lot and Matthew Maldonado Department of Physics and Astronomy California State University Long Beach The rope length of knot is the minimum contour length of tube of unit radius that traces out the knot in three dimensional space without self overlap colloquially the minimum amount of rope needed to tie given knot Theoretical upper and lower bounds have been established for the asymptotic relationship between crossing number and rope length and stronger bounds have been conjectured but numerical bounds have only been calculated exhaustively for knots and links with up to crossings which are not uci ent ly complex to test these conjectures Existing rope length measurements also have not established the complexity required to reach asymptotic scaling with crossing number Here we investigate the rope length of knots and links beyond the range of tested crossing numbers past both the crossing limit as well as the crossing limit of the standard knot catalog We investigate torus knots up to crossings establishing stronger upper bound forT knots and links and demonstrating power law scaling in below the proven limit We investigate satellite knots up to crossings to determine the eec of systematic crossing increasing operation on rope length ding that satellite knot typically has thrice the rope length of its companion We nd that rope length is well described by model of repeated Hopf links in which each component adopts minimal convex hull around the cross section of the others and derive formulae that heuristic ally predict the crossing rope length relationship of knots and links without free parameters

Left Right symmetric fermions and sterile neutrinos from complex split bi qua tern ions and bi oct onions Vats aly Vai bhava and Te in der Singh Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur India Tata Institute of Fundamental Research Hom Bha bha Road Mumbai India vats aly it ac in tp singh ifr res in ABSTRACT In this article we investigate the application of complex split bi qua tern ions and bi oct onions to the standard model We show that the Clio rd algebras Cl and Cl can be used for making left right symmetric fermions Hence we incorporate right handed neutrinos in the division algebras based approach to the standard model The right handed neutrinos also known as sterile neutrinos are potential dark matter candidate We discuss the left right symmetric fermions and their phenomenology using the division algebra approach We describe the gauge groups associated with the left right symmetric model and prospects for uni cation including gravity through division algebras We investigate the possibility of obtaining three generations of fermions and charge mass ratios through the exceptional Jordan algebra and the exceptional groups and

Resonant scattering of plane wave and twisted photons at the Gamma Factory Valeri Serbo Novosibirsk State University RUS Novosibirsk Russia and So bole Institute of Mathematics RUS Novosibirsk Russia Andrey urz hy kov Ph ys kali sch Technische Bundesanstalt Braunschweig Germany Institut fur Ma them at is che Ph sik Technische Universitat Braunschweig Braunschweig Germany and Laboratory for Emerging Nano metrology Braunschweig Braunschweig Germany Andrey Vo lot ka School of Physics and Engineering IT MO University RUS Saint Petersburg Russia Dated August We present theoretical investigation of the resonant elastic scattering of laser photons by ultra relativistic partially stripped ions that is the core process of the Gamma Factory project Special emphasis in our study is placed on the angular distribution and polarization of scattered photons as observed in the collider and ion rest reference frames In order to describe these angular and polarization properties for arbitrary relativistic many electron ion the general approach based on the application of irreducible polarization tensors is laid down By making use of the polarization tensors we explore in detail the scattering of both conventional plane wave and twisted or vortex photons For the former case we show how the propagation directions and polarization states of incident and outgoing photons are related to each other for the nS cid nS nS cid nS and nS cid nS resonant transitions For the scattering of initially twisted light that carries nonzero orbital angular momentum we explore the angular distribution of secondary photons and discuss the conditions under which they are also twisted

An approximate random iz ation test for high dimensional two sample Beh rens Fisher problem under arbitrary co variances Rui Wang and Wang liX Center for Applied Statistics and School of Statistics Ren min University of China Beijing China Thursday th August Abstract This paper is concerned with the problem of comparing the population means of two groups of independent observations An approximate random iz ation test procedure based on the test statistic of at Chen Qin is proposed The asymptotic behavior of the test statistic as well as the randomized statistic is studied under weak conditions In our theoretical framework observations are not assumed to be identically distributed even within groups No condition on the ei gen structure of the co variance is imposed And the sample sizes of two groups are allowed to be unbalanced Under general conditions all possible asymptotic distributions of the test statistic are obtained We derive the asymptotic level and local power of the proposed test procedure Our theoretical results show that the proposed test procedure can adapt to all possible asymptotic distributions of the test statistic and always has correct test level asymptotically Also the proposed test procedure has good power behavior Our numerical experiments show that the proposed test procedure has favorable performance compared with several alter vat ive test procedures Keywords Beh rens Fisher problem High dimensional data Random iz ation test Lindeberg principle

RECONSTRUCTING DYNAMICAL SYSTEM AND FORECASTING TIME SERIES BY SELF CONSISTENT DEEP LEARNING PRE PRINT Zhe Wang Claude Guet Energy research institute NTU Energy research institute NTU Nanyang Technological University Nanyang Technological University Singapore Singapore zhe wang ntu edu sg and School of Materials Science and Engineering Nanyang Technological University Singapore guet ntu edu sg August ABSTRACT We introduce self consistent deep learning framework which for noisy deterministic time series provides unsupervised lte ring state space reconstruction ident cation of the underlying differential equations and forecasting Without priori information on the signal we embed the time series in state space where deterministic structures attractor are revealed Under the assumption that the evolution of solution trajectories is described by an unknown dynamical system welter out stochastic outliers The embedding function the solution trajectories and the dynamical systems are constructed using deep neural networks respectively By exploiting the different ability of the neural solution trajectory the neural dynamical system is de ned locally at each time mitigating the need for propagating gradients through numerical solvers On chaotic time series masked by additive Gaussian noise we demonstrate the lte ring ability and the predictive power of the proposed framework Keywords Neural ordinary differential equations State space reconstruction Filtering and forecasting

An interacting molecular cloud scenario for production of gamma rays and neutrinos from MAGIC and MAGIC Pra bir Bani and run ava had ra High Energy and Cosmic Ray Research Centre University of North Bengal Siliguri India Recently the MAGIC telescope observed three TeV gamma ray extended sources in the galactic plane in the neighborhood of radio SNR Among them the PWN HESS was detected earlier by the HESS observatory during its rst galactic plane survey The other two sources MAGIC and MAGIC are detected for the rst time at such high energies Here we shall show that the observed gamma rays from the SNR and the HESS can be explained in terms of hadron ic interactions of the PWN SNR accelerated cosmic rays with the ambient matter We shall further demonstrate that the observed gamma rays from the MAGIC can be interpreted through hadron ic interactions of runaway cosmic rays from PWN HESS with the molecular cloud at the location of MAGIC No such association has been found between MAGIC and SNR or PWN HESS We have examined the maximum energy attainable by cosmic ray particles in the SNR PWN HESS and the possibility of their detection with future gamma ray telescopes The study of TeV neutrino emissions from the stated sources suggests that the HESS should be detected by Ice Cube Gen neutrino telescope in few years of observation Keywords SNR HESS Cosmic rays neutrinos gamma rays

Learning Task Agnostic Skills with Data driven Guidance Even Kle ms dal Sverre Her land Abdul majid Murad Abstract et al Ey sen bach et al Sharma et al Campo set al To increase autonomy in reinforcement learning agents need to learn useful behaviours without re Although skill discovery without reward function can be li ance on manually designed reward functions To helpful as primitive for downstream tasks most of the that end skill discovery methods have been used emergent behaviours in the learned skills are useless or to learn the intrinsic options available to an agent of little interest This is direct consequence of under using task agnostic objectives However without constrained skill discovery in complex and high di men the guidance of task spec ic rewards emergent ional state space One possible solution is to leverage prior behaviours are generally useless due to the under knowledge tobias skill discovery towards subset of the constrained problem of skill discovery in complex state space through hand crafted transformation of the and high dimensional spaces This paper pro state space Ey sen bache tal Campo set al poses framework for guiding the skill discovery However utilizing prior knowledge to hand craft such towards the subset of expert visited states using transformation contradicts the primary goal of unsupervised learned state projection We apply our method RL which is reducing manual design efforts and reliance in various reinforcement learning RL tasks and on prior knowledge show that such projection results in more useful behaviours Instead we explore how to learn parameterized state pro ect ion that directs skill discovery towards the subset of expert visited states To that end we employ examples of expert data to train state encoder through an auxiliary

Modelling the Dissipation Range of von Kr mn Turbulence Spectrum Fernanda dos Santos Laura Botero Bol var Cornelis Venner and Leandro de Santana University of Twente rie ner lola an NB Netherlands Noise pollution caused by now turbulence is major problem in many applications such as propellers and fans Leading edge noise models Amie ts model are widely applied to predict the noise produced by these applications This noise prediction model relies on the accuracy of the turbulence spectrum which is usually assumed to be the von Kr mn energy spectrum for isotropic turbulence However the von Kr mn spectrum does not model accurately the dissipation range of the turbulent energy resulting in incorrect far el noise predictions for the high frequency range An exponential correction can be applied to the spectrum to model the dissipation range This correction depends on the dissipation frequency which is the frequency where the energy spectrum changes from dependence of to an exponential decay This study experimentally investigates nearly isotropic now turbulence and determines the ow el characteristics that ect the dissipation frequency in order to model this frequency and the dissipation range Experiments have been conducted with two passive grids and hot wire nemo me try in the Aero acoustic Wind Tunnel of the University of Twente The turbulence uniformity in the test section and the turbulence development in the stream wise direction were analyzed showing that the grid generated turbulence was mostly uniform and nearly isotropic The dissipation frequency was observed to depend on the turbulence intensity the free stream velocity and the turbulence length scale An expression to compute this frequency is proposed as well as formula to predict the dissipation range The predicted leading edge noise is aec ted by the dissipation range modelling in the high frequency range presenting decrease in level up to dB for the highest frequencies Journal of the Korean Astronomical Society https doi org JK AS October pISS ISSN Published under Creative Commons license CC BY http jk as as org RE ACCELERATION OF COSMIC RAY ELECTRONS BY MULTIPLE CM SHOCKS yesung Kang Department of Earth Sciences Pusan National University Busan Korea hs kang pusan ac kr Received August accepted August Abstract Radio relics could be generated by multiple shocks induced in the turbulent intra cluster medium during galaxy mergers Kang demonstrated that the re acceleration of cosmic ray CR protons via diu sive shock acceleration DS by multiple shocks could enhance the acceleration ec ien cy and at ten the CR spectrum compared to single episode of DS Here we examine the CR electron acceleration through multiple re acceleration by considering energy losses and decompression of the parti cle distribution and magnetic lds in the post shock region between consecutive shock passages We nd that the accumulated eec ts of repeated re acceleration are sign cant if preceding shocks are stronger than the last shock and the shock passage interval is cid Myr In such cases both the CR spectrum and the ensuing radiation spectrum behind the last shock are enhanced and become tter than the canonical DS power law forms As result the shock Mach number estimated from radio observations tends be higher than the actual Mach number of the last shock Thus multiple episodes of DS may explain the enhanced acceleration ec ien cy for CR electrons and the discrepancy of shock Mach numbers cid inferred for some observed radio relics rad Keywords acceleration of particles cosmic rays galaxies clusters general shock waves

On the Parameter Estimation in the Schwartz Smiths Two Factor Model Karol Bin ko ski Peil un He Nino Kor zak hi and Pavel Shevchenko Macquarie University North Ryde NSW Australia karol bin ko ski edu au peil un he students edu au nino kor zak hi edu au pavel shevchenko edu au Abstract The two unobservable state variables representing the short and long term factors introduced by Schwartz and Smith in for risk neutral pricing of futures contracts are modelled as two correlated Or nste in hlen beck processes The Kal man Filter KF method has been implemented to estimate the short and long term factors jointly with unknown model parameters The parameter ident cation problem arising within the likelihood function in the KF has been addressed by introducing an additional constraint The obtained model parameter es ti mates are the conditional Maximum Likelihood Estimators LEs evaluated within the KF Consistency of the conditional LEs is stud ed The methodology has been tested on simulated data Keywords Kal man Filter parameter estimation partially observed linear system

Reasoning about Iteration and Recursion Uniformly based on Big step Semantics Xi meng Li Qian ying Zhang Guo hui Wang Zhi ping Shi Yong Guan Beijing Key Laboratory of Electronic System Reliability and Prognostics Beijing Engineering Research Center of High Reliable Embedded System Beijing Advanced Innovation Center for Imaging Theory and Technology Capital Normal University Beijing China Abstract reliable technique for deductive program ver cation should be proven sound with respect to the semantics of the programming lan gu age For each die rent language the construction of separate sound ness proof is often laborious undertaking In language independent pro gram ver cation common aspects of computer programs are addressed to enable sound reasoning for all languages In this work we propose solution for the sound reasoning about iteration and recursion based on the big step operational semantics of any programming language We give inductive proofs on the soundness and relative completeness of our reasoning technique We illustrate the technique at implied program ming languages of the imperative and functional paradigms with diverse features We also mechanism all formal results in the Coq proof assistant

Adaptive Path Planning for AV based Multi Resolution Semantic Segmentation Felix St ache Jonas West he ider Federico Mag is tri Marija Popo vic Cyril St ach is Abstract In this paper we address the problem of adaptive path planning for accurate semantic segmentation of terrain using unmanned aerial vehicles Vs The usage of Vs for terrain monitoring and remote sensing is rapidly gaining momentum due to their high mobility low cost and ex ble deployment However key challenge is planning missions to maximize the value of acquired data in large environments given ig ht time limitations To address this we propose an online planning algorithm which adapts the AV paths to obtain high resolution semantic segmentation necessary in areas on the terrain with ne details as they are detected in incoming images This enables us to perform close inspections at low altitudes only where required without wasting energy on exhaustive mapping at maximum resolution key feature of our approach is new accuracy model for deep learning based architectures that captures the relationship between AV altitude and semantic segmentation accuracy We evaluate our approach on the application of crop weed segmentation in precision agriculture using real world el data

Open quantum systems coupled to nite baths hierarchy of master equations Andreu Rie ra Camp en Anna San per and Philipp Strasberg sica Teo rica In form cio Fe no mens Qua tics Depart ment de sica Universitat Auto noma de Barcelona Bella terra Spain CREA Ps Ll us Company Barcelona Spain An open quantum system that is put in contact with an in nite bath is pushed towards equilibrium while the state of the bath remains unchanged If the bath is nite the open system still relaxes to equilibrium but it induces dynamical evolution of the bath state In this work we extend the weak coupling master equation approach of open quantum systems interacting with nite baths to include imprecise measurements of the bath energy Those imprecise measurements are not only always the case in practice but they also unify the theoretical description We investigate the circumstances under which our equation reduces to the more standard Born Markov secular master equation As result we obtain hierarchy of master equations that improve their accuracy by including more dynamical information about the bath We discuss this formalism in detail for particular non interacting environment where the Bolt mann temperature and the Kubo Martin Sch winger relation naturally arise Finally we apply our hierarchy of master equations to study the central spin model Au

HIGH PERFORMANCE ACROSS TWO ATARI PADDLE GAMES USING THE SAME PERCEPTUAL CONTROL ARCHITECTURE WITHOUT TRAINING PRE PRINT Tau see Gul rez Warren Mansell Department of Computing and Research Division of Psychology and Mental Health Sy sc on Australia Pty Ltd School of Health Sciences Melbourne VIC Australia University of Manchester UK gta use ef ieee org warren mansell manchester ac uk August ABSTRACT Deep reinforcement learning DR requires large samples and long training time to operate optimal ly Yet humans rarely require long periods training to perform well on novel tasks such as computer games once they are provided with an accurate program of instructions We used perceptual control theory PCT to construct simple closed loop model which requires no training samples and training time within videogame study using the Arcade Learning Environment ALE The model was programmed to parse inputs from the environment into hierarchically organised perceptual signals and it computed dynamic error signal by subtracting the incoming signal for each perceptual variable from reference signal to drive output signals to reduce this error We tested the same model across two different Atari paddle games Breakout and Pong to achieve performance atleast as high as DR paradigms and close to good human performance Our study shows that perceptual control models based on simple assumptions can perform well without learning We conclude by specifying parsimonious role of learning that maybe more similar to psychological functioning Keywords Perceptual control theory Atari games Machine learning Art ici al agent

EUROPEAN ORGANIZATION FOR NUCLEAR RESEARCH CERN EP August Inclusive production at mid rapidity in pp collisions at TeV ALICE collaboration Abstract Were port on the inclusive production cross section measured at the CERN Large Hadron Col li der in proton proton collisions at centre of mass energy TeV The mesons are re constructed in the decay channel and the measurements are performed at mid rapidity in the transverse momentum interval GeV using minimum bias data sample corre pond ing to an integrated luminosity nb and an Electromagnetic Calorimeter triggered in data sample with Lint pb The pT integrated production cross section at mid rapidity computed using the minimum bias data sample is dy stat syst lumi An approximate logarithmic dependence with the collision energy is suggested by these results and available world data in agreement with model predictions The integrated and differential measurements are compared with measurements in pp collisions at lower energies and with several recent phenom eno logical calculations based on the non relativistic QCD and Color Evaporation models CERN for the be net of the ALICE Collaboration Reproduction of this article or parts of it is allowed as specie in the CC BY license See Appendix for the list of collaboration members

Prepared for submission to IN ST nd International Workshop on Radiation Imaging Detectors June to July Ghent Belgium online Medi pix proton and carbon ion measurements across full energy ranges and at clinical ux rates in Med Austro IR Bal Schmitz er De Franco Enke Nik he Science Park XG Amsterdam Nederland BG GmbH Med Austro Marie Curie Stra Wiener Neustadt sterreich mail avr it nik he nl Abstract The Medi pix hybrid pixel detector with silicon sensor has been evaluated as beam instrumentation device with proton and carbon ion measurements in the non clinical research room IR of Med Austro nI on Therapy Center Protons energies are varied from to MeV with to protons per second impinging on the detector surface For carbon ions energies are varied from to MeV amu with to carbon ions per second Measurements include simultaneous high resolution be amp role and beam intensity with various beam parameters at up to FPS frames per second count rate linearity and an assessment of radiation damage after the measurement day using ray tube to provide homogeneous radiation measurement The count rate linearity is found to be linear within the uncertainties dominated by accelerator related sources due to special setup for the measurements without de graders Various frequency components are den tied within the beam intensity over time rst ly including Hz with standard deviation secondly Hz and thirdly Hz direct correlation between the number of zero counting and noisy pixels is observed in the measurements with the highest ux No conclusive evidence of long term radiation damage was found as result of these measurements over one day Keywords Instrumentation for particle beam therapy Solid state detectors Beam line in tru ment ation beam position and role monitors beam intensity monitors bunch length monitors Hybrid detectors Instrumentation for hadron therapy Radiation damage to detector materials solid state Beam dynamics Corresponding author

AN ADAPTIVE TIME STEPPING FULL DISC RET IZ ATION FOR STOCHASTIC ALLEN CAHN EQUATION CHUCHU CHEN TONG HE DANG JI AL IN HONG Abstract It is known in that regular explicit Euler type scheme with uniform time step though computationally ec ent may diverge for the stochastic Allen Cahn qua tion To overcome the divergence this paper proposes an adaptive time stepping full is ret iz ation whose spatial disc ret iz ation is based on the spectral Gale rk in method and tem oral direction is the adaptive exponential integrator scheme It is proved that the expected number of time steps is nite if the adaptive time step function is bounded suitably Based on the stability analysis in norm of the numerical solution it is shown that the strong convergence order of this adaptive time stepping full disc ret iz ation is the same as usual order in space and in time under the correlation assumption kA kL on the noise Numerical experiments are presented to support the theoretical results
