Node Connectivity Augmentation via Iterative Randomized Rounding Har is Angeli dak is Dylan Hyatt De ne sik Laura San it TU Eindhoven Abstract Many fundamental network design problems deal with the design of low cost networks that are resilient to the failure of their elements such as nodes or links One such problem is Connectivity Augmentation where the goal is to cheaply increase the connectivity of given network from value to The most studied setting focuses on edge connectivity and it is well known that it can be reduced to the case called Cactus Augmentation From an approximation perspective By rk Grand on and Jabal Amel were the rst who managed to break the approximation barrier for this problem by exploiting connection to the Steiner Tree problem and by tailoring the analysis of the iterative ran do miz ed rounding technique for Steiner Tree to the spec ic instances arising from this connection Very recently Nut ov observed that similar reduction to Steiner Tree also holds for anode connectivity problem called Block Tree Augmentation where the goal is to add edges to given spanning tree in or der to make the resulting graph node connected Block Tree Augmentation can be seen as the direct generalization of the well studied Tree Augmentation problem to the node setting Combining Nu to vs result with the algorithm of By rk Grand on and Jabal Amel yields approximation for Block Tree Augmentation that is the best bound known so far In this work we give approximation algorithm for the problem of augmenting the node connectivity of any given graph from to As corollary we improve upon the state of the art approximation factor for Block Tree Augmentation Our result is obtained by developing die rent and simpler analysis of the iterative randomized rounding technique when applied to the Steiner Tree instances arising from the aforementioned reductions Our results also imply approximation algorithm for Cactus Augmentation While this does not beat the best approximation factor by Cec chet to Trau and Zen kl use that is known for this problem key point of our work is that the analysis of our approximation factor is quite simple compared to previous results in the literature In addition our work gives new insights on the iterative randomized rounding method that might be of independent interest

Low complexity Scaling Methods for DC II Approximations Coelho intra Mad nayak Per era Abstract This paper introduces collection of scaling methods for generating point DC II approximations based on point low complexity transformations Such scaling is based on the Hou recursive matrix fac tori ation of the exact point DC II matrix Encompassing the widely employed Jr idi Alfa lou Meher scaling method the proposed techniques are shown to produceD CT II approximations that outperform the transforms resulting from the JAM scaling method according to total error energy and mean squared error Orthogonality conditions are derived and an extensive error analysis based on statistical simulation demon st rates the good performance of the introduced scaling methods hardware implementation is also provided demonstrating the competitiveness of the proposed methods when compared to the JAM scaling method Keywords DC Approximation Fast algorithms Image compression After its inception in the discrete cosine transform DC has attracted sign cant amount of attention leading to large number of variations and algorithms for its computation In particular the DC of type II DC II is widely employed for image and video compression codecs such asH MPEG VC HE VC and the new VC standard The polynomial arithmetic technique the use of the divide and conquer technique to reduce the degree of the polynomial and the matrix factorization technique direct factorization into the product of sparse matrices are the two main techniques that can be used to factor DC matrices and produce efc ent hardware implementations Traditional video and image codecs achieve data de correlation by means of block wise image analysis of sub images As result considerable efforts have been put into ding methods for the point DC II com put ation However the increasing demand for energy efc ent hardware implementations moved the Xi sci en tic community towards the development of low complexity integer based approximate transforms transforms whose fast algorithms simply require trivial multiplications and still provide good mathematical properties In particular deriving good low complexity approximations has been an actively pursued goal Such approximate approaches have led to robust image and video comp res sion systems capable of sign cant ly reducing the computational cost of the transform stage Although the point DC II is ubiquitously employed modern codecs such as the high efc ien cy video coding HE VC re quire the DC II computation for larger block lengths including and Energy momentum tensor and duality symmetry of linear zed gravity in Maxwell ian formalism Gabor olt To th Wigner Research Centre for Physics Kon kol The ge Miklos ut Budapest Hungary to th gabor olt wigner hu Abstract Maxwell like formulation of linear zed gravity in at background based on the Fier tensor as the analogue of the electromagnetic el strength is discussed in detail and used to study fundamental properties of the linear zed gravitational el In particular the linear zed Einstein equations are formulated as rst order partial dieren ti al equations in terms of the Fier tensor which is constructed from the rst derivatives of the linear zed metric in analogy with the rst order Maxwell equations An energy momentum tensor Tab is found for the linear zed grav it lg ional el with properties that allow it to be regarded as unique analogue of the standard energy momentum tensor of the electromagnetic el Tab is quadratic in lg the Fier tensor trace less and satis es the dominant energy condition in gauge that contains the transverse trace less gauge In generalized harmonic gauges two ad it ional symmetric energy momentum tensors are found that are analogous to some extent to the energy momentum tensor of the electromagnetic el It is further shown that in suitable gauges including the transverse trace less gauge linear zed gravity in the absence of matter has duality symmetry that maps the Fier tensor which is antisymmetric in its rst two indices into its dual Conserved currents as soci ted with the gauge and duality symmetries of the linear zed gravitational el are also determined These currents show good analogy with the corresponding currents in electrodynamics Keywords Fier tensor linear zed gravity energy momentum tensor duality he li city generalized harmonic gauge transverse trace less gauge Maxwell equations

Will Have Order Optimizing Orders for Fair Reviewer Assignment Just in Pay an and Yair Zi ck University of Massachusetts Amherst Amherst MA USA pay an yz ick umass edu Abstract Sci en tic advancement require see ct ive peer review Papers should be reviewed by experts in the subject area but it is equally imp or tant that reviewer quality is fairly distributed amongst papers We model reviewer assignment as an instance of fair allocation problem present ing an extension of the classic round robin mechanism called Reviewer Round Robin RRR Round robin mechanisms are standard tool to ensure envy free up to one item EF allocations However fairness of ten comes at the cost of decrease dec ien cy To overcome this challenge we carefully select an approximately optimal round robin order Apply ing relaxation of sub modular it weak sub modular it we show that greedily inserting papers into an order yields approximation to the maximum welfare attainable by our round robin mechanism un der any order Our approach outputs highly ec ent EF allocations for three real conference datasets outperforming several state of the art paper assignment methods in fairness ec ien cy and runtime Keywords Fair Allocation Envy Free up to One Item Reviewer As sign ment

Pervasive Hand Gesture Recognition for Smartphones using Non audible Sound and Deep Learning Ahmed Ibrahim Ayman El Ref Sara Ahmed Mariam Abou Ela He hamM Era qi Mohamed Mo usta fa Department of Computer Science and Engineering The American University in Cairo New Cairo Egypt ahmed ibrahim ay ref ie abou eid mariam her qi mo usta fa uc egypt edu Keywords Sonar Gesture Recognition Convolutional Neural Network Data Augmentation Transfer Learning Feature Fusion Doppler Effect Abstract Due to the mass advancement in ubiquitous technologies nowadays new pervasive methods have come into the practice to provide new innovative features and stimulate the research on new human computer interac ions This paper presents hand gesture recognition method that utilizes the smartphones built in speakers and microphones The proposed system emits an ultrasonic sonar based signal inaudible sound from the smartphones stereo speakers which is then received by the smartphones microphone and processed via Convolutional Neural Network CNN for Hand Gesture Recognition Data augmentation techniques are pro posed to improve the detection accuracy and three dual channel input fusion methods are compared The rst method merges the dual channel audio as single input spec tr ogram image The second method adopts early fusion by concatenating the dual channel spec tro grams The third method adopts late fusion by having two convection al input branches processing each of the dual channel spec tro grams and then the outputs are merged by the last layers Our experimental results demonstrate promising detection accuracy for the six gestures presented in our publicly available data set with an accuracy of as baseline

Semi parametric Functional Factor Models with Bayesian Rank Selection Daniel Kowal Abstract Functional data are frequently accompanied by parametric templates that describe the typical shapes of the functions Although the templates incorporate critical do main knowledge parametric functional data models can incur sign cant bias which undermines the usefulness and interpret ability of these models To correct for model miss pec cation we augment the parametric templates with an in nite dimensional non parametric functional basis Crucially the non parametric factors are regularized with an ordered spike and slab prior which implicitly provides ranks election and satis es several appealing theoretical properties This prior is accompanied by parameter expansion scheme customized to boost MC MC ec ien cy and is broadly applicable for Bayesian factor models The non parametric basis functions are learned from the data yet constrained to be orthogonal to the parametric template in order to preserve is tinc ness between the parametric and non parametric terms The versatility of the proposed approach is illustrated through applications to synthetic data human mo tor control data and dynamic yield curve data Relative to parametric alternatives the proposed semi parametric functional factor model eliminates bias reduces excessive posterior and predictive uncertainty and provides reliable inference on the eec ti ve number of non parametric terms all with minimal additional computational costs KEYWORDS factor analysis non parametric regression shrinkage prior spike and slab prior yield curve Do belman Family Assistant Professor Department of Statistics Rice University daniel kowal rice edu

spectroscopic observations with Gaia alone set to deliver millions of Ca triplet region spectra across the Galaxy We aim to understand the dimensionality of the chemical abundance information in the Gaia RV data to in form galactic archaeology pursuits Wet quadratic model of four primary sources of variability described by labels of log Fe and Fe to the normalized ux of red clump stars from the Gaia RV like ARGOS survey We examine the residuals between ARGOS spectra and the models and nd that the models capture the ux variability across of the wavelength region The remaining residual variance is concentrated to the Ca triplet features at an amplitude up to of the normalized ux We use principal component analysis on the residuals and nd orthogonal correlations in the Ca triplet core and wings This variability not captured by our model presumably marks departures from the completeness of the LTE label description To test the indication of low dimensionality we turn to abundance space to infer how well we can predict measured Si Ca Ni and Al abundances from the Gaia RV like RAVE survey with models of log Fe and Mg Fe We nd that we can near entirely predict these abundances Using high precision APOGEE abundances we determine that measurement uncertainty of dex is required to capture additional information from these elements This indicates that four label models uci ent ly describes chemical abundance variance for per pixel in Gaia RV spectra Keywords stars abundances techniques spectroscopic Galaxy evolution

Extending quantum probabilistic error cancellation by noise scaling Andrea Mari Nathan Shamma and William Zeng Unitary Fund Goldman Sachs Co New York NY We propose general framework for quantum error mitigation that combines and generalizes two techniques probabilistic error cancellation PEC and zero noise extrapolation NE Similarly to PEC the proposed method represents ideal operations as linear combinations of noisy opera ions that are implementable on hardware However instead of assuming ed level of hardware noise we extend the set of implementable operations by noise scaling By construction this method encompasses both PECan dZ NEas particular cases and allows us to investigate larger set of hy rid techniques For example gate extrapolation can be used to implement PEC without requiring knowledge of the devices noise model avoiding gate set tomography Alternatively pro babil is tic error reduction can be used to estimate expectation values at intermediate virtual noise strengths below the hardware level obtaining partially mitigated results at lower sampling cost Moreover multiple results obtained with die rent noise reduction factors can be further post processed with NE to better approximate the zero noise limit CONTENTS search problem for near term quantum computing Stan dard quantum error correction codes are the ore ti

The Impact of Machine Learning on Registration for Image guided Interventions Systematic Review and Perspective Mathias Un be rath Cong Gao Yi cheng Hu Max Ju dish Russell Taylor Meh ran Armand Robert rupp Advanced Robotics and Computationally Augmented Environments ARCADE Lab Johns Hopkins University Abstract Image based navigation is widely considered the next frontier of minimally invasive surgery It is believed that image based navigation will increase the access to reproducible safe and high precision surgery as it may then be performed at acceptable costs and ort This is because image based techniques avoid the need of specialized equipment and seamlessly integrate with contemporary work ow Furthermore it is expected that image based navigation techniques will play major role in enabling mixed reality environments as well as autonomous and robot assisted work ow critical component of image guidance is registration technique to estimate the spatial relationships between structures pre operative volumetric imagery or models of surgical instruments and images there of such as intra operative ray oros copy or endoscopy While image based registration is mature technique its transition from the bench to the bedside has been restrained by well known challenges including brittleness with respect to optimization objective hyper parameter selection and initialization di cul ties in dealing with inconsistencies or multiple objects and limited single view performance One reason these challenges persist today is that analytical solutions are likely inadequate considering the complexity variability and high dimensionality of generic registration problems The recent advent of machine learning based approaches to imaging problems that rather than specifying the desired functional mapping approximate it using highly expressive parametric models holds promise for solving some of the notorious challenges in registration In this manuscript we review the impact of machine learning on registration to systematically summarize the recent advances made by introduction of this novel technology Grounded in these insights we then er our perspective on the most pressing needs sign cant open problems and possible next steps Keywords Art ici al intelligence Deep learning Surgical data science Image registration Computer assisted interventions Robotic surgery Augmented reality

Prepared for submission to HE August MIT TP UCSB MATH Charge completeness and the massless charge lattice in theory models of supergravity David Morrison and Washington Taylor Departments of Mathematics and Physics University of California Santa Barbara Santa Barbara CA USA Center for Theoretical Physics Department of Physics Massachusetts Institute of Technology Massachusetts Avenue Cambridge MA USA mail drm at math ucsb edu wat at mit edu Abstract We prove that for every supergravity theory that has anF theory description the property of charge completeness for the connected component of the gauge group meaning that all charges in the corresponding charge lattice are realized by massive or massless states in the theory is equivalent to standard assumption made in theory for how geometry encodes the global gauge theory by means of the Mor dell Weil group of the elliptic ration This result also holds in DF theory constructions for the parts of the gauge group that come from sections and from bran es We nd that in many theory models the full charge lattice of the theory is generated by massless charged states this occurs for each gauge factor where the associated anomaly coe cie nt satis es simple positiv it condition We describe many of the cases where this massless charge uci en cy condition holds as well as exceptions where the positiv it condition fails and analyze the related global structure of the gauge group and associated Mor dell Weil torsion in explicit theory models

Automatic Detection of OVID Vaccine Misinformation with Graph Link Prediction Maxwell We in zi rl and aM Hara bag iu Human Language Technology Research Institute Department of Computer Science The University of Texas at Dallas Richardson TX USA Abstract Enormous hope in the ecac of vaccines became recently successful reality in the gh against the OVID pandemic However vaccine hesitancy fueled by exposure to social media misinformation about OVID vaccines became major hurdle Therefore it is essential to automatically detect where misinformation about OVID vaccines on social media is spread and what kind of misinformation is discussed such that inoculation interventions can be delivered at the right time and in the right place in addition to interventions designed to address vaccine hesitancy This paper is addressing the rst step in tackling hesitancy against OVID vaccines namely the automatic detection of misinformation about the vaccines on Twitter the social media platform that has the highest volume of conversations about OVID and its vaccines We present Co Vax Lies new data set of tweets judged relevant to several misinformation targets about OVID vaccines on which novel method of detecting misinformation was developed Our method organizes Co Vax Lies in Misinformation Knowledge Graph as it casts misinformation detection as graph link prediction problem The misinformation detection method detailed in this paper takes advantage of the link scoring functions provided by several knowledge embedding methods The experimental results demonstrate the superiority of this method when compared with classic ation based methods widely used currently

Toronto ON Canada konstantino lei zero vich jesse lucie som nath kundu ry ers on ca Abstract The search type problem of evacuating robots in the wireless model from the Euclidean unit disk was rst introduced and studied by Czy owicz et al DISC Since then the problem has seen along list of follow up results pertaining to variations as well as to upper and lower bound improvements All established results in the area study this dimensional search type problem in the Euclidean metric space where the search space the unit disk enjoys sign cant metric symmetries We initiate and study the problem of evacuating robots in the wireless model from cid unit disks where in particular robots moves are measured in the underlying metric space To the best of our knowledge this is the rst study of search type problem with mobile agents in more general metric spaces The problem is particularly challenging since even the circumference of the cid unit disks have been the subject of technical studies In our main result and after identifying and utilizing the very few symmetries of cid unit disks we design optimal evacuation algorithms that vary with Our main technical contributions are two fold First in our upper bound results we provide nearly closed formulae for the worst case cost of our algorithms Second and most importantly our lower bounds arguments reduce to novel observation in convex geometry which analyzes trade offs between arc and chord lengths of cid pun it disks as the endpoints of the arcs chords change position around the perimeter of the disk which we believe is interesting in its own right Part of our argument pertaining to the latter property relies on computer assisted numerical ver cation that can be done for non extreme values of Keywords Search Evacuation Wireless model cid metric space Convex and computational geometry

Eec ts of magnetic excitation and transitions on vacancy formation cases of fcc Fe and Ni compared to bcc Fe Kang ming Li Chu Chun Fu Universit Paris clay CEA Service de Recherches de Met all ur gie Physique Gif sur Yvette France Anton Schneider Engineering Physics Department University of Wisconsin Madison WI USA Vacancy is one of the most frequent defects in metals We study the impacts of magnetism on vacancy formation properties in fcc Ni and in bcc and fcc Fe via density functional theory FT and eec ti ve interaction models combined with Monte Carlo simulations Overall the predicted vacancy formation energies and equilibrium vacancy concentrations are in good agreement with experimental data available only at the high temperature para magnetic regime Eec ts of magnetic transitions on vacancy formation energies are found to be more important in bcc Fe than in fcc Fe and Ni The distinct behaviour is correlated to the relative roles of longitudinal and trans versa spin excitation At variance with the bcc Fe case we note clear eec of longitudinal spin excitation on the magnetic free energy of vacancy formation in fcc Fe and Ni leading to its steady variation above the respective magnetic transition temperature Below the Neel point such eec in fcc Fe is comparable but opposite to the one of the trans versa excitation Regarding fcc Ni although neglecting the longitudinal spin excitation induces an over estimation of the Curie temperature by no additional eec tis visible below the Curie point The distinct eec son the three systems are closely linked toD FT predictions of the dependence of vacancy formation energy on the variation of local magnetic moment magnitudes and orientations

How to avoid machine learning pitfalls guide for academic researchers Michael Lone Abstract This document gives concise outline of some of the common mistakes that occur when using machine learning techniques and what can be done to avoid them It is intended primarily as guide for research students and focuses on issues that are of particular concern within academic research such as the need to do rigorous comparisons and reach valid conclusions It covers ve stages of the machine learning process what to do before model building how to reliably build models how to robustly evaluate models how to compare models fairly and how to report results

On the Behavior of Superconductors of High Critical Temperatures Outside Schwarz child Black Holes in AdS Space On the Behavior of Superconductors of High Critical Temperatures Outside Schwarz child Black Holes in AdS Space Musk Dated August Condensed matter systems can be di cult to physically analyze due to strong coupling but the mathematical context of the AdS FT correspondence allows for non perturb at ive descriptions in terms of dual weakly coupled systems This analysis reviews holographic condensed matter applications of AdS FT in modeling superconductor with high critical temperature outside Schwarz child black hole in Anti de Sitter space This is initially done using simple two dimensional electron condensate Lagrangian previously employed by Horowitz used to calculate frequency dependent conductivity and free energy analysis the asymptotic of both in this procedure are also examined An extended Lagrangian with higher order Maxwell term is assessed thereafter with conductivity peak obtained at low frequencies described well by the rude model in certain limits The behavior of the rude model parameter in these limits is also investigated PAC numbers Hf Keywords AdS FT correspondence Condensed matter Superconductor Critical temperature

Missing ness Augmentation General Approach for Improving Generative Imputation Models Yu feng Wang ID Dan Li Cong Xu ID Min Yang ID Abstract Despite tremendous progress in missing data imputation task designing new imputation models has become more and more cumbersome but the corresponding gains are relatively small Is there any simple but general approach that can exploit the existing models to further improve the quality of the imputation In this article we aim to respond to this concern and propose novel general data augmentation method called Missing ness Augmentation MA which can be applied in many existing generative imputation frameworks to further improve the performance of these models ForM before each training epoch we use the outputs of the generator to expand the incomplete samples on they and then determine special reconstruction loss for these augmented samples This reconstruction loss plus the original loss constitutes the nal optimization objective of the model It is noteworthy that MA is very efc ent and does not need to change the structure of the original model Experimental results demonstrate that MAcan sign cant ly improve the performance of many recently developed generative imputation models on variety of datasets Our code is available at https it hub com Yu Feng Missing ness Augmentation Index Terms data augmentation generative model incomplete data imputation cid

PREDICTING POST CONCUSSION SYNDROME OUTCOMES WITH MACHINE LEARNING Min hong Kim Gyeonggi Suwon International School ABSTRACT In this paper machine learning models are used to predict outcomes for patients with persistent post concussion syndrome PCS Patients had sustained concussion at an average of two to three months before the study By utilizing assessed data the machine learning models aimed to predict whether or not patient would continue to have PCS after four to ve months The random forest classier achieved the highest performance with an accuracy and an area under the receiver operating characteristic curve UC of Factors found to be predictive of PCS outcome were Post Traumatic Stress Disorder PTSD perceived injustice self rated prognosis and symptom severity post injury The results of this study demonstrate that machine learning models can predict PCS outcomes with high accuracy With further research machine learning models maybe implemented in healthcare settings to help patients with persistent PCS Keywords post concussion syndrome concussion machine learning PCS outcome

Practices of public procurement and the risk of corrupt behavior before and after the government transition in Mexico Andrea Falcon Cortes Andres Al dana and Hernan Larra de Instituto de Ciencia sic as Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico Morelos Mexico Instituto de Bio tecnol oga Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico Morelos Mexico Centro de Ciencia de la Comp le ji dad Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico Ciudad de Mexico Mexico Dated August Abstract Corruption has huge impact on economic growth democracy inequality and its consequences at the human level are incalculable However government turnover maybe expected to generate sign cant changes in the way public contracting is done and thus in the levels and types of corruption involved in public procurement In this respect Mexico lived historical government transition in In this work we analyze data from more than million contracts corresponding from to to study to what extent this change of government aec ted the characteristics of public contracting and we try to determine whether these changes ect how corruption takes place To do this we propose statistical framework to compare the characteristics of the contracting practices within each administration separating the contracts in die rent classes depending on whether or not they were made with companies that have now been den tied as being involved in corrupt practices We found that even when the total number of contracts and the amount of resources spent in contracts with corrupt companies decreased after the government transition many of the patterns followed to contract suppliers labeled as corrupt were maintained and those in which changes did occur are suggestive of larger risk of corruption

Using Metamorphic Relations to Verify and Enhance Art code Classic ation cid Liming Xu Dave To we yb Andrew French Steve Benford Zhi Quan Zhou Tsong Yue Chen Department of Engineering University of Cambridge Cambridge United Kingdom School of Computer Science University of Nottingham Ningbo China Ningbo China School of Computer Science University of Nottingham Nottingham United Kingdom School of Computing and Information Technology University of Wollongong Australia Department of Computer Science and Software Engineering Swinburne University of Technology Australia Abstract Software testing is often hindered where it is impossible or impractical to determine the correctness of the behaviour or output of the software under test UT situation known as the oracle problem An example of an area facing the oracle problem is automatic image classic ation using machine learning to classify an input image as one of set of pre de ned classes An approach to software testing that alleviates the oracle problem is metamorphic testing MT While traditional software testing examines the correctness of individual test cases MT instead examines the relations amongst multiple executions of test cases and their outputs These relations are called metamorphic relations MRs if an MR is found to be violated then fault must exist in the UT This paper examines the problem of classifying images containing visually hidden markers called Art codes and applies MT to verify and enhance the trained classier This paper further examines two MRs Separation and Occlusion and reports on their capability in verifying the image classic ation using one way analysis of variance NOVA in conjunction with three other statistical analysis methods test for unequal variances Kruskal Wallis test and Dunne tt test In addition to our previously studied classier that used Random Forests we introduce new classier that uses support vector machine and present its MR augmented version Experimental evaluations across number of performance metrics show that the augmented classier can achieve better performance than non augmented classier This paper also analyses how the enhanced cid This work is an extension of an MET paper Xue tal which was completed while the rst author was PhD student at University of Nottingham Ningbo China Corresponding author Email addresses cam ac uk Liming Xu dave to Lossy Quantum Defect Theory of Ultra cold Molecular Collisions Arthur Christian en Gerri Gro en en boom and Ti js Karma Max Planck Institut fur Quan ten op tik Garching Germany Munich Center for Quantum Science and Technology Munchen Germany Rad bou University Institute for Molecules and Materials Heij end lse weg Nijmegen the Netherlands Dated August We consider losses in collisions of ultra cold molecules described by simple statistical short range model that explicitly accounts for the limited lifetime of classically chaotic collision complexes This con rms that thermally sampling many isolated resonances leads to loss cross section equal to the elastic cross section derived by May leet al Ph ys Rev and this makes precise the conditions under which this is the case Surprisingly we nd that the loss is non universal We also consider the case that loss broadens the short range resonances to the point that they become overlapping The overlapping resonances can be treated statistically even if the resonances are sparse compared tok which maybe the case for many molecules The overlap results in Ericson uc tu at ions which yield an on universal short range boundary condition that is independent of energy over range much wider than is sampled thermally Deviations of experimental loss rates from the present theory beyond statistical uc tu at ions and the dependence on background phase shift are interpreted as non chaotic dynamics of short range collision complexes

Disentangling Pauli blocking of atomic decay from cooperative radiation and atomic motion in Fermi gas Thomas Bil it ew ski sier Pine ro Ori oli Christian San ner Lindsay So nder house Ross Huts on Ling feng Yan William Milner Jun Ye and An Maria Rey JIL National Institute of Standards and Technology and Department of Physics University of Colorado Boulder CO USA Center for Theory of Quantum Matter University of Colorado Boulder CO USA Dated August The observation of Pauli blocking of atomic spontaneous decay via direct measurements of the atomic population requires the use of long lived atomic gases where quantum statistics atom recoil and cooperative radiative processes are all relevant We develop theoretical framework capable of simultaneously accounting for all these eec ts in regime where prior theoretical approaches based on semi classical non interacting or interacting frozen atom approximations fail We apply it to atoms in single pancake or arrays of pancakes featuring an eec ti ve level structure one excited and two degenerate ground states We identify parameter window in which factor of two extension in the atomic lifetime clearly attributable to Pauli blocking should be experimentally ob serva ble in deeply degenerate gases with atoms Our predictions are supported by observation of number dependent excited state decay rate on the transition in Sr atoms

Topology Optimization for Manufacturing with Accessible Support Structures Amir Mir zen deh del Mora Be hand ish and Saigo pal Nel at uri Palo Alto Research Center PARC Coyote Hill Road Palo Alto California Abstract Metal additive manufacturing AM processes often fabricate near net shape that includes the as designed part as well as the crici al support structures that need to be machined away by subtractive manufacturing SM for instance multi axis machining Thus although AM is capable of generating highly complex parts the limitations of SM due to possible collision between the milling tool and the work piece can render an optimized part non manu fact ur able We present systematic approach to topology optimization TO of parts for AM followed by SM to ensure remo ability of support structures while optimizing the parts performance central idea is to express the prod uci bil it of the part from the near net shape in terms of accessibility of every support structure point using given set of cutting tool assemblies and turing orientations Our approach does not impose any art ici al constraints on geometric complexity of the part support structures machining tools and turing devices We extend the notion of inaccessibility measure el IMF to support structures to identify the inaccessible points and capture their contributions to non manu fact ur ability by continuous spatial el IMF is then augmented to the sensitivity el to guide the TO towards manu fact ur able design The approach enable sec ent and eec ti ve design space exploration by ding nontrivial complex designs whose near net shape can be printed and post processed for support removal by machining with custom set of tools and ture We demonstrate the ecac of our approach on nontrivial examples in and Keywords Design for Manufacturing Topology Optimization Support Structures Accessibility Analysis Multi Axis Machining Cong ration Space Hybrid Manufacturing

JOURNAL OF LATEX CLASS FILES VOL NO AUGUST Out of domain Generalization from Single Source Uncertainty Quant cation Approach Xi Peng Feng chun Qi ao and Long Zhao Abstract We study worst case scenario in generalization Out of domain generalization from single source The goal is to learn robust model from single source and expect it to generalize over many unknown distributions This challenging problem has been seldom investigated while existing solutions suffer from various limitations such as the ignorance of uncertainty assessment and label augmentation In this paper we propose uncertainty guided domain generalization to tackle the aforementioned limitations The key idea is to augment the source capacity in both feature and label spaces while the augmentation is guided by uncertainty assessment To the best of our knowledge this is the rst work to quantify the generalization uncertainty from single source and leverage it to guide both feature and label augmentation for robust generalization The model training and deployment are effectively organized in Bayesian meta learning framework We conduct extensive comparisons and abl ation study to validate our approach The results prove our superior performance in wide scope of tasks including imageclass cation semantic segmentation text classic ation and speech recognition Index Terms Domain Generalization Bayesian Inference Adversarial Training Meta Learning Uncertainty Quant cation cid

Building Foundation for Data Driven Interpret able and Robust Policy Design using the Economist Alexander Trott Sun il Srinivasa Do uwe van der Wal Sebastien Han euse and Stephan Zheng Sales force Research Harvard University August Abstract Optimizing economic and public policy is critical to address socioeconomic issues and trade offs improving equality productivity or wellness and poses complex mechanism design problem policy designer needs to consider multiple objectives policy levers and behavioral responses from strategic actors who optimize for their individual objectives Moreover real world policies should be explain able and robust to simulation to reality gaps due to calibration issues Existing approaches are often limited to narrow set of policy levers or objectives that are hard to measure do not yield explicit optimal policies or do not consider strategic behavior for example Hence it remains challenging to optimize policy in real world scenarios Here we show that the Economist framework enables effective ex ble and interpret able policy design using two level reinforcement learning RL and data driven simulations We validate our framework on optimizing the stringency of US state policies and Federal subsidies during pandemic OVID using simulation ted to real data We nd that log linear policies trained using RL sign cant ly improve social welfare based on both public health and economic outcomes compared to past outcomes Their behavior can be explained well performing policies respond strongly to changes in recovery and vaccination rates They are also robust to calibration errors infection rates that are over or underestimated As of yet real world policy making has not seen adoption of machine learning methods at large including RL and driven simulations Our results show the potential of to guide policy design and improve social welfare amidst the complexity of the real world AT and SZ contributed equally Correspondence to stephan zheng sales force com AT SH and SZ developed the theoretical framework DW and AT cataloged and processed data AT and

Non contact friction The role of ph on on damping and its non universality Mir Lee Richard Vink Cynthia Volker and Matthias rger Institute for Theoretical Physics Georg August Universit ttingen ttingen Germany Institute of Materials Physics Georg August Universit ttingen ttingen Germany Dated August While obtaining theoretical predictions for dissipation during sliding motion is adi cult task one regime that allows for analytical results is the so called non contact regime where probe is weakly interacting with the surface over which it moves Studying this regime for model crystal we extend previously obtained analytical results and con rm them quantitatively via particle based computer simulations Accessing the subtle regime of weak coupling in simulations is possible via use of Green Kubo relations The analysis allows to extract and compare the two paradigmatic mechanisms that have been found to lead to dissipation ph on on radiation prevailing even in purely elastic solid and ph on on damping caused by viscous motion of crystal atoms While ph on on radiation is dominant at large probe surface distances ph on on damping dominates at small distances Ph on on radiation is furthermore pairwise additive phenomenon so that the dissipation due to interaction with die rent parts areas of the surface adds up This additive scaling results from general one to one mapping between the mean probe surface force and the friction due toph on on radiation irrespective of the nature of the underlying pair interaction In contrast ph on on damping is strongly non additive and no such general relation exists We show that for certain cases the dissipation can even decrease with increasing surface area the probe interacts with The above properties which are rooted in the spatial correlations of surface uc tu at ions are expected to have important consequences when interpreting experimental measurements as well as scaling with system size

CAMPANA TO REGULARITY THEORY FOR MULTI VALUED FUNCTIONS WITH APPLICATIONS TO MINIMAL SURFACE REGULARITY THEORY PAUL INTER Abstract The regularity theory of the Campana to space has been successfully used to understand the regularity of solutions to certain geometric variation al problems Here we extend this theory to multi valued functions adapting for the most part Campana to original ideas in Cam We then give an application within the regularity theory of st tio nary integral var folds More precisely we prove regularity theorem for certain blow up classes of functions which typically arise when studying blow ups of sequences of stationary integral var folds converging to higher multiplicity planes or unions of half planes In such setting based in part on ideas in Wi and KW we are able to deduce boundary regularity theory for multi valued harmonic functions which is the rst of its kind In con junction with Min the results he reestablish regularity theorem for stable co dimension one integral var folds near classical cones of density Contents Preliminaries Multi Valued Campana to Regularity Theory Applications to Minimal Surface Theory References Multi valued functions were rst introduced by Alm gren to study the branching behaviour of area minim ising currents In recent years multi valued functions have success fully been used to describe the structure of large classes of stationary integral var folds near multiplicity two planes and in particular near multiplicity two branch points see Wi Wi KW In order to understand the structure of stationary integral var folds close to higher multiplicity planes or higher multiplicity non at cones see Min we need to develop suitable regularity results for special classes of multi valued functions for the app lica ions we have in mind such classes are known as proper blow up class see Wi for key example The functions within proper blow up class are generated by taking scaling limits of approximate graphical representations of sequences of certain stationary integral var folds converging to axed stationary cone The functions within given blow up class are typically multi valued in most cases of interest de ned on either an open ball of half ball in plane and inherit certain integral estimates from the stationary assumption on the var folds When it is possible to use these estimates to deduce regularity of the functions within blow up class is key problem in geometric measure theory and is the motivation for our work here In conjunction with Min this work establishes regularity theory for stable

Incremental learning of STM framework for sensor fusion in attitude estimation Para Nark he de Ra hee Wa lambe Shashi Pod dar Ket an Kote cha Symbiosis Institute of Technology Symbiosis International Deemed University Pune Maharashtra India Symbiosis Centre for Applied Artificial Intelligence Symbiosis International Deemed University Pune Maharashtra India Central Scientific Instruments Organisation Council of Scientific and Industrial Research Chandigarh Chandigarh India DOI peer cs Subject Areas Artificial Intelligence Autonomous Systems Robotics Keywords Attitude estimation Inertial sensors Incremental learning Long Short Term Memory Sensor fusion Cite this article Nark he de Wa lambe Pod dar Kote cha Incremental learning of STM framework for sensor fusion in attitude estimation Peer Computer Science https doi org peer cs Abstract This paper presents novel method for attitude estimation of an object in space by incremental learning of the Long Short Term Memory STM network Gyroscope acc el ero meter and magneto meter are few widely used sensors in attitude estimation applications Traditionally multi sensor fusion methods such as the Extended Kal man Filter and Complementary Filter are employed to fuse the measurements from these sensors However these methods exhibit limitations in accounting for the uncertainty unpredictability and dynamic nature of the motion in real world situations In this paper the inertial sensors data are fed to the STM network which are then updated increment ally to incorporate the dynamic changes in motion occurring in the run time The robustness and efficiency of the proposed framework is demonstrated on the data set collected from commercially available inertial measurement unit The proposed framework offers significant improvement in the results compared to the traditional method even in the case of highly dynamic environment The STM framework based attitude estimation approach can be deployed on standard supported processing module for real time applications Cite this article Nark he de Wa lambe Pod dar Kote cha Incremental learning of STM framework for sensor fusion in attitude estimation Peer Computer Science https doi org peer cs

Under consideration for publication in Theory and Practice of Logic Programming Transformation Enabled Precondition Inference ISH OK SAN AFL IM DE Software Institute Madrid Spain mail ish ok san afl im de org GRAEME GANG PETER STUCKEY Faculty of IT Monash University Clayton Vic Australia mail graeme gang peter stuckey monash edu PETER SCHACHT HARALD NDER GA ARD School of Computing and Information Systems The University of Melbourne Vic Australia mail schacht harald uni mel edu au submitted January revised January accepted January Abstract Precondition inference is an on trivial problem with important applications in program analysis and ver cation We present novel iterative method for automatically deriving preconditions for the safety and un safety of programs Each iteration maintains over approximations of the set of safe and unsafe initial states which are used to partition the programs initial states into those known to be safe known to be unsafe and unknown We then construct revised programs with those unknown initial states and iterate the procedure until the approximations are disjoint or some termination criteria are met An experimental evaluation of the method on set of software ver cation benchmarks shows that it can infer precise preconditions sometimes optimal that are not possible using previous methods It is under consideration for acceptance in TPL

Localization PT Symmetry Breaking and Topological Transitions in non Hermit ian Quasi crystals run Prasad Acharya Adit Chakra barty and Deepak Kumar ahu Department of Physics and Astronomy National Institute of Technology Rourke la dish India San joy Datta Department of Physics and Astronomy National Institute of Technology Rourke la dish India and Center for Nano materials National Institute of Technology Rourke la dish India Dated August According to the topological band theory of Hermit ian system the die rent electronic phases are class ed in terms of topological in variants where in the transition between the two phases chara teri zed by die rent topological invariant is the primary signature of topological phase transition Recently it has been argued that the delocalization localization transition in quasi crystal de scribe by the non Hermit ian PT symmetric extension of the Aubry Andre Harper AH Ham il tonian can also be den tied as topological phase transition Interestingly the PT symmetry also breaks down at the same critical point However in this article we have shown that the delocalization localization transition and the PT symmetry breaking are not connected to topo logical phase transition To demonstrate this we have studied the non Hermit ian PT symmetric AH Hamiltonian in the presence of Rash ba Spin Orbit SO coupling We have obtained an analytical expression of the topological transition point and compared it with the numerically ob tai ned critical points We have found that except in some special cases the critical point and the topological transition point are not the same In fact the delocalization localization transition takes place earlier than the topological transition whenever they do not coincide

Under consideration for publication in Theory and Practice of Logic Programming Here and There with Arithmetic Vladimir if sch itz University of Texas at Austin USA submitted January revised January accepted January Abstract In the theory of answer set programming two groups of rules are called strongly equivalent if informally speaking they have the same meaning in any context The relationship between strong equivalence and the propositional logic of here and there allows us to establish strong equivalence by deriving rules of each group from rules of the other In the process rules are rewritten as propositional formulas We extend this method of proving strong equivalence to an answer set programming language that includes operations on integers The formula representing rule in this language is rst order formula that may contain comparison symbols among its predicate constants and symbols for arithmetic operations among its function constants The paper is under consideration for acceptance in TPL

Quantum Quan tile Mechanics Solving Stochastic Dieren ti al Equations for Generating Time Series Annie Paine Vincent Elf ving and Oleksandr Ky ri ien ko Qu Co PO Box AW Amsterdam The Netherlands Department of Physics and Astronomy University of Exeter Stocker Road Exeter EX QL United Kingdom Dated August We propose quantum algorithm for sampling from solution of stochastic dieren ti al equations DEs Using dieren ti able quantum circuits QC with feature map encoding of latent variables we represent the quan tile function for an underlying probability distribution and extract samples as QC expectation values Using quan tile mechanics we propagate the system in time there by allowing for time series generation We test the method by simulating the Or nste in hlen beck process and sampling at times die rent from the initial point as required in nanci al analysis and data set augmentation Additionally we analyse continuous quantum gene at ive adversarial networks qG AN and show that they represent quan tile functions with amo died reordered shape that impedes their ec ent time propagation Our results shed light on the connection between quantum quan tile mechanics QQ and qG AN for DE based distributions and point the importance of dieren ti al constraints for model training analogously with the recent success of physics informed neural networks

Temporally Abstract Partial Models him yaK he tar pal Za far ali Ahmed Gheorghe Co manic Do in Pre cup McGill University Mila Deep Mind Abstract Humans and animals have the ability to reason and make predictions about different courses of action at many timescales In reinforcement learning option models Sutton Pre cup Singh Pre cup provide the framework for this kind of temporally abstract prediction and reasoning Natural intelligent agents are also able to focus their attention on courses of action that are relevant or feasible in given situation sometimes termed affordable actions In this paper we de ne notion of afford ances for options and develop temporally abstract partial option models that take into account the fact that an option might be affordable only in certain situations We analyze the trade offs between estimation and approximation error in planning and learning when using such models and identify some interesting special cases Additionally we demonstrate empirically the potential impact of partial option models on the efc ien cy of planning
